												My wife has played through every race/ class combination possible, hence the 1300+ hours on record.  She has replayed the dwarf and human noble origins repeatedely just to know all possible outcomes (her favorite seems to be a dwarf rogue).  She is so good at playing the game she can run through it up to the final battle over a weekend (friday night, saturday, done sunday noon)  i was only able to write this review because she is at work.  ...I miss my wife, can i have her back yet? I guess i should recommend it because she plays it so voraciously?EDIT: 4/8/15: HOLY FRAK PEOPLE! :D  for those of you thave have commented: Yes the wife thinks i am like Alistair sometimesYes i have a beardYes she slays the dragons in the family...so far... but I am slowly catching up. (well she doesn't slay them directly per se, but she sets up the dragon to be slain by some warrior/fighter, typically Aveline, Fenris, or Iron Bull) DA 2 was just as time consuming as DA: O (but with only 700-ish hours gameplay over 2014; less choices with char-gen means less replayability for her, only 6-8 characters made this time instead of 30-40) DA: I ( which i just got for her in Feb. as a late X-mas gift) has totally consumed her time (AGAIN!) but with her new job she has only managed 300 hours (i estimate about 25 of it are my two characters) She is frustrated she cannot romance Varricshe loves Iron Bull  (who the hell doesn't he's got the best lines, along with Sera) i told her no DLC until the main storyline is finished,  she gave me puppy dog eyes, i haven't cracked...yet... I may be a bit biased but yes i do believe she is very awesome and I can geek out with her without her eyes glazing over, alternatively i dont Glaze-out either when she geeks out at me.  ...so, hooray?  for totally life consuming video games...?

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												Disclaimer: This is my favorite game of all time, so I apologize for any obsessive fan-girling that may occur within this review.tl;dr Pro's and Con's list at the bottom.Theres so many things I could say about this game, I love it so much.  A majority of my time playing is on console, where I easily have 500+ hours, as well as every achievement in the game as well as additional content.  I'm not much of a reviewer (this being my first lengthy one), so to keep it simple I'll seperate it into sections.Character Creation/Leveling-     There is a fair bit of customization when you create your character.  There are 3 races to choose from (Human, Dwarf, and Elf) which all give different bonus stats.  From there, you will pick your characters class (Warrior, Rogue, or Mage).  All of those classes expand at later levels, with your choice of sub-classes for each (unlocked at levels 7 and 14), which are unlocked by doing different things in the game, or learning them from certain characters.  So no, you aren't born with the ability to magically understand how to be a Bard, or a Templar, you need to actually be taught by someone, or learn the knowledge elsewhere.  Visual choices are alright, standard RPG things like different hair, different eyes, all of which will be covered by a helmet/cowl anyway no doubt.  Either way, you could always grab a mod or two for more character visuals, but I'll try to keep this review on the base game alone.  When you level up there are hefty decisions to be made.  Not only are there abilities for you to use in combat, there are also different abilties for out of combat purposes.  Are you going to put that point into your combat knowledge, unlocking the next tier of weapon abilites?  Or are you going to put it in lockpicking?  The next dungeon might have a door you can't quite pick yet.  Choose carefully...Story-     The best thing about this game is the enthralling story!  From character creation, based on your race, and class even changes how your story begins.  Are you a human noble, living cozy in your castle?  Perhaps a dwarf whose fallen on hard times, and has gone down a life of crime.  Maybe even a mage, stripped from your family and sent off to the Circle of Magi to be watched by the Templars.  In most cases, different events from your "Origin" story come back to either aid/hinder you based on how you handled them.  This game is full of heart-wrenching decisions, where you need to decide between being the good guy, or getting something that would be extremely helpful on your quest/not put you in danger.  There's a fair bit of situations where there is no clear-cut decision to be a good guy, someone is getting hurt and it will be your fault, and you can be sure it will change how certain people treat you/your story in general.Characters-     I might have lied about the story being the best part, because the different characters in the game are amazing.  I could go hours talking about the different personalities characters have, but I'll stick just to your party in this, because that's who you'll spend most of the time with obviously.  Your party as it starts getting full, is a ragtag group of different people, with various different outlooks on things. Literally, you might have an apostate witch, a templar, a chantry zealot, and a drunken dwarf all at once.   Each party member has a relationship bar, which goes up or down depending on your decisions and how you talk to them, which in turn effects how they treat you/open up to you.  You could make someone spit in your face and leave the party for good, or even turn and attack you, or they could open up to you about their past giving you a special quest to help them with something personal.  On top of balancing decisons on how it will effect you, and the world around you, you also have to think of how your party members will react to it.  Each character in you party has a lot of diologue opportunities, and if you pay close attention you might be able to find them a gift relevant to something they have said, or perform an action they mentioned.  You can even have relationships with some of the characters, and watch a blooming love grow, as well as listen to the rest of your party snicker and banter about you and soandso last night in a tent together.  If one party member is growing affectionate of you, you can see them get jealous when they discover your relationship with another.You know characters are a big part, when some of the ADD ON CONTENT IS FOR THE CHARACTERS.  Some of the additional content in the game focuses on a certain characters past, and another on his/her events after the story.  Of course based on what you did in the story, it effects it as well.Gameplay-     If you played Dragon Age 2, don't expect this game to be as hack and slash as that one was.  This is by far much more tactical.  One of the coolest features is allowing you to set up your party members tactics in certain situations.  You can set a condition where if 4 enemies are clumped together, your mage shoots a fireball in the center of them, or if your tank gets below 20% health, your Warrior activates an ability to take aggro off of him.  On harder difficulties, you might find yourself hitting the spacebar key pretty quick to pause the game, so you can asses the situation, and assign party members specific orders.Difficulty-     If your new to the game, start on the easiest mode for sure.  This game is brutal on harder difficulties, and while the ability to set your AI party's tactics is beneficial, you will need to be able to know what abilities do what, the different sub-classes to branch down..etc.  Even on easy, you'll find yourself in some situations pausing, and getting some much needed healing done, or think on how to take down a challenging foe.  (Seriously, f*** Revenants).  And remember to be careful when setting your Mage's tactics, there IS FRIENDLY FIRE with mage abilities.  That fireball you just set to go off when the enemies clumped?  You killed them, but your rogue with them.Glitches/Bugs-     There are of course some glitches in the game, scaling from minor textures on occasion, to something that could ruin a combat situation and make you die.  Some of the notable ones include:-Enemies not spawning in missions if you leave a set area/charge their spawn-Your attack speed going back to default if it gets insanely high-Your character not being able to get good placement in combat, making him run in place-A certain party members arm getting stuck in place like she's waiting for a bird to perch on it-Gifts not giving the appropriate amount of points on the relationship barAnd you might find a couple others.  Fortunately, the major ones are fixable by mods that are readily avalible on sites such as Nexus mods.  However as I said before, I'm reviewing this based on the base game.Pros and Cons-Pros:-Amazing story!-Heart-wrenching decisions, some with no clear-cut good or bad answer.-Characters and how they react to what you do!-Your party cast, and the relationship bar!-Manageable AI tactics for your party!-Harder difficulties are brutally challenging.-You can wrangle nugs!Cons:-A few glitches/bugs.  Nothing that ruins your gaming experience for more than a few moments.-The lack of sun you'll be getting isn't good for your complexion.-After playing this Dragon Age 2 is a big let-down. :(My rating of course, is a 10/10!  While there are a few bugs and glitches, they aren't so notable that it ruins your gaming experience more than just a few minute, if that.  The story is just phenominal!  The game is challenging, on the harder difficulties each battle you win feels like an achievement, and you find yourself stocking up and using everything you have on boss battles, most of the time narrowly making it through.  This game is a must play if you haven't already!

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												Words cannot describe how much I love this game, so allow me to describe it in words. Crafted by the same studio that has made some of my favorite RPGs of all time, Dragon Age answers the question of whether or not Bioware can create a compelling medieval fantasy RPG that isn't D&D based. The answer is a resounding yes. While containing many of the trappings of past RPGs like Neverwinter Nights and Baldur's Gate, Dragon Age works its own magic by offering three classes that can be customized by an almost infinite amount, six different origin stories for the player character, and doing away with the traditional good/evil morality mechanic in favor of one based on individual party approval or disapproval of your actions.Each character in your party is believable and compelling, likeable for different reasons, and some can be romanced or change their outlook depending on how the story progresses. Every major questline can have different outcomes depending on player choices and it's this feeling of agency in the world that keeps the replay value in this game. Dragon Age has often been called a dark RPG and rightly so, as the story is much less straight forward than a typical RPG. Often you will find yourself having to deal with choices where there is no clear cut "good" or "evil" outcome which is part of why player choice feels so meaningful.And on top of all that, the game is a lot of fun. I remember the first time playing this game and saying "this is the game that Neverwinter Nights 2 should have been!" It still holds up, probably even more so against its sequel which in some ways is unfortunate. If you love western RPGs and loved the past work of Bioware, you will love this game. I give it two severed darkspawn thumbs way up!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Dragon Age: Origins, debatably the last good game of Bioware's making, is a very intricate and detailed, although at sometimes cliche, foray into an action-adventure medieval setting.Gameplay - Personally, this was my favorite part of the game. I loved the real time with pause system, and always have with other games such as KOTOR. My only complaint is that melee and ranged did not seem to shine as well as the magic system, especially with mana versus stamina. Often, I played as Morrigan instead of the Warden just because it was much more fun. The tactics system is well-done but the AI could use some more work, especially with rogues - even though they were supposed to go behind enemies for backstabs, more often than not, I had to do it myself. I feel as though the wide amount of abilities would easily allow for a just-as-fun second or third playthrough.Story - The overarching storyline of the Blight was predictable, but I feel as though the game shines in the whole adventure there (as you don't "directly" deal with the blight until the ending) was much better. The characters involved in the story were well-written and the many dialogue options involved with most major NPCs was refreshing, although expected of Bioware's team. One of my favorite parts of the game related to story was the lore behind the whole games. As a TES fan, especially Morrowind, I really enjoyed the codex and each of its entries. The Fade was a unique concept which, although tedious in-game, was a great concept and a take on the supernatural that I hadn't seen in any game.Characters - I should preface this by saying that my main party consisted of myself, a human noble, Morrigan, Sten, and Shale. I opted for Shale instead of a vanilla character simply because I wanted a tank in my party. I tried to talk to each character a lot individually though, besides the secret companion, who I opted to not join my party. I romanced Zevran and Alistair (in order to take the throne) and felt that the amount of dialogue options and their own quests were really well-done. My advice for the game, if you want to be much more into the story and characters, is to set it to easy/normal and play with whom you like.That about wraps it up. You can easily spend 50 hours in a single play-through if you do more of the quests than I did, such as the rogue mage group, chantry quests, and each of the unique quests that your party members give you (Sten's sword, Flemeth, etc). It's very worth your time.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Dragons Age is well a put together RPG that will immerse you in the story and you will invest time in developing the characters that accompany you on your quest.  The biggest downside to the game is the story is tried, tired and done a thousand times over.  You the hero are on quest to destroy the dark spawn that is wreaking havoc on the land.  This being its biggest downfall does not make this a bad game at all.  I had over 70hours in one play through and with all the decision making you encounter this game will surely keep you amused for multiple plays.  One of the best combat systems I've seen  you can not only setup the AI to have your companions on the quest do what you like but you can fully take control of them which in my opinion is a huge advantage.  The combat system is a little bit of learning curve but once you get the hang of it you will love it and enjoy the simpleness of how your characters act and follow your directions in the heat of some best battles you will see in an RPG.  Bioware did an excellent job in creating a game you can fully plunge yourself into and get behind.

Posted: December 19, 2014
Reviews for the Deaf and Hard of HearingOverall Rating: 9/10Gameplay Rating: 9/10Accessibility Rating: 8/10Overall rating is a combination of the gameplay (mechanics and story) and accessibility (how the game includes deaf/hoh gamers).Overall GameplayDA:O's game format is very much in line with similar games by Bioware, ranging from Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic I/II, Mass Effect, etc.  If you're familiar with those games, you will understand the controls of this game.  If you haven't experienced those games, I would suggest each of them in addition to the Dragon Age line.These tend to be very story-rich games, and DA:O is no exception.  Starting out, you create a character in a very scaled-back Dungeons and Dragons format.  You decide between male/female, elf/human/dwarf, and warrior/mage/rogue.  As you progress, there are further specializations you can pick up, such as a rogue bard or a mage healer.At almost 30 hours of play, I am around 15-20% complete with the main storyline, so there's significant play time for the cost of the game.  Further, replay value comes from different character types, gender, and race, as well as modified slightly by the abilities of your character, such as intimidation or persuasion abilities.I am enjoying this game and will continue to play it beyond one playthrough.General AccessibilityDA:O primarily uses QWES to strafe/move and A/D to turn the camera.  I tend to hold right click to manipulate the camera and just use W to run forward.  The complexity of games like this require more keyboard use than an FPS, so different windows, HUDs, and menus can be accessed by various keys.  All keys can be rebound, making it a little more convenient for mobility-related issues.In line with all games of this type from Bioware, the combat in the game can be paused so that you can issue orders to your party members.  In combat, you can pause as often as you need to, which helps balance the game experience out for all gamers, regardless of needs.Subtitles & CaptionsSpeech is captioned in this game.  Important text is captioned so that you can read it readily and up-front and ambient speech (such as NPCs or banter between supporting characters in your party) shows up over their heads and can be read as you do other things.  Captions do not use color-coding, but conversations happen sequentially rather than simultaneously, and display the character on screen so you know who is talking.One complaint is that these background conversations, captions may be missed entirely, depending on the camera angles.  These are usually interesting or funny conversations that help develop the characters and their relationships, but, more than once, I have only caught the end of them.  Part of the draw of games like this is getting immersed in the environment, but this is hard to do when the mechanics of the game do not permit it.There is nothing in the game that requires being able to hear or hear well that I am aware of.Chatting/CommunicatingDA:O is single-player.No rating.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
 “Dragon Age: Origins is simply one of those games you have to play no matter if you like that genre or not."  TL;DR:  Buy it. Please. Note: This review doesn’t contain any spoiler. I did in fact play the DLC, but this Review only focuses on the main game.  Feel free to add me on Steam, if you have questions about DA:O!    Graphic 7/10 I guess that’s the weakest aspect of DA:O, and it still is better than many games of that genre. Animations are quite okay, nothing fancy here, but the atmosphere of the game is unbelievable. You’ve ever dreamt of a battlefield that actually looks like one? Here you have it. Even though you’ll come along some weird animations, bad textures and some bugs (typically for such huge games), you won’t be disappointed. It’s still beautiful. Sound 10/10 You may can say that it’s not the best looking game, but you can’t argue with me that it doesn’t sound awesome. First things first: Yes, every character is voiced and every actor did a pretty good job. I couldn’t remember any bad one. The background music is excellent. You’ll immediately fall in love with it. I could list 100 things about the sound part, but I guess a 10/10 stands for itself.  Story: 9/10 Story is always a hard one to judge. It’s often personal preference if you like it or not. If you see the deeper meanings or if you actually care about the background of everyone around you. The story is damn well presented and is overall superb. If you break it down it in fact would come down of being just another “We got invaded by some f*cking weird boss monster and you have to save the world bla bla” and even if it may look like it is just that, it really is more. Just explore it on your own and you’ll see how good it actually is, if you just spend enough time.  Gameplay: 10/10 Let me give you a little bit of a backstory here for all of you undecided ones: I NEVER played a round-based game before DA:O and I had my reasons for it. I always thought it’s boring, repetitive and focuses too much on that strategy part instead of action. Oh boy was I proved wrong. It was so easy to get into that game but you had so many features to find your style of playing. I don’t even know what I should tell you first about. You can create your own little party by choosing which companions will accompany you throughout the game. You’ll meet most of them during the game and you can interact with them to the fullest. And I mean to the fullest. (You can date almost all of them.) In conversations you can choose which answer is the most suitable. But be careful: You can even loose the chance to recruit a companion if you chose to just not let him / her come with you, kill him / her or you just forgot to complete that one quest. If you ever wanted to try out a Game like this, do it. It’s the best by far. Difficulty: 4 up to 9 As I said before: It introduces you quite well and I as a beginner never felt overwhelmed. There are many difficulty levels to choose and the hardest one is just pure pain. And that’s the way it should be. For my first playthrough I chose “Easy” and there were still some hard fights that require you to pause (By pressing spacebar) and think through your strategy. It’s for everyone.  I really recommend reading some class guides (There are a lot on youtube if you’re too lazy to read like me)!!  Only the DLC gives you the option to reskill. Or you have to download the mod. Notable: - I won’t say that there aren’t some bugs. You can’t expect a game this big without some minor bugs. But there wasn’t a single game braking one.- Good for newcomers to the genre- Runs smoothly - Complete Edition costs less than 10 bucks on Sale.- I completed it in around 70 hours. (And another 20 spent on the DLCs). You WILL spent a lot of time in this-  One of THE best games I’ve ever played so far  Conclusion: I BEG you to at least try it out. I didn’t like those games too, but DA:O changed my mind and became my favorite game. You won’t regret it! Thanks for reading, if there are any questions leave a comment below. Feel free to add me if you want to chat about the game, my other reviews or just for fun. Have a great Day!

Posted: March 10, 2014
												Excellent game with high replayability. One of my all time favorites. Still, I'll be honest and list the flaws. First, the level editor is nowhere near as intuitive as Neverwinter Nights, but given that these days a prepackaged editor is rare enough as is, I suppose I shouldn't complain. Awakenings is buggy as hell and Witch Hunt is far too short, although I rather liked Ariane and Finn as companions. The "hard choice" at the end of Origins feels contrived to me, although I can't really get into why without spoilers. For what it's worth, I highly recommend the Dragon Age Redesigned and Improved Atmosphere mods. Also, there is a mod avaliable to skip the Fade. You'll probably want to install that after the first playthrough. Still an excellent game, and you should buy it before Dragon Age Inquisition comes out. From what I've heard, you'll also probably want to skip DA2.

 “Join us, brothers and sisters. Join us in the shadows, where we stand vigilant!”Dragon Age: Origins is an excellent role-playing game with a truly epic campaign and great tactical gameplay. It offers a rich and vivid world, loads of mature themes and memorable characters. The storytelling and dialogues are witty and engaging, the music is inspiring and you will be deeply involved in the compelling gameplay. The different decisions and conversation options in combination with your individual character background allow you to proceed through the game in several ways resulting in a high replayability. Amusing quotes:  “We now have a dog and Alistair is still the dumbest one in the party.”  “Let's show them our hearts, and then show them theirs.” Trivia:Dragon Age: Origins is often considered the spiritual successor to the Baldur's Gate series of games, which took place in the Forgotten Realms Campaign Setting of the Dungeons & Dragons franchise.Achievements:The game has no Steam achievements. Chronology: Dragon Age: Inquisition (PC)Role-playing game(Dark Fantasy) – 2014Dragon Age 2 (PC)Role-playing game(Dark Fantasy) – 2011Dragon Age: Origins (PC)Role-playing game(Dark Fantasy) – 2009

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												After owning this and playing the hell out of it on the PS3 I decided it was finally time to see how well the PC version was made and get a couple DLCs I hadn't played. Right off the bat I noticed a massive difference from my console version in the load times. The PC version is a blink of an eye compared to my PS3 sounding like it was ready to take flight playing this with load times becoming increasingly annoying as you play through it. The graphics and performance overall are far superior as well and the mouse/keyboard controls are nice. It does take a little bit of getting used to rotating the look with either the keyboard, or the mouse (you have to hold down the right button to look around), but you get used to it fast enough. Not to mention the ability to quicksave and not wait 5 seconds like on consoles.As for the game itself, this is one of my all-time favorite RPGs. Mostly because I love the adult and mature content that it provides with the characters. No I'm not talkinng about sex, although you can hook up with other characters in your party and even have some grand old same sex encounters. The dialogue and writing in this game feels very realistic and not childish like most RPGs you will play. A lot of good dark humor as well as some smart interactions with the characters. This is what I love most about this series and what I loave about Bioware games in general like Mass Effect.It is fun to mix and match your party as you walk around exploring as they all talk to each other while you walk and have different things to say based on who is in the group. I would highly recommend this game to ALL RPG fans and would suggest buying the Ultimate Edition so that you can get all the DLC on Steam without the hassle of having to go through the Bioware website and getting shafted. The DLC is worth the few extra bucks for a completely new character (got this as a pre-order on PS3 I believe) that adds a lot of humor and their own character quests to the game. The story is farily well done and has a lot of character quests like most Bioware games that addsdepth to your party. The DLCs expand on some of them and add even more story. Plus you get new items, skills, and characters that can be used in the main campaign. The PC version also offers a decent modding community which can add a lot to the game, or take away some of the tedious things you dislike. This game for me is an easy 9.5/10.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below) Game Name: Dragon Age: Origins Original Release: 2010 Genre Tags: RPG; Strategy; Fantasy; Story-Rich; Epic My Overall Grade: A+ Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 60-150 hours Multiplayer Aspect: None Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs; Epic RPG enthusiasts REVIEWDragon Age: Origins is an immersive action/strategy RPG with a deep, intricate story and the potential for hundreds of gameplay hours.  If you like plunging yourself into truly epic RPGs which can keep you glued to your computer for days on end, this is one of the best games to play. Right from the start, the massiveness of the game assaults you. Making your standard start-of-an-RPG choices of character race and class will determine which of six origin stories you will play through to open the game.  Each of these stories can take several hours to beat.  And if you are like me, you will need to play them all before deciding which character you will anoint the chosen one which you will play as for the entirety of the campaign.  Who you choose will also affect certain conversations and quests in the main part of the game.Continuing with the theme of massiveness, the narrative and lore elements are truly epic and expansive. The main narrative is well written with great pacing, telling an interesting tale rooted in classic fantasy themes. The characters are diverse and interesting, and each one is given an actual presence in the world. And if you enjoy immersing yourself in the nuances of fantasy gameworlds, you will be pleased to know there is a plethora of lore and backstory. There is so much to learn about.As for the gameworld: it is atmospheric and mystical. There is no gigantic overworld to freely traverse, however. But the locations that do exist are very well designed and are expressive of the setting. And the graphics succeed in painting the picture that is intended, even if they may fall behind the curve as this game begins to age.The gameplay mechanics and the battle system are intricate and elaborate. On the higher difficulties, deep knowledge of interactive effects is necessary for tough battles. Luckily on the lower difficulties, you can get away with only a rudimentary understanding. But as you unlock new abilities and new characters who offer new playable classes, experimenting with different party combinations can help spice up the combat. For any game that lasts over 100 hours, that can be a welcome feature.One of the headlining concepts at the heart of Dragon Age: Origins is the decision system. I alluded to this earlier when I mentioned the diverse origin stories. There are a multitude of decisions to be made throughout the game, most of which have some sort of impact on the gameworld— be it large or small. And to make it better, most of the decisions have no clear “right or wrong,” so you’ll really have to make choices (and not just choose what you know the game wants you to).It is beginning to age, but true quality cannot easily be eroded by the sands of time. If you are a fan of truly epic RPGs, this one is a must-play for you. My only warning is that it is quite verbose and grand in scale, so if you are someone who easily loses interest then you may struggle with the sheer magnitude of the game.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												Dragon Age origins was No 1 and the best .... an absolutely brilliant game! Six character backgrounds to choose to start with and all could be played through for the whole game. Several vastly different endings depending on choices made through the game. Fantastic and witty dialogue with all your companions that you were able to take with you on your adventure. Interactions between the companions that you had with you at random event places. Love scenes with characters that you had started to have a relationship with .... which needed to be be done slowly and well over a long time being aware of three way jealousies and confrontations with other companions.... Brilliantly worked out! Massive Boss battles ... an AI system where you could set up how your companions would automatically react when certain conditions are met. Tough battles that you needed to be strategic about to survive... with a combination of four possible followers fighting with you and needing all the skills of magic, rogue and fighter to make it past all areas.DA Origins had an expansion called Awakening to which you could take a save file from Origins to take you into it ... and you needed to as the enemies in Awakening were at that level and a new game started at awakening started with the same gear you would have had in Origins. So anyone wanting to battle level 30 enemies with a rusty dagger and a robe.... good luck. The Awakening was a good addition a couple of your companions made the trip and could join you if you did all the right things. Certainly it is a smaller game than origins and a different one. But a worthy addition using the same game structure and similar dialogue ... although not as good as origins.The Dragon Age 2 game actually doesn't really have anything to do with the first. Some of the lore is the same ... and from some of the decisions you made in DA O will be represented in some vague background stories. The dialogue was tweaked further but is became convoluted  ... but none of the characters really felt like someone I could relate to. DA 2 had three chapters I completed the first and after 5 -6 tries eventually defeated the massive boss battle in the deep roads against the ARW (Ancient Rock Wraith) This battle was immense! For that the resulting Treasure was a major Disappointment!!!! I had played as a mage up to that point and the robe in the treasure wasn't much different than anything previously. The only character who had decent armor was the dwarf (narrator of the game when cut scenes happened)  who's Armor leveled as he did ... so you would think this dwarf was the protagonist. Then you supposedly won a massive income from your trip into the deep roads such that you bought a house for your self and your companions ... (that I didn't care about) but had no money left, to even buy potions. The only part of DA 2  that I did like was the combat! How they had you fight numerous enemies and the way spells and melee attacks worked was great. But hopeless story and characters that I couldn't care about .... and nothing to do with DA Origins at all very disappointing.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												I heard about this game a lot, having seen it on several "Top RPG's of All Time" lists and knowing it to be a personal favourite of many people. Suffice it to say, I was pretty excited to give it a run. I went from being  sorely dissapointed  to  becoming a big fan , so I thought it would be helpful to share my experience.  Note: I haven't finished the game or all of the DLC's yet, so this is a tentative review.  Early impressions Graphics sucked (even with beautification mods), combat was okay but certainly not "tactical", what the hell is this?I kept coming back to the game because, a) I heard so much about it, and b)  every quest has a really well developed narrative to it . Even in what would typically be fetch quests I was invested in participating because I knew the back-story (i.e. You meet a kid who's mother died, and find a quest on the notice board to locate her remains and bring back her amulet, presumably for the kid). It could have been "kill three sewer rats and report to the tavern", but it wasn't and that was amazing.Also, right off the start, you're thrown into a pretty epic story. Mid-game impressions After 20 hours in-game, your combat abilities are more fleshed out. Combat begins to feel  a lot  more tactical, because you have several variations in taking on enemies, and you need to use several abilities to win against increasingly difficult foes.Several quests really stand out relative to other RPG's, for instance when I -  begin spoiler -sacrificed an heir-to-the-throne kid's mother so that I could travel to a soul-realm, to battle a demon that was possessing him - making the kid murder people and summon monsters to kill townsfolk - using an outlawed form of magic through a guy I just busted out of a dungeon (because he MAY or MAY NOT have attempted to kill the kids dad/lord), - end spoiler - I was like, damn that was amazing.Little things in this world really come to the fore when you invest the time into it. Certain weapons have entire histories associated with them; codex entries come together to paint a really worth-while narrative picture. Also, you meet a pretty sizable list of interesting characters along your journey. Late-game impressions Not there yet, but I'm sure I will be. TL;DR This is an excellent RPG. Pros+ Awesome writing, even for simple quests+ Interesting history to discover+ Epic story+ Interesting characters throughout+ Decent mod support (but they do not help the dated graphics issue that much)Cons- Graphics are poor, but are sometimes really well done (inconsistent graphic quality?)- Takes a long time before combat is tactically engaging

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												This game right here is a prime example of what Bioware does right. The story is rich and even is presented to you differently throughout the game depending on your "Origin Story" and choices you've made in the game. The character's all have interesting back-stories and will behave in meaningful ways, depending on your relationship with the character. Even the most boring character for me, Sten, was still interesting enough that talking to him about his past and race's history didn't feel like a chore. Combat is simple enough, and while it doesn't have the same level of involvement or 'Flare' as some other games, it's strategic and satisfying. Graphics are pretty good, and with mods and a decent computer, you can really improve the atmosphere of the game.The amount of content is impressive, even by RPG standards. I got roughly 60-some hours on one play-through, and I didn't even bother to complete all the quests. While on that topic, side-quests in this game are well-done as well. Each side-quest usually has some kind of back story, and more often than not, rewards you with some kind of armor or weapon that you couldn't find in the vendor stores. One of my favorite side-quests (and I'll try not to spoil it) is when you battle several different Revents, or Corrupted Warrior Spirits, toretrieve this bass♥♥♥♥♥armor set called the Juggernuat. The rewards and backstory of the quests made it feel like it somehow tied into the actual story, making it much less painful for those 100% completionists.Dragon Age Origins is one of Bioware's best works (my personal favorite), and makes me wish Mass Effect took more from Dragon Age in terms of storytelling and interesting quests. If you're a Bioware fan, RPG fan, or even just looking for a good game to get immersed in, look no further... Dragon Age is worth wasting hours of your life away.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												Dragon Age: Origins is old-school. Before achievements and trophies, a role-player's greatest achievement was working the system to build the most broken, overpowered character possible within the constraints of whatever edition of Dungeons & Dragons the game was based on. Origins is a solitary experience; you'll isolate yourself from the outside world, staying up nights and well into the morning because when this game grabs you, it simply won't let go.This is a game that's been in development for what seems like forever, and it shows. BioWare's own Mass Effect was far more visually impressive, particularly in the dialogue sequences, where Dragon Age's facial animations and character models can seem stiff and wooden. Then there's the odd decision to go so over-the-top with the blood. Blood plays an important role in the world's unique fiction, but watching your characters relay meaningful lines of speech while splashed with more blood than the prom scene in "Carrie" borders on the ridiculous, robbing such scenes of any potential sense of gravitas.That isn't to say that this is an ugly game, by any means. Dragon Age: Origins' landscapes and dungeon interiors are rife with detail and a joy to explore. Combat animations in particular are impressive, as your characters will set themselves before enemies and go through complex motions, with rogues jockeying for position to backstab and warriors forcefully slamming their shields into faces. Colorful kill animations result in dismemberments and decapitations, rewarding you for critical strikes in a far more memorable manner than just a bigger damage number. Then there's the sheer scale of this undertaking. You can easily log a hundred hours exploring every inch of this world, with plenty of incentive to come back again to approach the tale of the Grey Warden from a new perspective and origin story.Your character's origin story, the first steps in your adventure, plays a significant role in how this tale plays out. The tropes of fantasy fiction lie intact, with Dwarves dwelling underground and elves living in the world's forests on the outskirts of human civilization, but these societies are still fleshed-out and made unique. Dwarves have a complex caste system, with the nobility focusing on political advancement while the casteless underclass live in ghettos, struggling to eke out a living as part of the criminal underbelly. Elves who live in human cities reside in closed-off alienages, destined for a life of servitude to the human nobility. Magi live secluded lives of research and study in their towers under the constant watch of the order of Templars, a religious sect tasked with ensuring that magic does not lead to demonic infestation.While your own story is important, the companions that join you play an equally important role. The Grey Warden Alistair, the witch of the wilds Morrigan, and the mysterious minstrel Leliana are your primary romantic options and the game's main supporting characters, though other characters like Sten, the taciturn warrior, are nearly as interesting. Even the dog companion is a full-fledged ally worthy of bringing along, complete with his own inventory and unique abilities. The quality of the voice work ensures that you'll rarely skip through the frequent conversations and inter-party banter. You'll spend lots of time wading through interminably long conversations while getting to know the members of your party, in an effort to improve their approval ratings. Fans of Dungeons & Dragons-styled role-playing adventures may be annoyed that there are only three core character classes and three race options, but there's remarkable depth to the character development system. Each class has a variety of talent options, and four specializations to choose from: Warriors can go weapon and shield or two-handed, Rogues can become archers or dual-wield, and Mages can master a wide variety of spell options. Dragon Age: Origins also provides countless opportunities for challenging, riveting combat sequences where strategy and tactics win out. Again, it's the decisions that make Dragon Age: Origins such a thought-provoking experience. I've played through the game twice now and I still have trouble choosing which companions to take with me on any given adventure. The story has a way of dropping situations in your lap where any of a handful of different options seem viable, with no clear-cut option standing out as the right one. This is due in part to Dragon Age: Origins' lack of a clearly defined moral alignment structure. Characters are generally complex, defying the unrealistically simplistic labels of "good" and "evil," and the game is the better for it.There is so much more to Dragon Age: Origins I just don't have room to explain here. Simply know that there are tons of weapons and loot to find, craft, and coat with poison, thousands of quests to take on, storekeepers to intimidate, and NPCs to persuade. If you're a Western-style, fantasy RPG nut, or if you love a great tactical challenge, you simply can't go wrong with Dragon Age: Origins. BioWare has outdone itself once again.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												From the brains of the guys and gals behind Baldur's Gate, Jade Empire, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic and Mass Effect emerges this game - Dragon Age: Origins. BioWare certainly knows how to pull off a good RPG, they are clearly not afraid to implement whatever they please to make it a superb experience. Dragon Age: Origins is no different. The game is set in the fantasy world known as Ferelden. A land that for long has been safe from war and suffering and looks like your typical fantasy land with elves, dwarves, wizards, maidens and of course - Dragons.The peace is not to last though, peace is a pretty bad setting to make a game in to be honest. A dark force gathers in the outskirts of the Kingdom and soon the faith of humanity (or what species have you) solely rests on your shoulders. In other words - like every single damn fantasy RPG out there. But hold your unicorns, that does not mean the game is bad does it? No! Making a game in the stereotypical RPG/Fantasy is never a bad thing. As long as it's up to standard with implemented unique features that successfully intertwine with a very good story.BioWare themselves described the game as the spritual successor to Baldur's Gate, at least in the sense of the atmosphere and game setting. I have not played Baldur's Gate, so I can not answer to this. I can however say that the game reminds A lot of Mass Effect and Star Wars: KoTOR, combine that with the general fantasy setting (like Skyrim), some intriguing story and this game is set to blow your brains out. My experience with this game has sadly been... shattered, though. I have throughout the years seriously tried to set my mind on RPG-mode, and just sink myself into this adventure. But I have only finished the game once, and have probably played the start 10 times. I am attracted by the setting and gameplay, but I always seem to end up forcing myself through the game, because I feel that the game MUST be good. Unlike with Mass Effect or any of the Elder Scrolls games for example, I pretty much ended up disliking the game because of my issue. I had the same problem with Bioshock, but this is just me, so it does not make the game any less good. You just have to crave for some RPG goodness, and not rush through it.Just like most BioWare games, you are but one character in a squad/company, and most of the gameplay are dependent on this as a strategic mechanic. It is possible to just ignore the other characters in your company, but this would require your main character to completely carry every fight, which is not optimal. Again, as with all Fantasy RPGs, you get to pick a class; Warrior, Mage or Rogue and build your character from scratch. In Dragon Age you also get to pick race and background, giving even more options as well as unlocking different storylines. This is to make every playthrough a unique experience compared to the previous. Overall BioWare are known as masters at extensive and complex dialogues for their games, often to make you choose a dark or bright path and reflect your options into the upcoming events.What I however Did enjoy about the game was the enormous background history to build the series on, the grim setting, the interactions between the main character and NPC characters, some adult scenery and romance interactions, the depiction of cracks in a fictional society that may or may not be referring to real life scenarios. As the majority of this game attract me I feel that it deserves a positive rating, even though I will probably not play it again due to lack of patience and time.If you love BioWare's games, Fantasy RPG's and are ready to sacrifice dozens of hours for a grand adventure, then this game is likely to entertain.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2016
Sten (a game companion) steals cookies from children "for their own good"Hailed by many as the best Dragon Age title ever made, this bad boy is the spiritual successor of none other than Baldur's Gate, therefore fans of the aforementioned series will enjoy this game a little bit more than usual.DA's plot is extremely rich with details that unfold slowly after hours and hours of exploration and gameplay. Wishing to keep this review spoiler-free, I will not reveal too much about it, except the general concept which you can still avoid it, if you want. The general backstory is about a race of tainted creatures, the Darkspawn, that occasionally awaken one of the dragon gods and corrupt him to their benefit. Then they proceed to invade the land, Ferelden, in an event known as the Blight. You have to stop them. The country of Ferelden has huge amounts of backstory elements about religion, wars, kings, races and more. You will not be bored finding out every bit and piece of information you come across. Despite its vastness however, plot tends to become repetitive at times. Even though every region and city has unique events and quests for you to fulfill, they tend to circle around the same principles: murder, assassination, betrayal. The results of your actions may indeed vary and have different consequences in the world, not every city should need a hero to rally everyone behind him and settle their differences like cities full of children.Your character's race and class will also allow you to choose one of the several starting stories you have. You can start as a noble, a common citizen, a member of the mage's circle or a member of a nomadic tribe. This creates a link between the player and your character, giving you a motive to drive the story forward. You might return to the lands you hailed from and everyone will remember you, or, depending on your standings, people you meet will react to you differently, either by addressing you "my lord" or with total racism. Your party members can be recruited from around the world (Le Daft Punk reference) and they can be kicked out anytime you want. They will also present you with side quests that involve them, like finding Sten's lost sword or helping the difficult relationship between Morrigan and her mother. Their skills can be customised and you can even select a second class for them if you want. Choosing the right members and getting to know them is key, since they have different personalities, backstories and opinions. That means your actions, like destroying a demon or making a pact with him, has corresponding results to the way your companions view you. If you do many things they consider them preposterous, they might even turn on you and try to murder you. This gameplay element is simply exquisite and so well made, I don't recall encountering anything similar, ever.Combat has several approaches you can take: you can fight in real time, by pausing and issuing orders or assign tactics that will determine the battle style of your companions. A combination of those means your party will be able to crush with ease the small groups of enemies you will encounter, forcing RPG veterans to buff the difficulty to Hard or Nightmare level. Micromanagement is key during battles, which adds to the tactical feel of the game. It tends to become repetitive quickly, however, especially since there's a limited number of tactics slots. Not only that, but sometimes, your companions tend to ignore their tactics or the commands you give them, resorting instead to use basic attacks instead of abilities and skills. Plus, their somewhat slow-minded AI makes them step on traps they could clearly see and disarm or avoid. Sooner or later, you will want direct control of everyone, after realising your mates can't do anything properly on their own.In the end, you can't help but enjoy this game, regardless of its flaws. You will have a good laugh as your companions jest and annoy each other, revealing this game's deep and complex character development and relationships, all set in a fractured world where civil war and mass extinction are threatening everyone.And remember to keep Sten away from cookies, and Morrigan with Alistair apart. Or not. Your choice.RATING:Gameplay: 8/10Presentation: 9/10Story: 9/10Unique Factor: Character Development: 9.5/10OVERALL: 8.8/10

number of helpful: 42 of 49 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 12, 2015
												WARNING VERY LONGI suppose I should write a review, since Inquisition's story has finally ended, now begins my watch, for the next Dragon Age game.INTRODUCTIONDragon Age Origins was first released by in 2009 and was met with great acclaim, for its fantastic world design, setting, story, basically it was one the best RPG games of the decade, i say "one of" and not "the" mind you. Being released between both fallout 3 and new vegas, Dragon age had some considerable competition. Luckily it hold its own and more, with great storytelling, characters and some great gameplay.It definitely was not the prettiest game at the time, I mean the character looks can be anywhere from pretty and handsome in rare cases almost exclusive to companions, to plain old ugly appearances. There isn't much variety in customization, armours are simple recolours for the most part, weapons and bows too. Honestly the looks are definitely one of the worst parts of the game, just too little uniqueness in armour and weapons to make you and you party stand out from any other ordinary grunt, unless of course you enjoy that sort of thing.STORYI’ll try not to spoil too much, as many choices affect not situations and the ending in this game but also in the sequels too.You will have an origin story, by choosing your race and birthplace, either being, human, elf or dwarf, and being birthed in the slums, nobility or mage. Oh and the singled out dalish elf. Each of these will affect some dialogue options and give racial traits, it can also make some things easier or harder depending on the quest at hand. With these picked you will take part in a battle as a soldier in the Grey Wardens, an ancient order of protectors whose sole purpose is to defend life against the darkspawn and blights.After the being defeated at the battle you find out you're one of the last surviving members of the order, and is up to you to gather allies for a new army for one last battle, or the spawn will overtake all of thedas. Thus begins the main quest, along the way you will help out random strangers, groups of mages and mercs, decide the fate of magical order and dalish clan, find a lost piece of ancient dwarven history and find the remains of the bride to the Maker, the creator of life in the known world.So this is a huge story with many quests and side jobs, they can be incredibly drawn out each main segments easily takes out a hour or more depending on difficulty. But you use this time to stockpile potions and arrows, find the best weapons and armour for each of your 9 companions, all find additional support for your army. All of it eventually paying off in the epic finale at the end of the game were it all comes into play. This is one of the main reasons why this game is so great still stands today, as a great piece of storytelling.GAMEPLAYThe game play likes a old fashioned RPG, where you will control a party of characters assign specialties and classed, equip them as well. So it mostly strategy based combat, assigning orders, positioning, setting priorities and tactics and more. Alongside this combat is alose magic and consumables which also affect your allies if they are caught in in it area of effect making for carefully planned attacks. Through your character's skills, you can buff and debuff units, effectively controlling the battlefield. It is very difficulty explaining it completely, but such examples can very easily be found online, or if you have played it's much like Baldur's Gate.DIFFICULTYThis is another main great point of the game, it is naturally hard, even on the easiest difficulty. The game will often throw a number of enemies at you either being a small horde of easily dispatchable grunts, to a mini boss or two, as well as mix of troops. Magic is also your worst enemy as if left unchecked a mage will destroy your team single handley.As for the difficulty settings, it changes it artificially, increasing unit health, damage and defence, as well affecting certain other stats.  But despite all of this, even on easy there is plenty of leeway in how you can build your characters, but as you go up you will have to plan your builds accordingly or suffer a painful, live die and repeat scenarios.COMPANIONSI feel like I should bring these in as if you get into the game, you become invested in their story, to the point like many other people, you consider them Friends/Family for you Warden. Here's two examples of my favourite ones. Leliana, she's an assassin  Bard turned religious sister. She's confident but sweet, very calm and has an interesting backstory and quest to boot as well has her own origin DLC story, where you can gain a an amazing set of armour for you or her.My second is a dwarf warrior exilce called ohgren, hes allways drunk and allways randy, constantly trying to get it on with your female compainons or you, and trys and excuse to talk about the dirty stuff.There 8 of them in total, 3 Warriors, 2 rogues and 2 mages and a dog, there is also a unique dlc companion who is a stone golem, and is very interesting one at that. Also depending on your game choices you can get another warrior to join your party at the expense of another.  These characters are lovable and hateable in their own ways, each can be customized and leveled individually, each have their own speciality for combat. Through combat they can sustain injuries and if not treated or treated, will lead to their eventual death. Doing they don't like too much, or do something that goes completely against them, will make either leave or attack you.They all have extensive dialogue and backstory each will have their own personal quests that will give them bonuses or special weapons and/or armour. If you take an interest in them and start improving their approval of you, they will get bonus their base skills like constitution furthering a specialty.CONCLUSION Okay the graphics aren't great, the environments are vast and empty ,customization is limited, overall game is difficult and has many unpatched bug that can break quests. But this is a tiny proportion to what you’re getting, a huge world of fantasy, filled with a few hours worth history reading, rememberable characters, epic story and potentially almost a hundred hours worth of fun. There are many little thing I haven't mentioned yet, like how there is a modding community, DLC’s offer post game content, that will give rewards for your next playthrough, how actions caused here will affect many details of the next game, and the actions of the sequel will affect the sequel-sequel.This is definitely worth a look at the very least, or even just a read of the timeline or sotries embedded within the game.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2013
												Dragon Age: Origins is a fantasy R.P.G. developed by Bioware and published by Electronic Arts. You are a Grey Warden, one of the last of this legendary order of guardians. With the return of mankind's ancient foe and the kingdom engulfed in civil war, you have been chosen by fate to unite the shattered lands and slay the archdemon once and for all. Explore a stunning world, make complex moral choices and engage in bone-crushing combat against massive and terrifying creatures. This title is yet another masterpiece from the fine people at Bioware. If you love roleplaying, fantasy or story-driven plot thick games then you will simply adore this title. From the beginning of Dragon Age: Origins to the very end, the adventure that your Grey Warden embarks upon will keep you enthralled as you follow the path of destiny in this wonderfully crafted land of R.P.G. goodness. The story, characters and lore all come together here in perfect increments to create a truly fantastic gaming experience that no fan of this genre should pass up.Besides the epic story, Origins gameplay/combat is the next big feather in this titles award winning hat. You have the option to engage in combat in either a third person view or the more popular and fun overhead tactical view which, in my opinion, is the best way to truly enjoy the game. One can choose to set parameters for battling and let the A.I. handle combat as you watch from the sidelines or you can opt to have complete control over the action and dictate every move that your party makes as well as what weapon, spell or potion that they use. The game implements a combat pause system that allows you to immediately stop the action and examine the battlefield to determine what commands to issue to your party members. Dragon Age: Origins definitely has some of the best tactical combat that you can find and it is just such a joy to play. I can still remember having my warrior unleash "Warcry" at the beginning of a battle quickly sending out a wave of force and knocking every enemy around me onto their collective bottoms pardon my french....ah good times. The best roleplaying games always give you many ways to customize your characters and Origins does a fantastic job of handling this requisite as well. Besides having the option to choose your race, gender and other physical features, there are also a variety of character classes to pick from and each of those can branch off into different subclasses or specializations futher improving the character customization. Also as in any typical R.P.G., as one gains experience points and level up you will be able to spend them on a number of abilities to enhance your parties combat prowess as well as their interactions with N.P.C.'s during dialogue as the story progresses.Graphically, I really like the look of Dragon Age: Origins. In my opinion, it does an absolutely wonderful job of truly capturing the "Sword and Sorcery" theme. Elves, dragons, magic, a love story, epic battles...this title manages to hit every bulletpoint that a great fantasy game requires. As the story unfolds, your party will trudge through murky swamps, dense forests, immense dungeons, towering cityscapes and beyond during your questing. The many locations that you visit are also quite diversified and have a unique look of their own from the dwarven thaig of Orzammar to the majestic towers of Denerim. The character models used in the cutscenes, be they human or non-human still look great to this day although some of the animations can seem a bit stiff at times. The sound quality is also exceptional and the game features a very memorable soundtrack as well.This title and it's expansion packs are well worth the money spent as it definitely is not a game that you are going to pick up and finish in just 10 hours...be prepared to spend many days or weeks in Ferelden depending on your particular style of play. The excellent main storyline will keep you intrigued from start to finish as you also find time to take on a number of nicely written sidequests and other various objectives. There is also an abundance of lore in Dragon Age: Origins in the form of books, scrolls and stories that you will hear from N.P.C.'s so if you're the type of gamer who enjoys this then be ready to spend plenty of time just reading as you game. Also, once you've finally finished the title for the first time I recommend that you start your second playthrough with some excellent modifications from the Nexus. Once again the wonderful modding community continues to prolong the replayability of yet another classic title...hooray! To summarize, I can honestly say without hesitation that Dragon Age: Origins is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED for roleplaying gamers and players who just love a strong narrative in their titles. Your R.P.G. library is vastly incomplete without this spectacular addition from Bioware.

number of helpful: 36 of 42 people (86%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												It's a good RPG with a very rich story and some interesting locations, but there's also a good amount of things that aren't that great.The presentation is flawless. The locations have a nice amount of detail and all feel unique. The music is great and the voice acting ranges from solid to excellent.The story will drag you in and give you many choices. There is a lot of flavour text to read and you can easily spend a couple of hours just wading through optional dialogue. There are also weaker quests and predictable subplots, but overall the story is good.Now to the not so good things: The combat system isn't bad, but you'll struggle with it quite often due to it being kind of delayed. Which in harder fights were every second counts can be very annoying. The game isn't overly hard, but there are fights that will really drain your patience because they aren't exactly well balanced.Next problem is the design of especially the later dungeons in the game. They are just stretched out way too much and filled with pointless time and resource consuming fights. In combination with the subpar combat system it's tedious to push through them.Lastly I have to say that the setting couldn't be more generic. There's nothing in this game that you haven't seen before (maybe except for some demons), but overall it feels like the team had a lot of ideas about the story, but none about the background. This is just a minor complaint though.I recommend the game, but mainly if you enjoy the story in a game more than actual gameplay.Edit: I just finished the expansion (The Awakening) and found it important to add a few lines about it as well. One complain about the main game was that it wasn't original enough in terms of setting and I have to say that this expansion really does a good job at correcting that mistake. It's nowhere as obvious what's going on as in the main game and there are unique non-human villains this time. Also due to the shorter nature of the expansion the dungeons don't drag as much as in the main game. I really enjoyed the expansion and would even go as far as saying that it's slightly better than the main game. This is more about the overall gameplay and not about the story. If you want to play the game you should really get the ultimate edition to get the full experience.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Dragon Age: Origins is the best game I've ever played in terms of role-playing. The Origin story system allows you to create characters that feel unique every time, and make every playthrough completely different. The interactions between your character and your companions are incredibly complex and engaging, and allow you to really develop your character's personality. The storyline is very long yet entertaining, and gives you many options as to how to proceed through and eventually complete the game. Often times, there is no right decision, and your actions will have far reaching consequences, and will also affect your companions' opinion of you.As for the gameplay, it is different to many RPGs in that it is very strategy based, and when playing on Normal or harder, you will have to actively manage all four members of your party in order to succeed. The combat can be very punishing and is perhaps too difficult, especially early in the game. Warriors, the front line of your party, will die very quickly without high stats and equipment. However, if you use your party's abilities well, and make good decisions as to which abilities you unlock, you should be alright. The game is open world, though to travel between areas, you must watch your progress on a map. The textures of the NPCs are good enough that they don't affect immersion, yet many of the textures of the environment are rather low-res. However, the game is pretty old now so that is only to be expected. I did not find that it took away from my role-playing experience. The voice-acting is superb, and while like most games you get used to the same voice actors, each NPC does seem slightly different.Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone, and putting in the hours to beat the storyline is extremely rewarding. The various expansions provide a significant late game, or you could just make a totally new character! Even after two playthroughs, the game says I have only completed 54% of the content. Buy this game!

content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												I originally owned this on a console, so really my time with this game is close to 1000 hours I would think. After all that time, I have 3 conclusions:1. Mages are OP, whether as NPCs, teammates, or your own character (probably most so as your own character)...but isn't that what magic is supposed to be?2. Swooping is bad.3. This is one of the best RPGs of all time. The writing, characters, gameplay, pacing, customization...everything, is just top notch. This is BioWare at its finest. Plus, after all this time and so many playthroughs, I still get surprised by funny banter between party members I had previously never really paired up before, such as this gem from my last playthru:     Shale: So here is a question for the painted elf...    Zevran: Painted elf? Oh, that's me! I do like that.    Shale: Am I to understand correctly that the painted elf is a "crow"?    Zevran: Not literally, but... yes. I am a Crow.    Shale: As in a bird.    Zevran: Is there another sort?    Shale: So the painted elf assaults helpless statuary with its feces?    Zevran: If given sufficient cause, why not?    Shale: That is outrageous! The painted elf will stay away from me. Or else.    Zevran: (Sighs) I get a lot of that. +Epic story with rich lore.+Awesome characters all around.+Multiple origins and endings keep things interesting with a new playthrough.+So much replayability+Requires actual strategy to your team building to not get massacred at key points.+Unlike so many other RPGs today, you actually do start to feel stronger and more heroic as the game progresses, but it still stays challenging. +Awakening expansion is nearly as good as the main game-General BioWare RPG gripe: it's always pretty lame how you so easily get wrapped up into awkward, immersion breaking conversations because of how the romance system works. Namely, unless you're mean to--or outright ignore--a romanceable party member, they're going to fall in love with you.-Minor gripe: wish there was a sell junk button in the PC version (but I'm sure there is a mod for that).-No griffons.Even if the combat style is not quite your thing, you would be remiss to skip such an expertly-crafted game.

number of helpful: 19 of 19 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 2, 2016
												This is without a doubt one of the best RPGs ever made. in a sense it's the perfect RPG. tons of choices, deep character creation, different playstyles, an amazing plot, great characters, and more. i have put about 300 or more hours into this game, since I got it on console way before PC and poured tons of hours into my console version. This game has a unique and great plot that will immerse you in a fantasy world unlike any other, with a combat system that is tactical and fun, and characters that you will become emotionally attached to. it has a great soundtrack, the main menu song is incredible and there are some scenes where characters will sing to you and the voices are beautiful. the graphics aren't anything special but there are mods that can make the graphics better. However this game is not about graphics, even with all the cool new games coming out with their high definition graphics i still come back and play this game, and still believe it to be one of the best. it has plenty of exploration and side quests, lots of loot, and nice armors and weapons. the classes are all varied and offer unique combat styles and are all very fun. this is just my personal opinion but this is the best out of the 3 Dragon Age games, none of the others quite capture the true nature of an RPG like this one does. The main story is great as well, with multiple endings and romance options that are all very fulfilling. Overall this game is very well rounded and there aren't many ways it could be improved. there are very few bugs and the game runs great. all in all if you want an amazing RPG to pour hundreds of hours into then this is definitely the game for you, i cannot reccomend this game more highly. I have hundreds of hours of playtime and i still discover somthing new every time i play it which is incredible. The DLC are all pretty good as well, some are better than others but none of them are bad. Bioware has a long history of amazing RPGs and this is one of them. SUMMARY:Story: 10/10Characters: 9/10Combat: 9/10Music: 9/10High ReplayabilityThis is a game you definitely do not want to miss out on, and is well worth your time and money.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												It’s not easy always being at the cutting edge, and that’s why I’ve decided to review this Dragon Age game, and not the new one which people are currently interested in.DA:O is a few years old now, but it has taken a few attempts for me to actually stick with it, and it with me. Hence, tardy review. But, let me be clear, right off the bat. It’s as good as everybody said it was, all those years ago! Sure, it has a somewhat off-putting generic fantasy shell, and the designers needn’t have limited themselves to just four colours (brown, grey, green, and reddish-brown) when they were painting this grand adventure. You might say it’s more realistic but sod realism, this is a fantasy game, and it’s all a bit too “trad”, at least at first blush.However, I can only speak personally. There are many people who adore trad fantasy and all its trappings, and who don’t like change. More power to them, but for me, at first glance, there doesn’t seem to a lot of originality here, in setting or theme. I persisted, peeled back those crusty brownish-grey outer layers, and found something truly engrossing. This game has a lot of humour, and a lot of heart.When it was first released, there was a lot of buzz about DA:O being a spiritual successor to the Baldur’s Gate games, which meant there would be swords, dragons, magic, derring-do and loads of fighting. This is all true of DA:O. There was also a lot of hype for the “Origins” system, proudly displayed in the title, which meant that instead of having one single starting sequence (location, npcs, events) you’d have a different one based on your race and class. You might find yourself a poor elf in an alienage, forced to get by on your wits and the point of a knife, or a stalwart dwarven noble in a monumental underground palace, and all the intrigue that entails. Where you come from also affects how you’ll be perceived by party members and other important characters in the game. It was supposed to make you feel more of a connection to your character, and I think it really works and actually helps give the game a decent amount of replayability. From my own experience the balance of the game is probably weighted about 60/40 in favour of combat over conversation, which is okay. It’s not great: there have been times when I’ve been exploring a temple or an underground cavern and become completely fatigued with having to fight the same enemies again and again, with the only difference being that this time it’s archers instead of mages standing at the back. It hasn’t happened often, though, and because the game is relatively free-form, you can always go and do something else. If you’re the type of player that prefers diplomacy over fistcuffery, beware: more often than not, quests end in big fights.Combat takes place in real-time, but you can pause the game to issue commands, and watch them play out when you unpause. There are tons of spells and skills, so you’ll want to make sure to use the right ones at the right times. I’d say that on any difficulty above Easy, you will need to pause quite regularly and be prepared to micro-manage to some degree. The other option is setting up tactics for each party member, which are like little scripts for them to follow. You might set up your tank to immediately engage the strongest enemy, or tell your mage to cast an AoE if enemies are standing near to each other. This takes time to organise, and tactics which work for one fight may not do so well in another, but generally this feature will reduce busywork and it can be satisfying to spectate as your team dismantles the enemy without you lifting a finger.Fights can get quite busy. You will almost always be assaulted by many foes, some up close and some at range, and there will be bursts of fire and magic bolts flying. It can be hard to keep track, so it’s a good thing the devs included a tactical camera. You can flick the mousewheel to pull the camera back into the ceiling, just far enough that you can see who is who and where people are positioned. It’s pretty useful, and entirely missing from the console versions. Pat yourself on the back for owning a PC.I mentioned before that I’ve bounced off this game, and this has been because of difficulty spikes. Depending on in which order you choose to approach the three (or four, I forget) “main” quests in the game, you may find yourself running up against enemies which are too tough for you, or battles which seem to go on forever, where enemy waves continuously spawn. Case in point, Redcliffe, which Alistair, a party member, specifically advises you to tackle first of all. This questline is good fun, but very combat heavy and has a one particular fight where waves of enemies just keep on spawning, so you need to keep party members safe all the way through the fight. From a storytelling point of view it makes sense: Alistair cares for the Arl of Redcliffe, and can’t have known about the danger before telling you to go there. But as a player, it’s a harsh lesson to learn at an early point in the game. As I said, don’t be afraid to go and do something else if you keep getting hammered. Will wrap up with the most positive points. The writing is frequently excellent, particularly with regards to the banter between party members. The lore is deep, and the in-game codex completely overflows with interesting entries to read about the history of the land, the people and the places. It looks good! Faces are a bit “uncanny valley” at times, but mostly well animated and  believable. If you’re in the market for a deep and fairly complex RPG to sink your teeth into, then get Dragon Age: Inquisition. But, if you’re poor like me, get this one.
