content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												So in 2009, Bioware decided to return to its roots of making RPGs in the vein of Baldur's Gate with Dragon Age: Origins. What resulted is a very engaging and thrilling tale of a band of misfits that come together to defeat the evil Darkspawn and their leader, the Archdemon. I wholeheartedly can recommend it.The story of Dragon Age is a pretty good one, with a good mix of political intrigue and dark fantasy themes. There is some really expansive lore in this game available for you to read in the codex, which would take you hours to read. I assure you, however, that reading all of it is worth it.The party members are all unique characters, and well-written. Some would say a few are weaker than others as far as being interesting (looking at you, Sten), but they all have decent backstories and are really fun to hear banter between each other. That's another thing; the party banter is hilarious and worth stopping to listen to.The combat in this game is beyond thrilling. You can pause combat at any time to issue orders to your four-member party, and after unpausing they will act out the order. You can play the game either in third-person or an isometric view. I prefer the isometric for tactical reasons and for that classic Baldur's Gate/Planescape feel. You can also set up tactics for your party members so that they will use certain items/abilities when a condition is met. This can get as in-depth as you like, and its one of the coolest features of the game in my humble opinion.Graphically, the game doesn't look too bad for how old it is already, but there are texture mods to spice it up, if you're interested. Be aware, however, that this could cause stuterring due to the game engine not really liking textures being TOO large. Otherwise, the graphics are servicable, but nothing to write home about. I don't really care about them, but its up to you to decide whether or not they bother you.tl;dr Dragon Age: Origins is a return to form for Bioware RPGs and a great 100-or-so-hour romp for RPG nerds like myself. Buy it if you want to experience one of the better games to come out in recent years. Its worth it. Good story, good characters, great game.

content:
Posted: January 30
												An absolute gem. Masterpiece of the Dragon Age series (haven't played Inquisition yet), tons of replayability, memorable characters and amazing storyline, infinite routes to go in terms of character development. For me this game easily qualifies to be one of the best RPGs of all time, a fantastic example of what Bioware can pull off with enough time and resources.The combat is satisfying and challenging at the same time, it will appeal to the tacticians as well as the people who aren't well versed in that sort of combat system. You can make amazing combinations with your character's attacks and the game rewards you for being intelligent. One example is if you freeze an enemy then use a crushing attack, the enemy will instantly die by being shattered, giving you an effective combo when you come upon a tough segment. There's a lot of combinations like this, and I encourage you to find them all for yourself.If you want to experience Bioware at their greatest, pick this up, with all the downloadable content. You'll sink so many hours into this game that's it not funny (ignore the time I have on Steam, used to have this on Origin and now I Family Share it with my brother-in-law, I have easily over 100+ hours on this game).

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												   Dragon Age: Origins is an oldie but goodie. It has quite the replay value - the game changes somewhat depending on the particular character origins; the character choices throughout the game impact its progression as well. The story itself is interesting - its dark tone doesn't get overwhelming thanks to occasional comic relief (sometimes unintentionally in the form of the enemies).     The game's strongest draw, however, are the well-written and expertly voiced companions - their attitude towards the player depends on the particular interactions resulting in either animosity, friendship or romance. The background banter between companions can be quite hilarious.   On the downside, the combat can get repetitive for those who are not quite the strategic thinkers (like me), although I grew to love it. The character creation is rather lacking, however the problem can be easily (and with great success) solved with the use of mods. Tl;dr: Whether you want to fall in love with one of the charming companions or get mentally scarred for life by the hideous boob monster, you're in for a treat.

												Such an amazing experience. Probably my favourite RPG of all time alongside Star Wars: KOTOR and The Sith Lords.+ Good main quest.+ The game is pretty hard on hard/nightmare settings and it will give you a challenge unlike many newer noob friendly RPG's with their ''press X to win/do something amazing" gameplay.+ Amazing soundtrack.+ Likable companions with interesting side stories.+ The origin stories! A lot of replay value here for just seeing how the diffrent origin stories start out. Also every origin story offers some unique dialogue options later in the game.+ Some great DLC like The Awakening (20+ hours of gameplay).+ Very funny party banter ( Allistair vs Morrigan is my favourite... or when Wyne and Oghren talk about beer in the Deep Roads )Really can't think of one thing i dislike about this game. Played all three Dragon Age games and this is by far my favourite. DA2 i hated with a passion while DAI i found pretty good, but not Origins level good. Sad we don't see more games of this type, and that the few RPG series we even have are going for more of an action/open world type gameplay, and less focuss on interesting story and actual RPG elements.

												Pros:- Combat is not just hack 'n slash. It relies heavily on strategy and tactics.- Character development like no other game (of its time). Not just your own story, but your party members too. The level to which you can interact with them - and even them with each other - adds a whole 'nother dimension of entertainment to the game.- It's easy to switch your party members around. content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Dragon Age: Origins is a spectacular edition to the fantasy genre. It has a lovely story of good vs. evil, and graces you with a lovely story with each waking. The companions, while not plentiful, are memorable. Each  one of them has a distinct personality, and react to different situations differently. Bioware has their trademark beautiful talking cutscenes, and depending on your group, and standing with them, they will jump into conversations on various occasions. The six varying ways to start the game adds a lot of diversity, and replayability for that matter. It's gameplay can be compared to WoW if you are familiar with it. A skill bar at the bottom for abilities and items, though a twist comes in. You have a party of four to control, you and three companions, and you have the ability to control each and every one. You gain even more control with the ability to pause the combat, and issues orders to be done when you unpause it. If you don't like strategizing, and have a console, you could pick it up on the Xbox or playstation for a more combat oriented gameplay.TL;DR, Overall, this game is a must-buy for anyone who enjoys the fantasy, spell-casting, and shield-bashing genre that this game falls under. In my honest opinion, this game is a 10/10. Great characters, good gameplay, and good story.

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2016
												Dragon Age was my first real experience with a computer game. I saw someone else playing it and wanted to give it a go. I ended up buying a PS3 and the game on console and played it through from start to finish twice (that's over 200 hours of playtime right there). Starting an Origins game is a bit of commitment, often I lose track of what I was planning for a character if I stop playing them for a while, so I start over. Rinse and repeat.At the time I can genuinely say that this game changed my life. How it holds up now is a bit harder to say for sure. I find the combat slow (which was great when I had never played a combat game before) and in fact the whole game is a bit on the slow side by today's standards, but if you can get past older graphics and a slow pace, I recommend giving it a go. Especially, when you can buy the whole lot on sale for so little.It has romance, humour, friendship, betrayal and so much more. The lore of the Dragon Age universe is deep and there is plenty to read if you're interested in a world with a lot of depth. The main story arc remains the same no matter what you do - for the most part - but you can surely mess with a lot of people's lives along the way, including your own followers. Will they find happiness? Love? A horrible death? Sometimes they will even break your heart.Also, there are 6 totally different starts to the game depending largely on race and class. If you find starting the game as a human noble a bit boring, try being a circle mage or a dwarven commoner or dwarven royalty or a city elf or a dalish elf. Each start is different. You will find yourself in a different location with a different tragedy establishing who you are. A few hours in all the stories converge to the main story arc, but you will never forget where you came from and where it placed you in the world. No amount of "this is your backstory" can have the impact of experiencing it. Even better is that you can import your save game into DA2 or use the Dragon Age Keep to recreate (or rewrite) your story for Inquisition and the choices you made will change both of those games in many small ways! You can have a continuous history over all three games. It's a beautiful thing.As for the content packs, some have more in them than others. One of my favourites is The Darkspawn Chronicles. Have you ever wondered how the final battle of a game would go if you were playing as the enemy? It was awful, having to defeat my own beloved companions in the final battle, but also really interesting. There were cutscenes and all. I may have even cried a little.Awakenings starts to move more into the style of Dragon Age 2 and introduces a very important character or two. It's a fairly substantial bit of extra content, maybe 20 hours from memory?All the way back then, I would have given the game 9.9 out of 10, now... it's still a great game if you can get into it, a classic even, but it's dated. Of course it is.If you have never tried a combat game before, but want to start playing combat games? You couldn't get a much easier introduction as you can pause combat (in all the DA games) and apply tactics - or just catch your breath. Difficulty can be ramped up if you want a challenge or right down if you want a cakewalk.Made me think, made me laugh, broke my heart, changed my life.On PC there are also plenty of modding options, Nexus mods has over 2000 files. I never really modded Origins due to playing it primarily on console, but I like the idea.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
 RATING: 9.5/10 - Legendary Masterpiece of Gaming ===Alright, i felt i needed to get this review done after finishing this game again, this time on Steam, and all the DLCs. Like you probably guessed by the score i given to it, this game is near absolute perfection as far as role playing games are concerned.So, let's start the usual way...=== Pros & Cons  + Pros + + Absolutely great story, with tons of dialogue options, romance possibilities, all fully voice-acted and very well-written.+ A huge world full of quests, discoveries to make, enemies to defeat and secrets to reveal+ Great companions with in-depth backgrounds, personalities and alignments+ Deep character and class building system, with loads of skills to suit any playstyle+ Programmable party members behaivior in combat to suit your own commands+ Real-time pause combat system with fully controllable companions and even summons, you can take control of any ally at any time+ Tons upon tons of different enemies, weapon types, armors and general loot to find+ Maximum level difficulty is hard as hell but gives great satisfaction+ Still good graphics for a game this old+ Balanced combat which always gives the right amount of challenge but is never frustrating+ Your choices in the story will impact heavily on what happens - Cons - Game doesn't work well on Win 8/8.1/10 systems. Use XP SP3 compatibility mode and run as admin to fix.- Above average amount of crashes. This is due to a memory leak issue that BioWare never addressed, but can be fixed by setting graphics to medium/low (doesn't matter if you have a high-end pc or not, it's just bugged)- Some spells are a bit overpowered if used right- Melee rogue class is underpowered and can't really compete with other builds even in late game, making it pretty useless=== Final thoughts even if it has some problems mostly related to it being old and bugged in the core programming (see memory leak), this game is still an absolute jewel and in my opinion one of the greatest RPGs ever created in the history of gaming. I have played all the major titles you can possibly imagine, and even edgy ones, but compared to this they all are blown away, only other true masterpieces can hold against a game of this greatness.Just get it.

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												Oh my god, how have I not yet written a review for this amazing Game?!Dragon Age manages to combine an Epic Story, a great tactical combat system and superb presentation almost perfectly in a single Game.I'll try to keep this somewhat short:Why is it good?  Player Freedom: You get to choose Gender, Race and Class for your Hero, each with a Unique Starting chapter and during the game, your choices MATTER. It will affect how people react to you, how a Quest ends etc. etc. The Combat System: It is a Party based Combat system that can be paused at any point, to give Commands to your party members. While that doesn't sound special - the way it is set up makes it Special. Not only are the different abilities interesting and add a lot of tactical depth, but these abilites can also interact with each other in 2 ways.1. Indirectly - for example your Mage freezes several opponents in Place, so another Party member can easily hit an AoE ability2. Directly in the form of Combos - For example combining different elemental spells to form the Thunder-Blizzard of the Century Engaging Story and Presentation: If there is one thing Bioware really knows how to do, it's how to create an interesting World/Lore and present it. The World really feels alive and coherent. There is so much material for the player to read into the Lore if he is interested and the presentation is just amazing. The cutscenes are well animated (as is pretty much anything considering when it came out), the voice acting is stellar across the board and the sound assets as well as the music itself is nothing to  sneeze at. Characters & Romances: A huge part of Bioware games such as Mass Effect, Dragon Age etc. is the ability for a Player to start a romantic relationship with a party member. To me personally, this is even better in Dragon Age: Origins, than it was in Mass Effect. The Characters in both games are of course very unique and likeable, but when it comes down to it, i'd choose Morrigan or Leliana over Tali or Liara any day of the week.Also characters that you cannot woo are amazingly well done overall. There will be some that you love, there will be some that you just wont ever really understand, and there are some that you will HATE. As it should be - and yet, if you put in the time you might figure out that a villain that you hated, actually had really good intentions.So overall they feel really well fleshed out, they feel like actual Persons with real emotions. Replayability: Due to the many different choices, origins and endings that you will experience throughout the game, it is very likely that you will have a second and third playthrough. (Hell I probably have like 20 different chararcters at this point). In addition to that, the game can be really challenging on higher difficulties - so maybe you want to try and beat it on the Legendary difficulty later on. Mods: While the modding community isn't very active anymore, it has been in the past and all their work is still available. Additional armors, better textures, new quests, Locations, characters, the ability to skip parts of the game (♥♥♥♥ the fade!),  nude- and ahem "love"-mods. You name it!They add to the already huge amount of time that this game will take out of your life. But it was worth every minute if you ask me :) What's bad about it: Slow Combat: This is pretty much the only thing i can think of. The Animations in Combat might feel slow to some people. They kinda did to me at first and were made faster in Dragon Age II and Inquisition. It's probably best to quickly check it in a Youtube Video - see if it bothers you. It's by no means unplayably slow, but everything kinda feels like it should just be a tick faster. Achievements: Now i dont really know if this can be counted as a negative thing for most people, but i feel bad only mentioning the combat System. So the game does have achievements - however they are not supported by steam. If you decide to play it on Origin, they will show up and you can brag to your friends there, as i am sure we all have a huge amount of friends on Origin....This seems like i am really biased, but that is the games fault because it is just THAT good. There really aren't many bad aspects that stood out to me.Overall this is a game that I believe everybody should have experienced at least once. It is certainly better than it's sequels, and to me, it even blows the Mass Effect series out of the water.Sale or not - this game is definitely worth it's price

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												If you're willing to get past some of the antiquated designs (mainly combat and inventory), DA:O is one of the best RPGs you could ever play. You could spend hours just talking to your companions, who are written fantastically and really draw you into the game. The intense struggle of uniting Fereldan and its conflicted peoples against the Darkspawn is a one of a kind adventure. There can be some lulls in its pacing, which generally come after completing a major quest (I'm looking at you, Deep Roads), but if you can power through and continue with the game, you won't regret it one bit.

number of helpful: 12 of 13 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												Take a fantasy novel, double it's length, throw in BioWare, and add a little EA meddling to make yet another Bioware classic.There isn't a secret recipe for a good solid game. It's just a shame the pure ingredient called Bioware can't be found anymore. You always find it now tainted with EA.While you will find this title to be well crafted, it's not for everyone. I had to get over my hate for the  fantasy genre, which wasn't easy. I'm glad that I did, as I would have missed out on yet another  Bioware classic. If you prefer running n' gunning, don't dream of playing this unless you can change your attitude. Sadly, many of the newer generation of PC gamers fall into the “action packed” trap, where they miss out on what makes a game – it's story. Characters take revenge, scheme behind your back, among other things.Speaking of story, one of my teachers once told me that a good plot mixes together the right amounts of gore, sex, and humor. While you will find all three in Dragon Age: Origins, there isn't enough humor to lighten the load so to speak. You will find that the story simply drags on. I recommend playing in 1-3 hour sessions, otherwise you might just end up leaving such a great title in the dust. The “behind your back” conversations are a nice break as the maps can take a long time to explore.It took me about 65 hours to play though once, not even completing every single minor side quest. Mass Effect 3 took 24, and the others in the series about 12-24. The store page lists 80 hours of gameplay, which seems about right. Many won't be able to withstand that long on one game since it feels like it just drags on. At the end of the day, if you can bear with it, you won't be disappointed.The “Ultimate Edition” includes quite a few DLCs that I didn't end up using/playing. The original seems plenty long enough, but I don't think I will end up going back soon for “The Awakening” DLC. The game ends with a cliff hanger, which was obviously setup for the 2nd.The joke with Mass Effect is that you should get an achievement for not getting laid. While some of you understand that joke and it being true for Mass Effect, it's not the same here. Dragon Age uses a scale from -100 to 100 (or what seems to be -100). If a party member's gauge is to low, they will leave you! Mass Effect uses a simple 1-5 scale, where “loyalty” is at 4, romance is declared at a 5, and save porting uses a special 6. All of that is of course hidden, but in Dragon Age it isn't. This newer and what some would call better “romance mechanic” makes it hard to understand. This isn't a real life simulator, but does a much better job then the “getting laid simulator” in the Mass Effect series. You can follow and please one individual, but then end up displeasing others severely – even if they aren't in your current party. Throw in the invisible “hardening” mechanic as well.. You will have to read the wiki to understand how complex the whole game is.It's judgment time now. I think 91/100 is fair for the metascore, as long as you can overcome your hate for the fantasy genre (nudge nudge me), not enough “pew pew” (many young gamers) and understand or appreciate the mature subjects within the title.So all in all, even with bugs in character's movement, old 2009 graphics, and a story that just seems to drag on, I can't stamp a great or terrible score. Playing quite a few other titles, and understanding who you need to be to enjoy this, I give this super long review a number for the game.8.5/10

number of helpful: 12 of 13 people (92%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 10, 2016
												Instead of reviewing one game, it would be more useful to discuss the trilogy. I would recommend you get them from Origin—unfortunately, there is no franchise bundle—though you can transfer saves between clients. Dragon Age shows BioWare's creativity by redefining the CRPG experience of storytelling as well as role-playing design. Each game provides subversions in fantasy, and even in BioWare games, that shows their best quality. Unlike Mass Effect, this trilogy has little direct relations, choosing instead to expand upon the lore. In many ways, DA uses aspects of past series (ex. Baldur's Gate, even SoD) to focus on the strengths of each game. The result, as often seen by fans, is a series divided by various camps thinking one game defines the franchise.  The truth is what defines DA is more a collection of shared interests: A title granted to a hero, and a story of world-building and of companions. Each game should be evaluated as its own take, which means if one game doesn't interest you the others may be more favorable.  Dragon Age: Origins	DA:O is often considered the best DA game. Looking back on Origins, it's hard to imagine that DA would be BioWare's most innovative series. DA:O is mainly derivative of their previous games of BG and Neverwinter Nights. You just have to look far beneath the surface for their differences.Though the lore is free from the D&D influence, choosing a Judeo-Christian-like fantasy religion, the mechanical complexity of DA:O is reminiscent of CRPGs. It's more streamlined and story/companion driven than their older games, but if you raise the difficulty it provides just as much challenge. It helps keeps a steady pace.As someone who was put off by BG's beginning, I relished returning to DA:O where companions only die in plot-related moments. The AI in BioWare's games have always been finicky, so the lack of punishment for random behavior is easier to tolerate. However, the difficulty can sometimes feel cheapened—especially in DLCs—if you don't maximize every tactical element, even on Normal.Gameplay, however, isn't DA:O's strongest aspect. The combat scaling can feel random, coupled by the slow pace of attacks and the limited variety of enemies. Like other CRPGs there is a lot of pausing to micromanage required to win. However, the combat is not what people come to replay but its narrative design.DA:O uses a modular design where there are multiple paths for each required section of the plot, but how you choose to resolve them and how they affect the future events is what is important. Some chapters have higher skill requirements, but your paths stay as player-driven as the city in BG2. The influence of past events, your character's identity and origin, and companion responses offer replayability. It all almost works.The origins of DA:O is where it struggles. The weakest introduction is probably the Dalish elves, which is odd because they have the most lore. The Human noble, City Elves and Dwarf stories are simple revenge/justice hooks. Only the Mage stands out as the most unique. Whatever your choice, it becomes irrelevant after the intro as the world takes the stage. Personal affiliation with the protagonist, as a result, becomes the weakest part of DA:O.  Dragon Age 2This flaw feels like the main source of refinement for DA2, and it's why I enjoy this game the most out of the series. The story of the Champion and of the personal narratives of Hawke's family and companions feels the most tightly written, unique story I've seen from BioWare. (Especially with Varric's liberties in the plot.) Even though Hawke is about as bland as Shepherd, the agency for how s/he reacts makes the player feel like this is his/her Hawke.Unfortunately, what was achieved for a greater personal narrative came at the cost of what many enjoy, replayability. Hawke can only be a human, and the only important choice is whether or not s/he is a mage or not. The storyline offers the illusion of agency similar to BeamDog's SoD where the "role-playing" is choosing how to respond to a predetermined fate with some greater consequences to decide. It's an experience I think story-driven/lore players would relish more than DA:O die-hards, and the way the issues raised (the Quanari's Qun influence, the Templar vs. Mage conflict and the Kirkwall refugees) are more grey than DA:O's binary options helped me immerse myself into DA. Especially the Templar vs. Mage conflict, which the game heavily reminds you of in almost every other quest and as it's a focal point for the setting of Inquisition.That repetition can also be seen in the gameplay. The best that can be said is how more visceral and fluid the gameplay has been enhanced over DA:O, and the unique setting of Kirkwall is far more memorable over the blandness of Fereldon. Most complaints are levied at the reused locations, which could be fixed if Kirkwall was one massive city like in DA:I. The other issue is the overused Templar vs. Mage conflict.This latter issue I find intentional as the reoccurrence of the possibility of blood magic and other mage-issues may change your mind whether or not you believe mages should be given total freedom. It may instill a prejudice and show character growth towards even hating mages, and I've yet to see another game be as effective as DA2. However, I will admit that DA2 suffers from its quest design and reused assets, which wasn't as much of a problem in DA:O. It is from this misstep that BioWare would learn to address in the next game, DA:I. Dragon Age (3): Inquisition If DA:I asks one question from you, then it is this: What is content to you, and what is it worth? DA:I is by far the most massive of all BioWare games, but it's also the most padded if you're a completionist. If you accept not doing everything, however, then you can find just as an enriching personal experience as DA2 and as a experience driven by player agency. Though of all three, this game lacks consequences.It's strange to complain about lacking consequences in a game that gives you total freedom, but this game does its best to think there are risks. DA2 also suffered from this issue but the guise feels more transparent here. You may lose a character or decide the fate of some NPC in places. The problem is how much of your time is spent doing one-solution tasks vs. player-driven choices. You will never see the same extent of options as much as the amount of choices from past games influences this world.This isn't to say I'm against the base-building mechanics. They are resources that offer many diversions to gain them, including when you're not playing the game, and the grind towards progression helps make the plot feel grander. However, you can easily get caught up in 20+ hours of fetch-quests only to enjoy the story-bits that offer something different. This design does succeed by making the Inquisition feel like our Inquisition (with companions).Companions have never been an issue for BioWare. While I didn't enjoy every single character in DA:O (Sten and Dwarf-Dude) and DA2 (Fenris and Carter), I do like how BioWare has innovated companions for non-squad members. The War Room members, reoccurring helpers (Scout Harding) and other familiar faces lends a lot of close ties in all parts of the organization. The amount of effort to write that much content, let alone program it, speaks volumes for how much BioWare cares for their story-content.Unfortunately, DA:I sacrificed the one thing that made DA so wondrous for me, the excellent pacing, that makes replaying it more daunting than other games.Conclusion & Other Issues with the SeriesIf it isn't clear, I love all these games, but not for the same reasons. However, the biggest issue is its DLC practices (see below).

content:
Posted: January 21, 2016
												The following review will be my first impression of the game.I bought the Ultimate Edition while it was on sale, and I definitely think I got more than my money's worth. In retrospect, I'd probably buy it for the normal price. Let me tell you why:PROS-In RPG's like Skyrim, ESO, and even Dragon Age Inquisition, I have a bad habit of skipping through dialouge. With this game, however, I found myself listening closely to every single cutscene. I started as a human rogue, so I'm not sure what the other origin stories are like.-The combat is certainly interesting. It's not like the games ahead of this one. In fact, it reminded me very much of Runescape combat. You click on an enemy, and your player auto-attacks it. Of course, you can use your abilities. I have yet to explore the tactical combat system. I just don't like pausing the game to give orders, and it's working out fine for me.-The character customization is decent. One benefit of playing on PC is the availability of mods. While I found the base hairstyles and facial features more than enough, there are some mods to add more choices if you're really invested in your character's appearance.-The followers are full of personality, and you can romance some of them too. -The dialouge options are great for roleplaying. Instead of the standard 2 choices of evil and good responses, there's four or so responses you can choose from to create a more in-depth personality for your character.CONS:-Don't be expecting amazing graphics. It's pretty standard, even on the highest setting. -The movement system is clunky and weird to get used to at first. A and D keys turn the camera instead of the traditional strafing movements offered by newer games. If you hold down the right mouse button you can swivel the camera, which I found to be easier.As someone who played Dragon Age 2 and Inquisition before visiting this game, I can say it's a completely different experience- in a good way. You cannot go wrong buying this game while it's on sale.

number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
Dragon Age: Origins is my favorite game of all times, and I am absolutely loving every bit of it. I must have finished it 5 times by now, and I still find myself drawn to it every year or so. It takes me about 120 hours to fully complete the Ultimate Edition. The Ultimate Edition of Dragon Age: Origins is the complete bundle consisting of Dragon Age: Origins, its expansions and its DLCs in a single release.   Which means that there is a huge world to explore: vast cities, villages, abandoned dwarven thaigs, large forests, underground caverns, ancient ruins, swamps, mountains, towers and citadels, palaces and estates, stores and taverns, caves and highways. Oh, I could go on for hours about all the places you could visit throughout your playthroughs. It's up to you, my dear reader, to take heart and embark on a journey like none you have ever had. And thanks to the insane amount content, detail, customization, and features - every playthrough will grant you a new experience.   There are six origins - background stories for player characters — that are playable in Dragon Age: Origins and a seventh in Dragon Age: Origins - Awakening. These playable backstories will allow the Warden to put themselves in a specific role within the social structure of Ferelden and will help explain motivations for the Warden joining the Grey Wardens. There are three main Races you can choose from: Human, Dwarf and Elf. After choosing your Origins and Race, you will get to choose your Class and Specialization. There are three classes – warrior, rogue and mage – in Dragon Age: Origins, each with four specializations. Six additional specializations were added in the expansion Dragon Age: Origins - Awakening. To be honest, all my 5 complete playthroughs were as a Human Mage. Gifted with a power considered dangerous by most, mages were always my favorite."Tread carefully, friend.If you intend to cross the path of one whose soul is so tightly woven into the realm of the arcane, I would not suggest you do it lightly."   Dragon Age lets you create you character from scratch. You get to shape his appearance and choose a set of starting skills and powers. The game quickly envelops you in it's story. Which is a legendary adventure of a Grey Warden and his companions traveling together through the fantastic lands of Thedas, seeking to end the Blight and save the world from being utterly destroyed and enslaved by the Darkspawn. This is a long journey is full of fantasy and drama. Tragedy and Comedy. Romance and Betrayal. War and Peace. Good and Evil.   My Grey Warden was an almighty Archmage. Who wielded the power to crush and dismember the enemy with a snap of his fingers. A true leader, merciful and forgiving, capable of turning foes into friends. A most persuasive character, who tries to resolve every conflict peacefully. A man would help and save everyone, even with the cost of his own life.    The darkspawn are a race of humanoid tainted creatures that mostly dwell in the underground of Thedas. When the darkspawn uncover one of the Old Gods, they expose it to the taint, changing it into an Archdemon, which then leads them in an attack against the surface world called a Blight. The darkspawn are perhaps the greatest single threat to all of Thedas; they are bloodthirsty, exceptionally numerous and willing to indiscriminately kill or corrupt all in their path.   But my favorite part of the game - was the companionship and all that comes with it. On your travels you will meet all sorts of people, because you live in a world full of magic and wonders, abounding with energy ready to be gathered. You will travel thousand of miles, meeting: Humans, Elves, Dwarves and Qunari which could be your friends or enemies, depending on your approach. Some of them will join your cause, becoming your most trusted friends who would shield you from the killing blow. Or perhaps your relationships would develop into something even more wonderful, and they would become your loved ones. Romance and Friendship is always nice, especially when the characters feel this natural and real. Each with their own thoughts and impressions on your current situation. Some of them may approve and appreciate the fact that you're helping innocent people, saving entire villages from being destroyed or just doing charity, while others may think it's a total waste of time, and recommend you to carry on. Their personalities are so full-fledged and so deep, that even the most brief connection can make the strongest and most indelible impression.   Just like in real life, everyone is a stranger at first, and every companion is a puzzle. But with each passing day, you start do discover who they truly are thus, slowly solving the once mysterious puzzle. Depending on your words and actions, your companions will either: become your friends or your enemies, fall in love with you or desert you completely. You can always head to the camp, where you can find all your party members:- Morrigan - a charming shapeshifting sorceress. With a personality as cold as the tips of her pretty little fingers. But beneath all that sarcasm and cynicism, lies a frigid little girl. That wishes to be protected, truly loved and appreciated by people she cares for. [1]Morrigan: Have a care where your eyes linger, Alistair.Alistair: Yes, well don't worry. It's not what you think.Morrigan: I see.Alistair: I was looking at your nose.Morrigan: And what is it about my nose that captivates you so?Alistair: I was just thinking that it looks exactly like your mother's.Morrigan: I hate you so much.Alistair: What?Morrigan: Never mind.- Alistair - a former templar initiate who was recruited into the Grey Wardens not long before the protagonist. A valiant warrior and a loyal friend. He has a good and caring heart, and often will ask the Warden about his or her welfare. While serious and sincere most of the time, he likes to joke around and isn't afraid to appear somewhat childish. Which I think, is a wonderful trait to have. [2]Join us, brothers and sisters. Join us in the shadows where we stand vigilant. Join us as we carry the duty that cannot be forsworn. And should you perish, know that your sacrifice will not be forgotten... and that one day, we shall join you. - Leliana - a bard and cloistered sister from Orlais who sought refuge in Ferelden. She firmly believes in the existence of the Maker, and thus dedicated her life to the chantry. She is a very skilled rogue and a cunning ally. A very passionate and eloquent young lady. [3]Leliana: Maybe we could get you in a nice dress one day. Silk. No, maybe velvet.Morrigan: Stop looking at my breasts like that. 'Tis most disturbing!   The voice acting is extremely well done. All the people you meet feel alive and unique. The music is memorable and epic, Inon Zur quickly became one of my favorite composers.    This game is a true masterpiece. I still get goosebumps every time the battle at Ostagar is about to start. I still shed a tear or two when Duncan dies. And I still get a goofy smile every time Alistair cracks one of his classic jokes. Priceless.   Every creature you kill, every flower you crush, and every choice you make, will undoubtedly affect the world and it's people. And depending on how will you Push the World - the World will Push back.    I would like to talk about every character and every aspect of this stunning game, but it seems that I've hit the limit. And it is time to end this review. I will leave you with this last quote:[/i]"Either you have an enviable memory, or a pitiable life, to know nothing of regret." [/i]10/10

All the people you meet feel alive and unique. The music is memorable and epic, Inon Zur quickly became one of my favorite composers.    This game is a true masterpiece. I still get goosebumps every time the battle at Ostagar is about to start. I still shed a tear or two when Duncan dies. And I still get a goofy smile every time Alistair cracks one of his classic jokes. Priceless.   Every creature you kill, every flower you crush, and every choice you make, will undoubtedly affect the world and it's people. And depending on how will you Push the World - the World will Push back.    I would like to talk about every character and every aspect of this stunning game, but it seems that I've hit the limit. And it is time to end this review. I will leave you with this last quote:[/i]"Either you have an enviable memory, or a pitiable life, to know nothing of regret." [/i]10/10

												This is my favorite western RPG ever.If you like bioware RPGs I think this is the best one they've made, good story, good gameplay. It has the traditional RPG classes but with very interesting sub-classes (Who doesn't want to be a blood mage at least once?) number of helpful: 12 of 14 people (86%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												Short verdict: an epic story-driven RPG with all the usual BioWare stuff: moral choices, romance options, a s-h-1tl0ad of dialogues, alternative endings, unlockable character specialisations and mediocre tactical combat system.If you’ve played and liked games like Mass Effect and Jade Empire, you might also like this game. Although combat in Mass Effect was much more better.(If it’s too long to read, just skip to the summary.)The strongest aspect of DAO is the story. It’s very long, very detailed, interesting, but also overwhelming. After 100+ hours into the game, you get tired of it, and just wish for it to end, but it doesn’t. Don’t get me wrong, the game is interesting till the very end, but, at times, it seems that there’s just too much lore thrown at you. When I play games, I play them like this: 1. exploration -> 2. side quests -> 3. main quests, because I don’t want to miss anything. In DAO, after entering a new region, you can easily spend 2 hours just talking with NPCs, before you accomplish anything.The chaotic pacing, in which the game throws quests, puzzles or unlockable secrets at you doesn’t help either. At times, there could be more than 20 or even 30 active quests in different regions of the game’s world.Also, some of the main quest lines are incredibly long, particularly the Fade mission and Deep Roads mission. The Fade mission is so annoyingly long, because of all the mazes and backtracking, that there’s even mod[www.nexusmods.com] to skip it.  And it took me 3 evenings to finish everything in Orzammar and Deep Roads.On the bright side, all side quests are interesting, enjoyable, unique and well thought through. Even the few fetch quests that there are in this game, are nice and cool.However, it should be noted, that although the story is fantastic and engaging, there’s not much new DAO brings to the table. What you have is basically your typical Tolkien universe: elves with bows and arrows that have lost the glory of the civilization they once had and now are living in forests or city ghettos, Viking-like dwarfs who live underground with their runes and golems and crafting, greedy and power-hungry humans and menacing and brainless orcs, which are named “darkspawn” in this game. The class choices are also very typical: warrior, rogue and mage.And, it should be noted, that the game is favouring the warrior class over the other two classes, because majority of your companions are warriors and, also, most of the cool armour sets and weapons are intended for warriors. Mages, on the other hand, have more variable skill sets. I played as a rogue. It was still fun, but I wish I had more unique armour sets and weapons. This flaw is corrected in DAO: Awakening, though.As to the combat system, I think it’s the biggest DAO drawback. The combat is tactical and, although not static, it very much feels like the old RPGs of the 80’s (which I absolutely hate), where you need to take into account the stats, damage type and use either correct form of attack or skill. Another feature that reminds me of those old RPGs, are sudden ambushes, when enemies appear out of nowhere. I’d rather have had just a simple hack ’n’ slash experience, where the outcome is based on my reaction instead of strategy. I wouldn’t mind the planning part; at first, I even liked that I am able to pause the game, switch between the weapon sets, plan which item or skill to use, where to place my squad mates; but later on it turned out that, in narrow dungeon areas, this actually doesn’t play out well, and, even if it did, it still is tiresome to micromanage the s-h-1tl0ad of skills and items you have, after you have levelled up above level 20. Theoretically, you don’t need to micromanage everything, because there are automatic action slots available, but in reality, the automatic actions don’t cover every possible situation, and you still need to switch between the characters and adjust their actions. Fortunately, when you’re maxed out, you can just go and kill everyone, but the strongest enemies, without using any skills or strategy. Believe me, after 100+ hours into the game, that pausing and clicking gets annoying. For me it was so annoying, that I just started using console command runscript killallhostiles towards the end of DAO: Awakening. I was tired of the combat, I just wanted to find out, how the story ends.As to other gameplay aspects, insufficient inventory space (and even insufficient storage space) and lack of money are typical RPG problems that are present in DAO, as well. Also, very often, certain outcomes are dependent on just a few tiny dialogue choices. So save often!The level design is nice and the different areas are detailed and quite beautiful (as far as the dated graphics go). The characters are designed well and thoroughly, each having their unique background (and companion quests for the squad mates). You can engage in dialogues with your squad mates. Your dialogue choices determine their rate of approval of you. And it’s fun to listen to their funny cat fights, while you’re on a mission.As to the graphics, well, the game is quite old, so don’t expect Witcher 3 quality in it, especially when it comes to the textures. But there are a few mods that can improve your experience. I particularly recommend the Redesigned mod[www.nexusmods.com] for better character look. There are also some SweetFX mods available, but, imo, they just make things worse. Vibrant colours mod[www.nexusmods.com] is ok, too.A few words about the DLCs:Stone Prisoner: a fun additional quest that adds an extra warrior to your squad.Warden Keep: a fun additional quest that provides you with a base, where you can buy good items and equipment and also store your inventory. You also get a unique armour set and two new skills.Return to Ostagar: a chance to avenge Duncan, your mentor who dies in the second main quest.Feastday gifts and pranks: special items that can increase or decrease your companion rate of approval.The Witch Hunt: this DLC reveal the events around Morrigan and her child, who is crucial in the next DA games. This story line is especially rewarding, if you romanced and was faithful to Morrigan in the main game.Leliana’s Song: a nice little campaign, in which you play as Lelian - one of your companions in the main game. It tells the events before Lelian became a sister of the Chantry.The Darkspawn Chronicles: a what-if scenario, where you play as a darkspawn warrior and try to destroy the grey wardens of Ferelden. It’s short, boring and feels like a fan made content.The Golems of Amgarrak: just as boring as the Darkspawn Chronicles, with annoying backtracking and particularly difficult combat.Awakening: the best expansion of all. Just as interesting as the main game. The events take place after the main game. This DLC raises your level cap from 25 to 35, it expands your skill set, specialisation options and has better equipment and unique items. Unfortunately, there are quite a few bugs in Awakening, which prevent you from completing certain quests. I had to use third party patches on more than one occasion.So, to sum up, DAO + Awakening is an epic RPG with great and engaging story. If you are a fan of RPGs, this game is definitely for you. Unfortunately, DAO has all the typical RPG flaws, as well. Because of the overwhelming amount of the content, it is better to take breaks from this game, before you finish it. The Ultimate Edition is highly recommended.My overall rating: 8/10. P.S. I played the game on Origin (130 hours), therefore, the short gameplay time on Steam. You can use your Steam key to activate DAO on Origin.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												I'm a grandmother and often simply cannot keep up with many of the fast paced action games out there. However, with the pause capability and the ability to move every character to where I want them is perfect for me. Also the fact it let's me make my own danged decisions counts as well (well most of them...there are some it steers me into without mercy). I admit that I usually play at normal with a few drops into casual which enables me to enjoy the game even more. The fact that I can do that is  a plus, instead of doing a battle over and over until I win  (not that I haven't done that) or worse, be forced to give up. This game is like immersing oneself into a rich story that one mostly controls. Not that fate won't have it's say now and again. A thing that is all to the good. Like the building games I adore, you place one brick after another, each time hoping it's the right brick, and watch your creation expand and grow. Don't get complacent though, as any of your bricks/comments can cause a totally unexpected reaction. I say go for it and enjoy!

content:
Posted: February 12
												One of the most fun games I've ever played. It came out in 2009 or so and I played it in 2017. The best way I can explain it is this: it hasn't the greatest story ever, nor the greatest RPG system ever, nor the prettiest graphics by today's standards, not the best design or a sprawling open world (which all the cool RPGs must have these days).But it succeds by combining good elements from other great RPG's into a fantastic streamlined experience. I had a great time without ever feeling like I was "grinding", there was never a dull moment even though the settings were somewhat familiar from other great and original RPG's or movies. Also, Awakening is a brilliant expansion. I can see why people have hundreds of hours played on this game. Highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10
												This game... is hard for me to put into words. There is a apocraphyal rumor out there that this game had been developed to completion by BioWare before its sale to EA. And that EA freaked after the sale when they discovered this. But when you play this game, you can see the detail and attention that BioWare put into it. Some would say it is the finest game BioWare ever made (I still say Knights of the Old Republic was better, but this is a darn close second).The quests are epic. The gameplay is fantastic. The characters are well-developed and have rich backstories. There are six origin stories for your PC, and two of them have differences depending on factors (the Magi differs slightly if you are human or elf, and the City Elf Origin differs in a rather signifact way depending on gender). You have some of the greatest companions in BioWare games (Leliana, Morrigan, Sten, even Alistair). The romances make sense... depending on who you pursue.And the background... The Fifth Blight, the Grey Wardens, Ferelden... all of it is wonderful. And then there is the soundtrack... some of it is heart-wrenching.And of course... you have to save the world. And in this game, a lot of that saving is from itself.And since the Ultimate Edition brings along with it all the expansions... it gets even more epic.Cannot recommend this game enough.

I would definitely purchase the game because its OVERALL amazing.~Quiirex

content:
Posted: June 8, 2015
												Electronic Arts Dragon Age: Origins RPG is for its time a breakthrough for a RPG game.  The Good1)  Play one of three different races, each having a different story line. This is presented at the start of your story.2)  Play one of three classes, Warrior, Rouge, or Mage.  At a higher level the class you choose can be improved to have skills like for example (Holy Smite) for the Warrior class.3)  What you choose to say for your Gray Warden will effect your RPC group and the story outcome.4)  Many quests during the Main story and side quests. To gain coin, favor from RPC's and loot.5)  Have a relationship either male, female, or both! Naughty Naughty!6)  Mixing your group. You can mix and match as much as you want between RPC in your party.The not so Good1) Plot never changes so if you complete the Story at Normal level and play again at Hard level (Ho Hum) you already know what to do.  Of course it may take a long period of time to defeat the Archdeamon's army.2)  What? my (Gray Warden) is a mute? Kinda,  It would have been better to have him/her speak the sentence you have choosen.  When you choose a action for the (Gray Warden) it is acted out during the game.3) Weapons and Armor stay fresh and new, it would have been interesting to have items get worn or become damaged.The game is addictive if you a first time player or return to it after a while.  What is nice with the Ultimate edition is that after you play the main story you can transfer your (Gray Warden) to one of the other stories to start another adventure.

Who are you gonna let die ?Dive into this unique adventure and discover a huge fantasy world in dire need of a hero (and his loyal and unique companions !).

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												This game is defintly one of the best games i've ever played and one of my favourites (if not my favourite). The gameplay is great, second to none, the storyline coundn't be anybetter BioWare really knows how to pull it off as shown in also in their Mass Effect Series. The storyline does well to get you attached to the game by making the descions that you make effect how the story pans out for you for the rest of the game and its expansions (classic BioWare tho i must note). The chat dialouges and cutscenes are always dramatic and never cease to bore you and always seem to add to the drama and hype of the already superb Storyline, the quests are never boring and their are endless side quests to do besides the storyline, this game will last you weeks on end.The characters in this game are represented very well, with so many different personallities in the game you are never left short from any chat dialogue. As for things to do other than questes you can't fall short, Poison Making, Trap Making, Tactics, Enchanting, Gathering and much more, I'm sure you wouldn't run out of things to do. As far as i am concerned i have not come across any glitchs or problems though bearing in mind it is a game and i am sure i will encounter one soon enough. I would recomend this game to anyone that really likes RPG games that have a great storyline and good feel overall to the gameplay, this game is like all the good things from The Elder Scrolls Series and The Diablo Series put together it is just great and i cannot stop playing it, best $7.50 i've ever spent and I would be willing to pay the actual price of around $20-$30 for this game because it is worth every cent you pay for. Had this game not gone on sale i would've never bought it, hats off to Valve for putting this game on sale and getting this gem out of the rough. Everyone NEEDS to get this game, you'll regret not getting it.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												Great fun! Dragon Age has you taking on the role of the newest Grey Warden, travelling the lands of Ferelden recruiting allies to fight against a new blight of Darkspawn - a blight not taken seriously by others in the kingdom. This game is definitely the spiritual successor of the Baldur's Gate series, with a deep, complex storyline that twists and shapes according to your choices as the Warden. The excellent writing and voice acting keep the game feeling fresh; I thought the humourous exchanges between different party members were particularly fantastic. I've enjoyed Dragon Age immensely so far and would strongly recommend it to fans of roleplaying games, fantasy settings and those who love a compelling story.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
												The first videogame I ever played that made me cry. One of the absolute first PC games I ever owned too. It sat in my library for months upon months until I thought one day "Why not?" and I can honestly say without a doubt that after that first time playing it changed the way I saw videogames forever. They weren't hack and slash games for fun, something to pass the time and win achievements in. Oh, no. They were stories, worlds waiting to unfurl at your fingertips of heroes, lost histories, forbidden myths, and characters that stay in your heart forever. Little did I know that by giving this game a chance despite the older graphics that I would come to fall in love with the characters and come to follow the series for years to come. If you ever ger into the series, I 100% reccomend the books which are prequels and sequels to the games and really help bring this amazing world to life. Also if you want insight on Duncan and Loghain, the first two books make you see those characters in an entirely new light.Overall, this will forever be one of my favorite game series, something I can keep coming back to--to meet the characters and explore the world once more... and fall in love with them all over again.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												Depressing as it is to know that this (and Mass Effect 2) were the last good Bioware games, Dragon Age Origins stands as one of my favorite games, considering that it is one of the few games that I can enjoy from start to finish. Pros:-The game contains a great amount of content. You can easily sink 60 hours into the base game-The cast of characters following the protagonist are memorable and well written. In fact, they are about on par with the cast in Knights of the Old Republic-The gameplay is well balanced and may often require you to use your brain, especially in higher difficulty settings-The dialogue is well written, and your character's attributes may determine what you want him or her to say-Each of the 6 different origin stories are very entertaining, and even offer a degree of replay value-Your choices in the game actually have an affect on the outcome of the story and are far from black/white, as a cunning player may find a compromise if all the availible options are assessed-The soundtrack fits the mood quite well, though (aside from a few tracks) there's none that really stand out to the point where I'd go out of my way to listen to itCons:-There are difficulty spikes in certain areas of the game-The tedious fade section-The extremely akward romance scenes-Magic can be quite over powered to the point where it takes only one mage to influence the outcome of the fight-Although the Player Character can do some very horrible things, there isn't exactly an "evil" endingVerdict:Dragon Age Origins is an extremely entertaining role playing game that offers a vast amount of content. If you are a fan of Bioware games, you'd be doing yourself a disservice by not playing this. If I had to rate the game, I'd give it a 9/10.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												Dragon Age Origins is a game of fierce strategy, engaging characters and amazing narrative.You start the game off in one of the various origin stories. Almost all of these are well done, and serve to really lend an identity to your player character. After that you are thrust onto a tale of revenge which prompts you to gather all of the various powers in the land toward survival, or risk extinction.What Dragon Age Origins does well is moral ambiguity and effective characterization. All of your party members have unique and interesting backstories, many of whom are entirely optional to recruit and you could just as easily murder them if you please. This also extends to the villains, who are all very complex and have some of the best dialogue in the game.This is the Ultimate Edition which includes all of the paid DLC Bioware released, including the expansion pack Dragon Age Awakening. All of the little DLC like the preorder packs have already been released for free. Making this the definitive edition of the game, and a must play for anyone who likes RPGs. Bioware also released an SDK for the game, and hundreds of modifications have been released for it. Take in Dragon Age Origins, few games like it are still made today.

												I finished this game last night live on stream. It took me about 3 weeks of playing for about 3/4 hours per night. It is a fantastic game with an incredibly amazing storyline and well thought out characters. The game is left open for replayability because of the way you can a) pick different characters/background b) the way you can delivery yourself to the AI in the game and c) the difficulties. I played the game on Normal throughout, however I could easily go back and play it on Easy for a more RPG style type of game or on a higher difficulty for a more stategic style type of game, which I will most likely do. The music as well in the game is fantastic. I would highly recommend this game for anyone who enjoys diving into a vast world with lots of story and characters where you can pick how you play! 10/10 from me!

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
												Recommend? Yes indeed. If you like old school rpg games. For those that dont like to read, plz stop now lol.Will say that other users who commented on the single version DAO are right when they say there is less content in comparison to other old school rpg's. Weapons, clothing, armors are limited but can be compensated through a mod that allows you to craft ur own items. Storyline is great, I have played the game before it came on steam and will say like so many others have played at least over 15 times. The race origins gives a lot of replay value, since certain storyline characters and items can only unlocked through that specific origin. Every origin also contributes a different game ending and influence on the post game world. Many mods available to influence this. Lot of lore to read for those that realy want to get everything out of the story, not as much as in TES4 Oblivion (good god) but still more than enough.One may argue the classes available for choice are limited to only 3 classic classes being: warrior, rogue and mage. Then again this is compensated with specialisations or if you want to translate into d&d language: multiclassing and yes with no pentalty. These classes are sometimes unlocked through relations with companions (regular no romance) and sometimes by purchasing manuals of that class or making certain decissions during the storyline that allow you to obtain said class. U can also choose what type of class u will get through levelling, meaning to say for example: a warrior u can choose to invest in two handed skills,  sword and shield skills and supportive skills, allowing u to build the type of character u want. Also the same with companions so u can shape ur party just the way u like it.Once again, lot of replay value.Storyline is pretty much rpg classic, first starting out not knowing what is happening, struggling through the story halfway, getting better, and in the end be the hero and save everything. Great storyline with almost every classic element you could wish for. This being a game that unlike many others, combines graphics and a good story line. Battlesystem in the early going can be a lil confusing but if you have played these type of games before, no sweat. For everyone something, storyquest about mages, elves, dwarves, the holy grail (has other name in game), and the corruptive nature of men, could have been LOTR if that hadnt come out sooner.Character companions are also very varied, going from those with noble origins to common crooks and murders, drunk warriors and a stoic giant who just likes to be sarcastic and put everyone down. Good thing is that they have written these characters in a way that any player can certainly recognise one self with fragments of those characters' story. Every companion also has a personal quest that allows the player to greatly enhance their relation with said companion. Other ways are to give them presents. With higher relations comes that companions get a specific bonus to their stats. (for example, +strentgh for warrior, +willpower for mage, and so on.)Few bugs that remain unsolved with certain side quests but those can easily be undone, plenty of reading material on the net on those right now.Awakening: good storyline once again allthough I will say that it is somewhat short in comparison to the original campaign. To say when it launched: they stated that origins would give the player over 70 - 80 hours in game to complete, in comparison Awakening was announced as having a even larger amount of space to explore then the original but with only between 20 - 30 hours of game time to complete, they may have run a lil short on that one, but in the end is it worth it? Oh yes. Is launched in game as a separate campaingn so doesnt go along with the main campaign, but like the main campaign also has an epilogue showing the result of the player choices made during his/her progress. New things, few new materials, few new companions, and guess what you become senechal (local lord) of your own keep and can judge people (comes back in DA Inquistion, spoiler).The rest of the dlc in short:Return to ostagar: adds background story and closure for the Alistair companion of the main campaign.Leliana's song: gives u a backgroundstory on the Leliana companion of the main campaign.Witchhunt: give prequel story to what Morrigan has possibly planned for the events in DA Inquisition(spoiler)Stone Prisoner: Gives u an additional companion through a short storyline (comparable to Zaeed in ME2 or Jarvik in ME3)Golems of Amgarrak: Dwarven history (lotr compare, in the end balrog like battle) and for me the hardest to play, lot of puzzles and difficult battles.Warden's Keep: Discover the sinister origins of a merchant family and in the process claim a castle for urself to enjoy. Darkspawn Chronicles: Play as the enemy, invade, pillage, burn...leave none alive.In short (ironic I know): Is it worth getting, no question, eventhough it has a few flaws here and there ramaining, everything else you get more then compensates for it. And for me one of the best rpg's I have ever played. Will certainly not dissapoint.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												Dragon Age: Origins is one of those rare games which profess to offer a deep, meaningful degree of choice and then truly deliver on that claim. Here you will create your protagonist and forge a clearer picture of just who they are with every decision they/you make.But they won't be going it alone. A handful of diverse companions will become available as you progress, each with their own agendas and intricacies. The campfire conversations had with this bunch are among the most memorable in the game.The gameplay is also worth noting. The selection of abilities available as characters level up means that two of the same class can be made to suit very different roles, allowing multiple playthroughs to feel genuinely unique. Combat against large numbers of powerful enemies can result in some very satisfying use of the tactical options to achieve victory, particularly in the higher difficulty settings.The story's central conceit -- a shattered kingdom under siege by a great and powerful darkness -- is incredibly well written, and sets up countless opportunities for the protagonist to make defining moral choices. It may not sound particularly imaginative, but BioWare have done a stellar job at making this trite fantasy framework their own.To summarise: Dragon Age: Origins is absolutely not one to miss.

												I just started playing this game again after I got a little bored with Skyrim and Eve Online.Dragon Age: Origins is an amazing game.  It's graphics have withstood the test of time, and the story has a way of still feeling fresh: even though I am playing as an elf rogue, again, the number of choices that affect the outcome make it feel like a completely new experience.  The only real complaint I have is that the camera controls are a little dodgy at times, but this is a minor gripe and it has not deterred me.Bottom line: if you're are currently on a budget and want to experience an amazing RPG with deep lore, strategic combat, and an amazing story, then you should buy this now.  If you are really on a budget, put it on your wishlist and buy it when it is on sale.

For those that dont like to read, plz stop now lol.Will say that other users who commented on the single version DAO are right when they say there is less content in comparison to other old school rpg's. Weapons, clothing, armors are limited but can be compensated through a mod that allows you to craft ur own items. Storyline is great, I have played the game before it came on steam and will say like so many others have played at least over 15 times. The race origins gives a lot of replay value, since certain storyline characters and items can only unlocked through that specific origin. Every origin also contributes a different game ending and influence on the post game world. Many mods available to influence this. Lot of lore to read for those that realy want to get everything out of the story, not as much as in TES4 Oblivion (good god) but still more than enough.One may argue the classes available for choice are limited to only 3 classic classes being: warrior, rogue and mage. Then again this is compensated with specialisations or if you want to translate into d&d language: multiclassing and yes with no pentalty. These classes are sometimes unlocked through relations with companions (regular no romance) and sometimes by purchasing manuals of that class or making certain decissions during the storyline that allow you to obtain said class. U can also choose what type of class u will get through levelling, meaning to say for example: a warrior u can choose to invest in two handed skills,  sword and shield skills and supportive skills, allowing u to build the type of character u want. Also the same with companions so u can shape ur party just the way u like it.Once again, lot of replay value.Storyline is pretty much rpg classic, first starting out not knowing what is happening, struggling through the story halfway, getting better, and in the end be the hero and save everything. Great storyline with almost every classic element you could wish for. This being a game that unlike many others, combines graphics and a good story line. Battlesystem in the early going can be a lil confusing but if you have played these type of games before, no sweat. For everyone something, storyquest about mages, elves, dwarves, the holy grail (has other name in game), and the corruptive nature of men, could have been LOTR if that hadnt come out sooner.Character companions are also very varied, going from those with noble origins to common crooks and murders, drunk warriors and a stoic giant who just likes to be sarcastic and put everyone down. Good thing is that they have written these characters in a way that any player can certainly recognise one self with fragments of those characters' story. Every companion also has a personal quest that allows the player to greatly enhance their relation with said companion. Other ways are to give them presents. With higher relations comes that companions get a specific bonus to their stats. (for example, +strentgh for warrior, +willpower for mage, and so on.)Few bugs that remain unsolved with certain side quests but those can easily be undone, plenty of reading material on the net on those right now.Awakening: good storyline once again allthough I will say that it is somewhat short in comparison to the original campaign. To say when it launched: they stated that origins would give the player over 70 - 80 hours in game to complete, in comparison Awakening was announced as having a even larger amount of space to explore then the original but with only between 20 - 30 hours of game time to complete, they may have run a lil short on that one, but in the end is it worth it? Oh yes. Is launched in game as a separate campaingn so doesnt go along with the main campaign, but like the main campaign also has an epilogue showing the result of the player choices made during his/her progress. New things, few new materials, few new companions, and guess what you become senechal (local lord) of your own keep and can judge people (comes back in DA Inquistion, spoiler).The rest of the dlc in short:Return to ostagar: adds background story and closure for the Alistair companion of the main campaign.Leliana's song: gives u a backgroundstory on the Leliana companion of the main campaign.Witchhunt: give prequel story to what Morrigan has possibly planned for the events in DA Inquisition(spoiler)Stone Prisoner: Gives u an additional companion through a short storyline (comparable to Zaeed in ME2 or Jarvik in ME3)Golems of Amgarrak: Dwarven history (lotr compare, in the end balrog like battle) and for me the hardest to play, lot of puzzles and difficult battles.Warden's Keep: Discover the sinister origins of a merchant family and in the process claim a castle for urself to enjoy. Darkspawn Chronicles: Play as the enemy, invade, pillage, burn...leave none alive.In short (ironic I know): Is it worth getting, no question, eventhough it has a few flaws here and there ramaining, everything else you get more then compensates for it. And for me one of the best rpg's I have ever played. Will certainly not dissapoint.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
   My Playthrough   Youtube Playlist    The Review Dragon Age: Origins as it stands is one of my all time favorite RPGs. This game succeeds at so many points. The game has a great story, setting, gameplay, characters, and mod support. I love the setting of thedas as it has so much potential for stories that can span multiple games. The great characters are what really help this game stands out from other similar RPGs. Every character is memorable, from the companions to the NPCs. Every companion is a 3 dimensional characters. And if you personally dislike a companion you will never find yourself outright hating them. The gameplay is very much like that of Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic which is also a very good game. But the by far best aspect of this game is the story. You can choose from multiple origins, races, and classes. And these choices and the choices made during the main quest makes each playthrough different. This is one of the few games that I played through more then 20 times. The downloadable content add much more hours of gameplay plus with the mod support this game gets even more hours of replay value. This is by far one of the best RPGs I played and I can't recommend it enough.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												This is easily one of my favorite games of all time. The plot is completely fascinating, the characters feel like real people, and your choices will have far-reaching consequences. Sometimes doing the right thing is not the best option, which is why this game can be absolutely visceral. The graphics are a bit dated, but with some artful modding (and there are some fantastic mods out there) and a little imagination, this game is a true adventure.The sheer size of this game is startling. Not in maps (of which there are plenty), but in depth. The characters all have fascinating backstories, but the world itself is what truly shines. The codexes in this are nearly an art form. This is a living, breathing world, where religion, politics, and simple humanity are the most beautiful and poignant characters, rather than the companions that walk with you.
