content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												This is less a review of Origins by itself, and more a review of the Dragon age Series as a whole.  Heavily opinionated and spoilers ahead, so be warned.If you like D&D style fights with an element of chance, and overcoming pitted battles with a tactical mindset, then Dragon Age: Origins is for you.  There are a few exploits here and there, but this game glitters like a ruby among RPGs released within the last few years.  I Just wish Inquisition was available through steam.  (And that it was more like DA:O.  It's got the hallmark sins of modern RPGs being too damn flashy.  This is supposed to be a Western RPG series, not a JRPG series.)And don't waste your energy on DA2.  It's a mess.  Watch a playthrough instead, you will get to experience a decent story without having to sit through gameplay that's trash comppared to DA:O.All top-down tactical RPGs should emulate Origins, I hope the next Dragon Age game takes cues from the Witcher and backs off from the cartoony flashy power activation nonsense that belongs in WoW and JRPGs. The series needs to get back in touch with its dark fantasy roots. I don't care if people think its gross or offensive.  Don't let trying to be politically correct limit you creatively  Perfectionism is the enemy of creativity, and trying to make a perfect game that pleases everyone will just land you with something dull and fangless.The Darkspawn in Inquisition were like boring zombies...While the Darkspawn in THIS game are like horrible scabby mutants with mouths full of corroded pointy snake teeth.  Their faces permanently twisted into manic grins of madness, gibbering in their gutteral and violent tongue.You're doing something wrong when your race of subterranean♥♥♥♥♥♥orcs comes off as boring and inoffensive.  They NEED to be disgusting, they NEED to be cruel in order for a player to feel invested in going in and seeking every little pocket of darkspawn lurking in the shadows.  Each kill is a small victory, each Hurlocke beheaded is a dwarven woman that doesn't need to suffer mutation and mutilation at the hands of darkspawn captors, each Ogre slaughtered is a caravan of soldiers that gets to go home to their families alive and not in boxes of bloodied paste.Recapture 30% of that, and Dragon age 4 will be a hit.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
Very quick review:Well worth the money for a memorable RPG that can be played in so many ways. Fulfilling, funny, and completely engaging from start to finish. Minor flaws are forgivable and ignorable for the most part. Absolutely brilliant.Slightly less quick review:Pros:+ Overall gameplay is fantastic – flaws are not overly bothersome.+ Main storyline is excellent – very satisfying and great value for money in terms of length, involvement, and balance of fetch-type quests vs more intricate jobs.+ Side quests are interesting and don’t feel like chores.+ Character development is perfect – you’ll want to do those side quests!+ Customisation: great choice of unique starting points and character builds makes for unrivalled replay value.+ Incredible writing. Draws you in from the very start with whichever character build and story you’ve chosen and is genuinely hilarious at times.+ Voice acting is fantastic.+ Well-developed and immersive world build and lore, but not boring.+ Decisions actually matter.+ Great soundtrack.+ Good mod support.Cons: - Graphics are a bit outdated – high settings or a couple of mods can help, but it’s not horrendous.- Combat mechanics aren’t perfect – a bit slow at times and it takes some getting used to.- You might cry a bit.- You might also laugh till you pee a little. Down to business:Just as a starter, I adore this game. It’s one of my all-time favourites. The DA franchise is amazing, and although Origins is no spring chicken, it has aged well. On higher settings the game still has spectacular moments, graphically speaking, and the mid-low range settings are playable and artistically enjoyable, although not the best by any means. But you won’t care. At all.If you’re looking for an entertaining, fulfilling, thoroughly immersive RPG with brilliant writing and touching character development, grab this. As someone who has also read the Dragon Age novels because she was desperate for more, I can tell you the world build is incredible – the lore is well structured, believable, and gripping. But for those of you who don’t want to read codex or journal entries, with this, you really don’t need to – you’ll be drawn in by the game itself, which expertly takes you through a robust storyline and gives you just the right amount of info to keep you interested without being boring or overwhelming.Your companions will give you feels. Some you’ll hate, some will make you laugh, and some you’ll go full Hulk mode to protect.As far as mechanics go, it’s not perfect – combat is a little slow and clunky at times, and it can take a little while to get used to. The multitude of tactical options and talent customisations available may be a little overwhelming to start with, especially if you’re not used to RPG builds. However, this is more than compensated for. Put simply, you can play whichever way you want. If you enjoy micromanaging and tactical play, the game deals very well with this. If you’d rather be more hands-on, or a mixture of both, go ahead – the AI is pretty good at letting your party get on with it while you smash some darkspawn skulls in with a sword as long as your own body, or go full mage-rage and burn someone to a crisp. As for your actual character – the game does the (mostly) silent protagonist thing very well. It takes nothing away from the enjoyment of this game. The voice acting as a whole is excellent – very believable, very natural, and the right amount of comic relief vs. dramatic, feel-inducing bits. It’s all very epic but not over-acted.The story customisation is second to none. At the start of the game, you can build your male or female character from scratch (or just use the presets) – human, elf, or dwarf; warrior, rogue or mage; noble or bottom of the pile - these options DO make a huge difference to the story. Replay value is amazing. You basically have multiple different games, and the choices you make as you progress shape the world around you as you deal with the Blight. As far as DLC goes, Awakening is brilliant. You can take your story and character forward from the ending of Origins itself, or you can create another new one! It’s another good chunk of gameplay, with fantastic characters and plenty more to do. The other extras are great value too – not to spoil anything, they’re perfect for those wanting a little more from certain characters, and are well worth the play time. Moving forward to DA:2, you can take your Origins story along with you – yay for transferrable save files! Or you can custom-build a story if you weren’t exactly happy with your Origins playthrough and can’t be arsed to do another one. What more could you want?Overall, DA:O is one of the best RPGs I’ve played to date. The characters, the world, and the general gameplay are too much fun to be dented by the flaws in mechanics. It’s something I will happily replay over and over again.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Dragon Age: Origins is a great game, and the Ultimate Edition is the way to go as it includes every single piece of DLC released for the game. Everybody raves about this game, but rarely are the shortcomings addressed:- Animations are dull and stiff (during both combat and dialogue)- Character models have only a few different variations, (so you'll see the same haircuts etc. over and over again) - The overall story arc is rather generic, (hey, you're the hero, go collect everyone and prepare for a final battle)- Depending on what classes you play as, combat can be mind numbingly slow and weak (in particular for any ranged spec rogue, or sword/shield spec warrior)- The world is kind of presented in a rather dull manner- Several bugs (lots of crashing in Origins, and many other technical ones in Awakening)Most of these issues can be ignored because of the other great content in the game. There are some intriguing side quests, interesting companion characters, tough decisions, there's loads replayability and the lore is really deep and well written. For me personally, most of the issues are fixed in Dragon Age II (though that game also brings forward some new issues...)Overall, it's still a great game, I'd give it a flat 8.0/10. But again, for all the praise it gets, it's flaws are never talked about.

Posted: August 31, 2013
												Grab your sword and shield because we're going on an adventure, First stop, Being born. Then we're off to fight rats in the kitchen, find your trusty mutt who turns out to be smarter than everyone else in the kingdom, seduce a visiting princess and head to bed where you're awoken by a siege to your castle. The rest of the game is a trudge across a wonderfully bland landscape dotted here and there by complete nonsense quests like Explore the dangerous swamp until you meet a sexy teenage witch who doesn't turn you into a frog. Kill ten gnolls along the way.Racist stereotypes abound, as the only intentionally attractive male character has blonde hair and blue eyes and casts snarky comments the entire adventure, and you're introduced to the party's only black character by finding him naked, shackled in a cage and saying he belongs there. You have the option to free him and bring him as a servant if you go through a complicated back'n'forth with the village leader, who hates dark skin. But in all seriousness this game is pretty chill, it's a 100+ hour modern day Baldur's Gate with decent characters, so if you're looking for another Baldur's Gate fix and don't have ADD you should consider this.Mods that are must haves:Advanced TacticsCharacter Respec ModDetailed TooltipsMadd Gift Guide + AwakeningMorrigan 3.3 and Leliana 2.8 (their default faces are fugly)No Helmet Hack + Awakening (not a single good looking helm in this game)Pretty Faces (NPC faces are fugly)Skip the Fade Manual (don't even question this, this lets you skip the ♥♥♥♥♥iest part of the game)Storage Chest (an official mod by a dev, that wasn't but into the game...)Unlock 25 Tactic Slots Extendedv2 No more Snarling (shuts that damn dog up at the camp)

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												Crashes and Freezes abound in this game. I remember having problems when originally trying to play the game in 2009 and for some reason it's worse with modern day (2014) hardware.That aside, DA is a classic. A quick history: BioWare originally gained fame by creating isometric tactical RPGs in the Dungeons and Dragons (Forgotten Realms) setting. I never looked this up, but my guess is that some suit at Hasbro wasn't able to continue that relationship with BioWare (and ultimately Electronic Arts) and so they created their own setting to create a franchise around at or around which became the Dragon Age universe.In contrast to the High Fantasy themes of Forgotten Realms, the campaign setting of Dragon Age is more Low Fantasy or Dark Fantasy. Magic is to be feared, the mood is dark and gritty, you are surrounded by despair and (to some degree) magic items are a little rare. Also in contrast to any D&D setting, characters do not seem to have direct relationships with gods (or Gods) and do not attain magical powers (i.e. healing) from them. In other words, there are healing schools in magic and no clerics.Differences in the campaign aside, DA is EXACTLY what you would expect from a BioWare game. You have exactly the same viewpoint and controls as seen in Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, and Neverwinter. Interactions with NPCs and companions is exactly as you would see in Mass Effect (which is the natural extension of the previously mentioned games).Lots of replay value is inherent with the different starting areas, different ways in which to approach quests and companions and multiple side quests. However, not NEARLY as much open endness within the world if you are to compare to a Bethesda, Elder Scrolls game. Multiple mods exist to enhance the game as well (check Nexus Mods)DA is a classic RPG. Whether you like it or not, however, depends on your style of RPG. Obviously it's a single player game. It's not a JRPG. It's not as open as Elder Scrolls. Tactics are of moderate importance within encounters. Lots of scripted (voice acted) dialogue with NPCs with 'some' variation, but in the end moderately rail-roaded.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2015
												Dragon Age Origins: Ultimate EditionPositives:+ This game is a tactical based RPG, requiring frequent pauses in combat to issue party orders. Each class has unique strengths and weaknesses, mages, rogues and warriors alike all contribute something special to the battles. The game itself is very challenging but satisfying and fun at the same time.+ Rogues can learn the art of dual wielding and typically fit in as party DPSER, while Mages have access to a plethora of spells, from aoe and single target disables, to healing, revivals, nuke damage and more. Warriors can inflict savage damage with two handed weapons or tank enemies with a shield and armour.+ The dialogue and story in Dragons Age Origins: Ultimate Edition is amazing. Bioware are well known for their fantastic storytelling and this game is no exception. There are memorable characters who you can build friendships with and complete quests for. Romance is also an option. The main plot is well thought-out and maintains your interest. +There's a large number of side quests to complete, around 120 hours of content in total with the expansions. Plenty of moral decision making which impacts on the story progression too.+ Lots of random event encounters, with forests, temples and ancient ruins to explore, along with several cities.Mixed:~ For 2009 the graphics are not the best, but by no means are they terrible. This is definitely no reason to avoid the game.Negatives:- Some redundant skills, like trap making or survival, that don't seem to serve any useful purpose.Overall Score 9/10Dragons Age Origins: Ultimate Edition is a really solid game in pretty much every respect. Well worth purchasing on sale for $10 or less. In fact, many digital distributors are offering this price daily, so don't miss out.

content:
Posted: January 19
												Recommended, but only with reservations.It doesn't run completely stable. I've had it crash several times when opening the party's inventory screen directly after a larger fight in the city of Denerim. Other players have had similar crashes years ago already. The Wiki mentions various bugs in quests and other parts of the game.The game's playtime is long enough, if it's your first playthrough without following any guides/walkthroughs. If you want to rush through the game a single time, note that some guides are controversial.The game's is easy enough at "Normal" difficulty, and even more so, if you don't mind reloading an older save from time to time. Such as when you've found out something that's not explained in the manual.The included manual only gives a very sketchy picture of how everything works. Don't expect to find any maths in there. Searching the Wiki and discussion forums will be needed, if you're interested in details, such as how exactly an attribute influences a skill's efficiency.Combat is very repetitive, especially since the party's size is limited to your player character and only three NPC companions, which you control. Companions, which you remove from the party, remain available at the party's camp site till the end of the game. I think the skill/talent tree has been dumbed down pretty much. The variety of enemies could be much greater.It is not an open world. Quest locations on the overview map get added/removed as you progress through the game. The quest areas themselves often are very restricted, and even in the wilderness you can only move through an area on predefined paths and not move freely.In some parts of the game you enter meta-gaming hell. Such as an ambiguous answer during conversation leading to an immediate and unexpected ambush of a potential companion, because that's how some of the conversation trees have been designed. Reload and avoid the WTF-moment. Or one of your long-time companions, who has been with you almost since the beginning and  calls you a friend, leaves permanently before the last few endgame fights just because the game only offers two story-driven choices for taking either the evil or good path. Or merchants at various stages of the game, who offer unlimited supplies of some very important crafting materials or a recipe you need. Once you've gained such meta-gaming knowledge, the real planning can start. Or else the potential for multiple playthroughs would be low.If you only want to do a single playthrough, the game is entertaining enough for sure. Its beginning varies in quality. Don't quit in rage early. The middle and end are better. The voice acting is fine, but sometimes a bit silly (they couldn't resist adding crap when you select a companion). And there are lots of cutscenes that add to the atmosphere.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2011
												English------------Deutsch"We now have a dog and Alistair is still the dumbest one in the party."Dragon Age: Origins is a very intricate and detailed rpg in a medieval scenario, alongside Mass Effect a brilliant game made by Bioware. Could listen to the "Main Theme" by Inon Zur over and over again.++ three different races, each having different origin stories++ great amount of content and exciting main and sidequests++ gorgeous companions with their own companion quests and interesting background information++ brilliant dialogues, in almost every situation companions wants to talk with you about it++ hilarious party banter (my favorites: Alistair and Morrigan, or everything with Shale)++ amazing and sort of melancholic soundtrack++ tactical gameplay and various difficulties-- extremely awkward romance scenes (even worse with mods)-----------------------------------------------------------------------"We now have a dog and Alistair is still the dumbest one in the party."Dragon Age: Origins ist ein sehr detailiertes und komplexes RPG in einem mittelalterlichen Szenario, neben Mass Effect ein weiteres brilliantes Spiel von Bioware. Ich könnte mir das Lied "Main Theme" von Inon Zur aus dem Hauptmenü immer und immer wieder anhören.++ drei verschiedene Rassen, jede mit ihrer eigenen Herkunftsgeschichte++ sehr viel Kontent, spannende Haupt und Nebenquests++ großartige Begleiter mit ihren eigenen Begleiterquests und interessanten Hintergrundinformationen++ brilliante Dialoge, nach vielen Entscheidungen oder in bestimmten Situationen möchte ein Begleiter mit dir darüber sprechen++ extrem lustige Zickereien unter den verschiedenen Begleitern (Alistair und Morrigan, oder einfach Shale sind meine Favoriten)++ wundervoller und stellenweise sehr melancholischer Soundtrack++ taktisches Gameplay und mehrere Schwierigkeitsgrade-- extrem merkwürdige "Liebes"szenen (noch schlimmer mit Mods)

content:
Posted: December 30, 2012
												My favorite RPG of all time.  You manage a whole team of characters and choose 4 to venture out with to complete quests and explore.  You actually have to use tactics and correct positioning to succeed which really makes the environment you fight in extremely important (leeroy jenkins tatics do not apply).  Lots of customization in terms of character abilities (multiple advanced classes to choose from) and armors/weapons to wear.  You can also change up your team compisition to create new and exciting gameplay options.  The story is not the greatest but does feel epic at times, the gameplay is what makes this game so good.  Seriously, buy this ♥♥♥♥ing game... you will not regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Dragon Age: Origins is a massive fantasy rpg that is bound to suck you in with its amazing story and complex characters. Bioware really hit it out of the park with this one. If you have played games made by Bioware in the past, Mass Effect and Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic. You will feel right at home here. Dragon Age will have your heart and make you care for the world and everything within. The game truly makes you believe all of your decions matter and you're making a big difference. Before you even begin the game you will be prompted to pick and choose your race (Human, Dwarf or Elf) with each one having their own unique starting adventure. The game also does a nice job of giving you special dialouge options depending on your race. With so many possible paths you can take in the game, the replayability is through the roof. In my opinion, where Bioware absolutely slam dunked, Morrigan! The romance options in this game was the icing on the cake for me. Never have i ever seen it done more masterfully. At one point, i had to set the game down for a little bit and seriously ponder just which female follower i wanted to pursue a reltionship with. If you have never had the chance to play this game, i highly recommend it. Now, Pros and Cons.Pros-Story-Characters-Dialouge options-Voice Acting-Soundtrack-Replay Value-Combat/Spells-MORRIGAN!!!!Cons-Lack of random loot-No exploration-The Fade

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												DA: Origins won me over with the different introductions for each of the classes and the way you are treated depending on your origin story throught the game. The atmosphere is great, character interaction is superb and the story makes you want to progress. It can get a bit 'samey' from time to time but this game is a true gem and takes me back to the glory days of isometric RPG's. Not to mention the game is good to look at and runs on mid range hardware without a problem.   I was pleasantly suprised at how well balanced the combat and levelling systems were. I got a real kick out of playing the mage, no 1 spell overwhelmed all enemies in a single casting which kept the magic system interesting. I'll generally play warrior classes in RPG's, the reason being is in the late game combat usually presents a more of a challenge for fighters over spell casters that can blast or summon their way to easy victories. However, in DA:O if you didn't tactically use you mage and support charaters there is a real danger of losing story significant battles, it's almost a shame that you're forced to reload it would have been nice to see a consequence. I highly recommend this game and you'll really miss the care and true attention to detail this game has, should you play the sequel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												As a relatively 'new-'ish gamer, this was the first game I properly got into on the PC, and is the game of all games in my opinion. Less said about its sequel the better, the first Dragon Age has an engrossing storyline and a really good tactical system which you can make full use of in order to avoid the norm of idiotic AI getting in your way during a fight. Admittedly the graphics are not the best out there anymore considering we're now in 2014, but they still work well with the overall feel of the game. I am not ashamed to say I've revisited this game loads of times now and still love it. This is an amazing game: if you haven't already bought this and played it, go do it now!

The fighting can be interesting especially as a mage because you can combine spells and have different effects. For example, putting down grease and using a flame spell to create a giant grease fire. You can also build relationships with your companions and romance one or more. Many of the choices you make will carry on and have some sort of effect in the second and third installment of Dragon Age.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Dragon Age: Origins stands as one of the most memorable rpg experiences I've ever had. Memorable because it does something that too many games nowadays don't do. It invests you into the story. Your choices influence the way a lot of story elements pan out. Sure the game follows a fairly defined progression but it is your choices that influence the way certain characters react during that progression. And while it might seem trivial, in reading, it can impose a very broad spectrum of emotional connections with the characters in your party. If you haven't played Dragon Age: Origins you're seriously cutting yourself out from a fantastic experience. This is not your generic Jrpg. This is a powerful epic that spins multiple perspectives on race inequality, the meaning of life, the essence of good vs evil in the eternal struggle for moral/ethical definition of a corrupting world, and theological/mystical affluence.Don't deny yourself one of the greatest RPG experiences ever created. Get Dragon Age: Origins as soon as you can and let yourself be moved by a true masterpiece.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 21, 2014
												I got this 'Ultimate Edition' for £5... Possibly the best money I have ever spent!I have around 26 hours on record so far and have not even scratched the surface. I had played Dragon Age 2 on console and no idea that this bargain would be by far superior to it's sequel. Depth, lots and lots of depth. Voice acting, for the most part, is superb. Every companion has bags of personality (for better or worse), the storyline is gripping without making you feel like you should rush through the main quests, environments have obviously been lovingly created to the point where it feels like you're in a world that's had as much TLC as one created by Tolkien himself.All of this and I'm 13% of the way to completing the game... It's going to be a good ride :) MUST BUY!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												*possible spoiler alerts!*Dragon Age... Dragon Age... Dragon Age... Where to begin? Well this game was made in 2009 (I think), so giving that it's around 4-5 years old, It's pretty fun to play. The main story is not only vast, but intense as you're protecting the realm, nay the human population from the inevitable Blight as the ever popular hero among the 'Grey Wardens'.The combat system isn't too shabby, and the leveling up system (Skill tree) is pretty neat also. The main thing which does it for me however (like the Mass Effect series), is the dialogue. You can even level up your coercion skill which provides 'intimidate' and 'persuade' options during dialogue cutscenes. Along with the fact that the campaign is amazing, there are HUNDREDS of side quests (as expected) to achieve!Now so far, this review has been based upon 'Dragon Age: Origins', yet I feel I should also take a moment to talk about it's expansion 'Awakening'... Other than additional DLC for this game (Wardens Keep, The Stone Prisoner etc) Dragon Age: Awakening opens up yet another vast campaign which continues from 'Origins'. This places your main character (which can be imported over from a previous save, or created from level 20) into what becomes Vigils Keep, the home of the Grey Wardens. You soon discover that although the Blight has been prevented and the Archdemon killed, Darkspawn are still at large and taking orders from someone, or something...Cutting this review short, whether you buy this game (preferably the Ultimate Edition with all DLCs) in a sale or not, you will not be disappointed.You will however, be disappointed if you play Dragon Age 2, which I will not get started on...Overall, 8-9 / 10!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												I finally decided to give this game a whirl & I'm glad I did.It's tons of fun & there are so many different ways you can play it since the story branches depending on your conversations & choices.You can also enable a developer console to enter console commands by editing C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\SteamApps\common\Dragon Age Ultimate Edition\data\DAOriginsLauncher.xmlJust replace the line<true action="execute" file="${BINARIES_DIR}\DAOrigins.exe" path="${BINARIES_DIR}" autoquit="true" />with<true action="execute" file="${BINARIES_DIR}\DAOrigins.exe" path="${BINARIES_DIR}" autoquit="true" arguments="-enabledeveloperconsole" />___________________________________________________________NOTE: Some guides I found had the arguments="-enabledeveloperconsole"  before autoquit="true", but that didn't work for me.  A guide on steam listed it after and when I tried that it worked.___________________Then edit your Documents\BioWare\Dragon Age\Settings\KeyBindings.iniand change the OpenConsole_0 line to something else, for exampleOpenConsole_0=Keyboard::Button_F7So when you press F7 it will open the developer console.___________________Then you can do all kinds of things with the developer console; like god mode, add any amount of money or skill points, jump to any point in the game, add or remove characters, etc.. There's a list of the commands you can use if you scroll down a bit on the wikihttp://dragonage.wikia.com/wiki/Console_%28Origins%29#If you do this, make sure to use the mod to make the commands visable while you type them.  It's a lot easier that way.http://www.nexusmods.com/dragonage/mods/1110/

												If you're like me and like to complete games in order and are considering playing this before Dragon Age: Inquisition, do it!!!I can't believe how much I loved this game! number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Possibly the best game I've ever played. It has some bugs so some missions cannot be finished, and the UI and controls take some getting used to, Also, the learning curve is quite steep so you need to level your characters carefully and plan ahead. But the atmosphere more than makes up for any problems/glitches I have found. I have really felt like being part of the story all along the way. The characters and their background stories are great, voice acting is superb (in particular Claudia Black and Geraldine Blecker). And the whole game has an incredible sense of humor: I spent long hours playing the jailbreak scene over and over again to see the various plotlines for that part as well as tried different groups of companions to hear the different ways the characters mock each other.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												+/+ Complex and engaging battle mechanics.+/+ Some very memorable characters & locations.+/+ Good number of side quests and a lengthy (30+ hour) main story.+/+ Solid graphics and sound effects.+/+ Multiple options for character builds and good/evil choices.+/+ Multiple difficulty options.+/+ Various PC options (rebindable keys, multiple graphic settings, etc.).+/- Voice acting varies dramatically throughout the game.-/- Orzammar (Dwarven location) is poorly designed.-/- Not all dialog options have a real or noticeable impact.-/- Some backtracking is required.-/- Lacking steam features (achievements, cloud, workshop, etc.) – to be fair, this game was released before these features were integrated into steam.Verdict: 8.5/10.  Dragon Age is a very well-constructed RPG. I would easily recommend it to fans of the genre.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Great game series. I enjoyed the hours of gameplay, the depth of story, and also complexity of the overall mythos of Dragon Age and all its DLC. This game had just the right blend of character, fighting, class systems, story, and humor. On top of your own storyline, there are plenty of characters peppered into your party that have their own storys and quests that you may pursue if you like. As with any good RPG, you get complete control of your characters background, apperance, and fighting style. I played through the first half of the game 3 times before I finally settled on an female elf rogue build. The quests are pretty straight forward in most cases, nothing incredibly challening or puzzling...but the fights are brutal. Unless you play on easy, be prepared to die a lot. Not a problem really when you can pretty much save game whenever you like. I've always liked the combat pause function in games like SW:KOTL and again it works well here giving your party time to plan its next spell or attack. The combat itself is varied, and there are quite a few different builds you can acheive with race, class, and specializations. The spell system is follows suite, its diverse and rife with ways to achieve mage dominance. Only downfall for me was a few crashes when the spells and fighting really got hectic. I attribute it to my lack of resources on my PC, but was still frustrating enough it bears mentioning. 9 out 10. Fun to play, hours of content.

content:

												Overall, Dragon Age: Origins is a very diverse game. After completing my first playthough in around 60 hours, I began my second run through the game, and had a completely different experience. content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												Originally bought this game for PS3 when it came out and played it ALOT so the hours i sank into it don't match up in Steam.I bought it because of the epic CGI trailers that spawned in between TV commercials (weird that they aren't on the store page) and bought it in a whimp without knowing what i was getting myself into. So, when i started playing i was like "WTF is this ****"? ugly graphics (compared to it's trailer counterpart that is) and weird gameplay (didn't check the box for info. I just dived into it). But i kept going because of the story and setting. I literally played hours smashing buttons when i was in battle and thinking what crappy unresponsive combat it was :DAfter +- 3 hours i noticed you had to trigger combat by pressing a button "ones" (auto-attack) and select the appropriate skills when needed. I was like "mehh" and yet i still kept playing and then it slowly started to grow on me. When i was like half-game i was addicted! I couldn't stop playing (micro managing tougher battles! hell yeah!) and days turned into nights in a heartbeat! What voodoo trickery is this! So yeah, it was hard getting into it mainly because of the visual aspect and there's not really an in-game explenation of the batlle system (for as far as i know i had to figure it all out by myself and not being into Tactical RPG it took a long time), but story, gameplay and setting (medieval fantasy) made me forget that. And best of all... some characters you meet in this game are so loveable and if not worst; are truely missed in the next installments (besides some small cameo's) :( This game got me truely into RPG games (if you don't count "Wonder Boy In Monsterworld" xD )Bought it again for PC so i can mod it!Dragon Age: Origins get's 10 hearts!*crappy review i know :p

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												The Story: It is amazing for this game. Well thought and well Detailed. Spread over the whole map. The main story line is amazing it drags you in from the get go. Straight to the end of the game. The side quests are great to again all over the map. Certainly gives you that extra bit to work on even if it only gives a little extra bit of game play. Even with character stories to. Some meld together. Even the interaction talks while wondering about. It all works together perfectly.The Detail: Tones in my book. Just perfect for a long RPG. Which is what it should be. Certainly a lot to read to give you more detail and draw you into the game world. Which it should. Cause that moment you start to play it should drag you in which it dose with this. Many might say that tones of reading is boring. But this is always a key point to good RPG. No way you could have some one just speak it all out. Some might say that would be better some would say not. Hence why having both in it. Is much better. The detailed conversations from the characters and npc's down to the codex notes which give you information.The Graphics: Perfect and still now perfect in my books for an RPG like this one. The Characters are life like, even in the cinematic's. The towns and Cities are well detailed and work with the time period of the game. The npc's and even the animals. The darkness in it work even well better for game and story. Some might say it dose not. But I beg to differ.The Music: It is great. It enhances the game amazingly, drawing you into the game even more. So much work put into it, It is certainly one of the things I love in this game. Nothing more I can say. Watch this video about the music. LinkThe Reply Value: The reply value of this game. Is great to reply as the other classes certainly makes it worth while indeed. Even go different ways with them in the sense of character. Yes there is mods out there you can use to further enhance that. But on just the game it is perfect. It is certainly one game I will reply many times out of my large and I use that loosely game collection.Overall: This game is one all you RPG players should certainly have. Graphics, story, Detail. Everything works perfectly for this game. I give this 100% and 10/10StrangleholdStory: This is a Classic style story/plot. Cop go's missing and it ends up the kidnappers want one cop to come with a ransom. But as usual Cop boss dose not want to. But you Tequila end up going to do it yourself. This is what I like Defiance against bosses to go get the job done! There is definitely some interesting story lines to this game. Even at the start you see kidnapping like I have said but just not the cop. There is love and secrets to. Heck I even found some bits in funny.The Detail: There is some good detail in this game via the in game film scenes. Bring more to the story as it unfolds. There is no in-depth reading in the game. Like in some others but again this is more of Shoot first and ask questions later.The Graphics: The graphics are good to a point for now. Yes there is some limitations to it. But it stills holds it own as an HD Game. Explosions from barrels lighting up the screen. Gives me tingles all the time. Even seeing the movement waves from the bullet being fired in precision fire mode. Button number 2 on your controls which I will go into in a sec. Enemies are generic like most reviewers have said and I agree. All in all the graphics are good for this game in my books. They could be much better but. I cant really Truly match this game to todays games for graphics. I put it down to your judgment.Game play: What can I say. Controls are nice and easy to master. No messing around. Jumping in any direction or interacting with any object. I found that fun sliding accross the table and down hand rails shooting people in the awesome slow motion mode. This is called Tequila Time. Now in my mind Tequila time points to Alcohol but I digress. There is some other modes you use to. First one is Health Boost. Which is just like a First aid pack. Second is Precision Aiming which I love. When you get it right you see the kill cam. Perfect kills or even just to injure so you can get up and just pummel in a whole clip just to be evil. Third is Barrage one of the most potent modes. 20 seconds of enhanced firepower and invulnerability ripping through the environment. Lastly the Spin firing with stunning accuracy in a circle. I tend not to use this one. As I like getting up and close. Its still nice to use.The Music: THe music is good. It fits the game and game play. But if your like me with shooting games you might turn the music off and play your own.The Reply Value: Now replay value. Yeah there is reply value but since the game is long it might be more of a time filler between the games your waiting for to come out. But if you like countless shooting then yeah there is replay value.Overall: Overall this game packs an interesting classic story. Countless fighting good graphics and music and replay value even if its just to fill space. Defo worth the play. It captures John Woo movies into a game. I give this 9/10. As much as I want to give a full 10/10 even tho its got help from John Woo. I cant there is still room for improvement that can be done.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Honestly, this is that one game that I keep coming back for. I've always been a sucker for pretty graphic, but honestly, this game needs none of that. It has such well-developed world history and politics that I find deeply fascinating. The characters are endearing, and it's just not possible for you not to feel some sort of affection for them. The main plot is rich, and the side quests can affect the future, either in the end, or the other installments. It makes you want to complete them, and in a way, makes you wonder if you will see these people you have just helped again.Out of three Dragon Age installments, this has to be my favourite because it has this distinctive quality that you don't come across easily in video games.

												Let me start by saying Dragon Age Origins is by far my favorite game!!! <3	Dragon Age Origins Ultimate Edition consists of an interesting combat system, rich story along with DLC to only add to the immersive gameplay experience. Origins has an unique RPG experience with the feel of a true RPG. 	There are many game changing decisions that change the your gameplay! You venture through the magnificent lands of Ferelden with your party at your back. You have the power of choice and with that power you choice the fate of not only your venture but of your party's.	Origin's combat system is something that standout with its unique twist of features that aren't see in many RPGs these days. The combat consist of the many possibilities to pause the game mid fight to make those tactical life saving power moves to save the life of your party!	There is so many features in this game to make it so unique in so many ways that it must be experienced by one's self.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												Oh wow, where should I start? Well first of all this is the third time I've owned the game, first on the Xbox 360, then again on the PS3, and finally on the PC.  Now this game is dated, it came out in 2009, and you can really see it when you play it.  Even cranking the graphics up to max on your pc won't do much to improve the apperance of the game.  However there are quite a few mods out there that tweak the appearance of the game, making it signficantly more pleasant, however I have not seen any total overhaul mod out there.  Do note that there is no Steam workshop for this game, but Nexus does include the Nexus Mod Manager, and has a very large selection of mods available for this game, so definitely check them out once you buy, and install this beast.Now for the meat of things, Dragon Age Origins is the first game in the trilogy, and takes place in Ferelden, the fictional nation inspired largely by medieval England, as the on set of the Fifth Blight encroaches the land.  I do not want to spoil anything, so I'll avoid talking any more about the story, but I feel that at this point in time almost everyone has played this game or at least wikia'd the plot.  This game features the point and click style combat, as in I left click over my oponet and he begins to swing his sword, then I can press one of my hotkeyes for him to use a skill.  Do not come in expecting this to be like DA II or DAI, where you'll be spamming the attack button like a game of Dynasty Warriors.  Fortunately you have regenerating health outside of combat, and mages have a healing branch, something that Bioware took out of DAI, which drove me insane, especially on Hard and Nightmare difficulties.  In this game you'll often find yourself pausing combat so you can survey the battlefield, formulate  a plan, and then issue orders, then unpause to watch your four man/woman team move out. Now I would definitely recommend playing this game on hard at least, to get a real challenge out of things, it definitely makes the game more enjoyable, and I practically live in pause mode/tactical mode.  The mechanics here are amazing, as you travel from area to area, you have a slight ability to explore each of these areas.  Now this is not a free roaming game, well not in the traditional sense at least.  You can control to which 'area' you want to go to, and within each area there is a small degree of exploration involved, but to me that was never important, seeing as how I was so engrossed by the story.  There's plenty of NPC's to talk to, a fair amount of side quests to do, and so much♥♥♥♥♥♥to pick up it isn't even remotely funny.  The Ultimate Edition also comes with all the DLC you could ever want, and the game has for that matter.  So you definitely get your money's worth, especially with the story expansion Awakening installed that (can) continue your journey after the completition of Origins.  Not to mention you have all of the smaller story/mission DLC's to play, that will take up a few hours of your time, answer some of your questions or give you some closure in some of them, as well as net you new items for your main game.  Oh yeah I forgot about the prologue story for Leliana, entitled Leliana's Song, which takes place before Origins, lets you play as Leliana, and also gets you some cool items to use in Origins (especially for Leliana!).  This game is amazing, it has so much content, gameplay is fantastic, the story will keep you hooked and playing until the sun comes back up, and you'll know why this game is the best of the trilogy.  Plus you'll establish such unhealthy connections with some of the characters you might end up getting a body pillo...uh you'll just try to learn everything about them.  Also the game gets better with mods, they're like swear words and spices, it makes things better.  Plus it'll help clean up the appearance of the game a little bit.  Personally I love this game, it's in my top 5 games of all times, and it's better then those other two, and it has a better ending than Mass Effect 3.  This game is a 10/10, you wont find a better game with as much content for this price with access to thousands of mods that make it even better.  Plus it has a story better then the entire Elder Scrolls universe.  Even Commander Shepard would tell you that this is his favorite game on all of Steam, I mean at least believe him, he is the first human SPECTRE, savior of the galaxy, human icon, and an all around great guy.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												Dragons Age is well a put together RPG that will immerse you in the story and you will invest time in developing the characters that accompany you on your quest. The biggest downside to the game is the story is tried, tired and done a thousand times over. You the hero are on quest to destroy the dark spawn that is wreaking havoc on the land. This being its biggest downfall does not make this a bad game at all. I had over 40+ hours in one play through and with all the decision making you encounter this game will surely keep you amused for multiple plays. One of the best combat systems I've seen you can not only setup the AI to have your companions on the quest do what you like but you can fully take control of them which in my opinion is a huge advantage. The combat system is a little bit of learning curve but once you get the hang of it you will love it and enjoy the simpleness of how your characters act and follow your directions in the heat of some best battles you will see in an RPG. Bioware did an excellent job in creating a game you can fully plunge yourself into and get behind.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												I was reluctant to dive into this game for a long time based on the previews I came across when it was first being marketed.  It came off in promotional material as a bro-ish rpg (actiony, poorly simulated sex scenes, apparent LOTR lifting, and yet another  tired save the world plot).  While I wasn't necessarily wrong in my initial views of the game, I was surprised at how deeply engaging the game actually is. This is a party-based roleplaying game.  You can choose from one of three races for your main (Player) character:  Human, Elf or Dwarf.  One of the hallmarks of the game is that there are 5 different "origin" stories for your main character.  So, you can start the game as a City Elf living in the slums of an alienage (Apartheid-like ghetto) or as a Forest-dwelling Dalish Elf living mostly unfettered by human society.  Each of the 5 origin stories acts as a prologue, but once the backstory is established the main game story begins and is the same no matter what origin you chose.  While you begin the game as a lone adventurer, you eventually have up to four active party members.  You get about a dozen or so party-members eventually, but you can only take 3 along with your character when adventuring - the rest wait for you at camp.  The combat, while real-time and of the MMO-style we've come to know with ability cooldowns and gads of useable items, is actually pretty complex tactically.  The combat is real-time, but can be paused to give orders ala Baldur's Gate, and you can take direct control of any party member at any time.  I found many battles that I came across were unwinnable until I changed my tactical approach.  I'm about 100 hours in playing as a City Elf Rogue character.  I found my ideal party generally consists of two mages and a warrior.  My mages act as healers when party member health dips low, while my warrior acts as a threat sponging tank.  I try to get the drop on enemies by either going stealth and doing a sneak-attack backstab to any enemy mages or archers before they notice my party, or by sniping them from the shadows with my bow.  Taking out enemy spellcasters quickly is essential.  Archers are also a deadly threat, especially in groups.  One neat feature is that the game has a built in scripting system for how party members behave in combat that is easy to configure.  Each character begins with some combat tactics slots for you to customize, but as they level they can unlock more tactics slots.  You can have it so a party member will heal another party member should their health be too low, cast a defensive aura on themselves or others when being attacked, or quaf a mana potion when it dips below a specified level.  Every character will use the scripted tactics except for the character you currently have direct control over.Item collection is a staple of any rpg and DAO is no slouch, with lots of unique weapons and armor and a neat item tier system.  For instance, if you find a leather helm when your character is level 2, it'll be tier 1 with lousy stats, but discover that same leather helm when your character is level 15 and it could be tier 5, 6 or 7 and have better stats with each tier level.  This applies to magical items as well.  Also, an item can be forged of different materials and depending on the material used to make it, be better than the same item created with a different material.  For instance, a steel dagger is better than an iron dagger, but a red steel dagger is better than a steel dagger, etc.Character leveling has the typical RPG attributes that govern things like magic, attack damage, resistances, etc.  There are also skill trees for specializations and more skill trees can be unlocked through quests, party interaction, special items...  Leveling characters is both thought-provoking and fun.  Some skills require meeting a stat requirement, but there is otherwise alot of freedom in how to customize each party member. Questing works in the fashion we've come to know, but the dialogue system means that the outcome of a quest can vary greatly.  How you interact in the world with the npcs, how you complete quests, or how you interact with even your own party can all change the course of the game.  For instance, in a conversation you say something to Joe Shmoe the quest-giver that a party member voices an opinion about.  You disregard that party-member's opinion and do what you want.  You might get what you want out of it, but the party member may like you less for it.  Each party member has a scale regarding how they feel about you.  If it dips too low they may leave and never return.  If it climbs you can unlock new abilities like greater constitution for them.  Part of the system is influenced by how you interact with them and part of it is determined by how you interact with the world.  You can also find and buy gifts to give to your party members.  NPC appreciation of you can also unlock romances with certain characters, some of which affect end-game results.The game world is huge and has various environs and biomes.  You'll travel through cities, forests, swamps, snowy mountains, underground tunnels, ancient ruins, ethereal realms, etc...  The game is not open world like the elderscrolls games, but if feels big and there is alot of detail to it.  You can fast travel to places marked on your map.The graphics can be a mixed bag.  Generally, they look very good, great even.  The level of detail in the game world itself is pretty amazing.  Some of the smaller details are sometimes overlooked.  So, while player models and textures all look great, especially close up in in-game cutscenes - some of the smaller details are wanting.  A few textures here and there are noticeably low-rez and some of the world geometry is of lesser quality then others.  It's not a startling difference, and it doesn't detract because it all blends, but graphic ♥♥♥♥♥s will undoubtedly not be satisfied.  There are a few texture mods that touch on this issue, but I wouldn't bother.  The game looks great as is.  Also, there is a memory leak in the game that starts to effect loading time and transitions the longer you play.  One of the larger, more expansive texture mods out there requires a beefy rig and will still crash frequently.  I myself downloaded a minimalist/purist mod that changed 48 textures - only the worst offending low-rez textures.  You can find it here: http://www.nexusmods.com/dragonage/mods/3869/?The music and sounds are all great.  The sound effects of swords clashing, glancing off shields, enemies screaming, and the whizzing of arrows are all spot on.  The attention to sound in each environment is noticeable and it really helps immerse you when you're trumping through a forest hearing wind in the trees, water dripping in caves, or the bustle in the city.  The voice acting is amazing.  Usually, the weakest point of any game is the voice acting, but every voice here is perfect.  And you will hear ALOT of inter-party banter as you travel, plenty of which is whimsical or laugh-out-loud funny.  The story itself is engrossing, but not earth-shattering in originality.  It's the smaller stories you come across as you make your campaign through the main quest that really shine - allowing you a sense of the world and it's inhabitants.  To that end, the history of the world is rich and you can discover hours of reading material within the game that's gets added to your "codex".I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the dungeons & dragons style of rpg gaming.  It is not, however, for the casual gamer.  While it's not as pedantic as 'Temple of Elemental Evil', it's still a game for the more serious roleplayers than those used to FF7 or Zelda.

												I have recently been revisiting this little gem that I once owned on Xbox 360. I wish I'd had the PC version from the start! The controls are so much better, having hotbars to put skills in is great, and the game looks very nice on PC. For those of you who havent played this, or have only played it on Xbox, I'd recommend buying it (on sale right now $7.99). The DLCs are worth the investment, and the game still keeps me captivated even though I've probably beaten it on Xbox 3 or 4 times.Those who haven't played Dragon Age can expect an awesome RPG with tons of character customization, interaction between party members, and of course thrilling and challenging combat. If you liked Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter Nights, and Icewind Dale, this is the type of game for you. (minus the D&D rules, but it still follows the basic recipe for a great party-based RPG.) Definitely a good buy at the price!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												I only have like 20 hours on steam with this game, but on console I have well over 200, and I have beaten origins along with awakening with 6 different characters and my favorite to play with is the mage. Having said all of that, this is easily in my top 5 games of all time. I love the story line and how in depth it can get with desicions, and the desicions actually matter in dragon age, they affect quests, what people (mainly your party) think of you, and change the ending. The combat can be a little slow and clunky at times, but this doesnt really deter me. I prefer the big hot bar of spells and talents to the button mash system that is implemented in many newer RPGs (dragon age 2). If you want hours upon hours of in depth gameplay, in depth and deep if not sometimes tear jerking story, character romance, great boss fights with killer rewards then this is the game for you. I highly reccomend it, and at the price it's at now, it's more than worth it.

content:
Posted: January 5
												Awesome game, and I have more hours on this than on Steam alone; I had played it for a while on the nonsteam version.Pros:+Excellent writing+Excellent voice acting+Excellent in-depth lore like in Mass Effect+Interesting story, albeit somewhat generic in some aspects (but the other aspects of it make up for that I think)+Interesting characters and interactions+Interesting character progression and system of gameplay+Interesting game world overall+Lots of mods available on the Nexus[www.nexusmods.com] (and maybe elsewhere)+Challenging on higher difficulties; some in-depth strategy involved sometimes (Nightmare difficulty on console versions is the same as Hard on the PC; thus, Nightmare difficulty on PC is one step above the highest available on the console)+Great music+Some aspects of the default visuals aren't that bad to today's standardsNeutral:~Visuals are dated to today's standards, the game hasn't aged well in some ways and in some ways it has (there are some mods to help with that).  I have only used one texture pack but there are other mods that improve the visuals.~Some chances to use exploits (more or less) for some fights, but nothing that cheap usually.Cons:-The transition from the end of the Origins campaign to the beginning of the Awakening campaign is not clearly explained in some ways; you will need to prepare your inventory before the end of Origins in order to retain items you want in Awakening.-Major bug involving the Silverite Mine in the Awakening campaign (easily fixed with this mod[www.nexusmods.com] found on the Nexus)

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Possibly the best game I've ever played. It has some bugs so some missions cannot be finished, and the UI and controls take some getting used to, Also, the learning curve is quite steep so you need to level your characters carefully and plan ahead. But the atmosphere more than makes up for any problems/glitches I have found. I have really felt like being part of the story all along the way. The characters and their background stories are great, voice acting is superb (in particular Claudia Black and Geraldine Blecker). And the whole game has an incredible sense of humor: I spent long hours playing the jailbreak scene over and over again to see the various plotlines for that part as well as tried different groups of companions to hear the different ways the characters mock each other.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Great game series. I enjoyed the hours of gameplay, the depth of story, and also complexity of the overall mythos of Dragon Age and all its DLC. This game had just the right blend of character, fighting, class systems, story, and humor. On top of your own storyline, there are plenty of characters peppered into your party that have their own storys and quests that you may pursue if you like. As with any good RPG, you get complete control of your characters background, apperance, and fighting style. I played through the first half of the game 3 times before I finally settled on an female elf rogue build. The quests are pretty straight forward in most cases, nothing incredibly challening or puzzling...but the fights are brutal. Unless you play on easy, be prepared to die a lot. Not a problem really when you can pretty much save game whenever you like. I've always liked the combat pause function in games like SW:KOTL and again it works well here giving your party time to plan its next spell or attack. The combat itself is varied, and there are quite a few different builds you can acheive with race, class, and specializations. The spell system is follows suite, its diverse and rife with ways to achieve mage dominance. Only downfall for me was a few crashes when the spells and fighting really got hectic. I attribute it to my lack of resources on my PC, but was still frustrating enough it bears mentioning. 9 out 10. Fun to play, hours of content.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												I finally decided to give this game a whirl & I'm glad I did.It's tons of fun & there are so many different ways you can play it since the story branches depending on your conversations & choices.You can also enable a developer console to enter console commands by editing C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\SteamApps\common\Dragon Age Ultimate Edition\data\DAOriginsLauncher.xmlJust replace the line<true action="execute" file="${BINARIES_DIR}\DAOrigins.exe" path="${BINARIES_DIR}" autoquit="true" />with<true action="execute" file="${BINARIES_DIR}\DAOrigins.exe" path="${BINARIES_DIR}" autoquit="true" arguments="-enabledeveloperconsole" />___________________________________________________________NOTE: Some guides I found had the arguments="-enabledeveloperconsole"  before autoquit="true", but that didn't work for me.  A guide on steam listed it after and when I tried that it worked.___________________Then edit your Documents\BioWare\Dragon Age\Settings\KeyBindings.iniand change the OpenConsole_0 line to something else, for exampleOpenConsole_0=Keyboard::Button_F7So when you press F7 it will open the developer console.___________________Then you can do all kinds of things with the developer console; like god mode, add any amount of money or skill points, jump to any point in the game, add or remove characters, etc.. There's a list of the commands you can use if you scroll down a bit on the wikihttp://dragonage.wikia.com/wiki/Console_%28Origins%29#If you do this, make sure to use the mod to make the commands visable while you type them.  It's a lot easier that way.http://www.nexusmods.com/dragonage/mods/1110/

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Bioware's entrance to a new serires is by far the best start any company has had, in my opinion. Also in my opinion, the best out of the series as of writing this. (Dragon age 3 is not yet out)Dragon Age is a RPG with a DND feel to it. It's got loads of Weapons and Armour to provide great flexability while also providing a good amount of spells and specializations.It's got detailed companions who act and re-act to the choices you make. They don't just feel like mindless drones following your about because Bioware knows how to make a great character. Just look at the Mass Effect seires. :)The story isn't exactly new to Bioware, but the details are. It fits in perfectly within the fantasy world they've created. Similar to Mass Effect, you will have a lot of choices to make, adding replayability.Dragon Age and Dragon Age Awakening are well supported by the modding community.The game provides great graphical appeal and stability, the DLC are nice for a short respite and the Awekening expansion pack is a proper expansion. Providing a new story, and even allowing your character to cross over into the expansion, complete with your entire inventory.The only negative is that there appears to be a slow memory leak which is most notable lower-end machines. It's not crippling like other games which have a memory leak and is easily setback by re-starting the game every few hours, like when you go get a cup of coffee, or food.I highly recommend Dragon Age if you are a fan of the work the Bioware does, or if you love RPG's. This is definetly one of those games you will remember for quite a long time.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												DA:O is an incredibly fun tactical squad-based RPG. The story is solid and character decisions make a HUGE difference, especially as you can import your save from DA:O into Dragon Age 2, and then into Dragon Age: Inquisition. The gameplay is just as strong, featuring a simple, easy-to-use dialogue system and a robust combat system, replete with AI tactics which can somewhat automate the process of managing 4 characters in a combat environment.TL;DR - If you like RPG games with meaningful player decisions (e.g., not what Skyrim does with meaningless player decisions) and don't mind an over-the-shoulder/bird's-eye-view approach to a tactically-grounded squad-based combat game, then this is the game for you!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												One of my favourite games to date, if not my favourite ever.Dragon Age: Origins allows you to make decisions and interact with NPCs and party members in a way that can get you truly attached to their stories. There are so many tales woven into one wonderful, complete and complex campaign which you can, to a fair extent, influence through your decisions. The combat system is very simple to learn but still can be manipulated to fit your style, and you can make this game as challenging or leisurely as you like it.Not only can I appraise the obvious, but I can also comfortably say that the attention to detail in this game, right down to the little things like the designs on the armour sets, is set to a very high standard.It's abundantly clear how much work was poured into this game. The only flaw I could accentuate would be that the dungeon crawling does get a tad repetitive, but it's necessary, so if you can forsake a hard. gruelling dungeon crawl and you're willing to give up many, many hours of your life, this game comes with my strongest recommendation.

												I have recently been revisiting this little gem that I once owned on Xbox 360. I wish I'd had the PC version from the start! The controls are so much better, having hotbars to put skills in is great, and the game looks very nice on PC. Definitely a good buy at the price!!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												So good that I played it 3 times. My hours don't show it here, but I played the original steam version, then bought a boxed copy of the ultimate edition for cheap and then bought the ultimate edition steam version when it went on sale. Anyway, the game is the true successor to games like Baldur's gate and Neverwinter Nights. It is a fantastic game with strategic combat, where you cant just chuck a fireball wherever you want due to friendly fire. Makes the game much more interesting as it adds a layer of strategy that wouldn't be found otherwise. The game keeps the same pausable real time combat as Baldur's gate and other such CRPG's. The class system, while initially basic, branches out into many sub classes that you unfortunately have to unlock, but they stay unlocked for all future playthroughs.  It's not so bad because it encourages replay value. Most are pretty easy to unlock, but Blood Mage and Arcane Warrior are some of the best classes and are easily missable if you don't know where to look. To get blood mage you must make a deal with a demon in redcliffe as yourself, (You must be a mage to be able to do this) while to get arcane warrior you must find and help an elven phylactery in the elf dungeon. Overall I would highly recommend this game to anyone. This game begs for mutliple playthroughs, and it delivers. One thing I would suggest though is on your second or so playthrough, get a mod to skip the Fade. You will know what I mean when you get to it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22, 2014
												I was reluctant to dive into this game for a long time based on the previews I came across when it was first being marketed.  It came off in promotional material as a bro-ish rpg (actiony, poorly simulated sex scenes, apparent LOTR lifting, and yet another  tired save the world plot).  While I wasn't necessarily wrong in my initial views of the game, I was surprised at how deeply engaging the game actually is. This is a party-based roleplaying game.  You can choose from one of three races for your main (Player) character:  Human, Elf or Dwarf.  One of the hallmarks of the game is that there are 5 different "origin" stories for your main character.  So, you can start the game as a City Elf living in the slums of an alienage (Apartheid-like ghetto) or as a Forest-dwelling Dalish Elf living mostly unfettered by human society.  Each of the 5 origin stories acts as a prologue, but once the backstory is established the main game story begins and is the same no matter what origin you chose.  While you begin the game as a lone adventurer, you eventually have up to four active party members.  You get about a dozen or so party-members eventually, but you can only take 3 along with your character when adventuring - the rest wait for you at camp.  The combat, while real-time and of the MMO-style we've come to know with ability cooldowns and gads of useable items, is actually pretty complex tactically.  The combat is real-time, but can be paused to give orders ala Baldur's Gate, and you can take direct control of any party member at any time.  I found many battles that I came across were unwinnable until I changed my tactical approach.  I'm about 100 hours in playing as a City Elf Rogue character.  I found my ideal party generally consists of two mages and a warrior.  My mages act as healers when party member health dips low, while my warrior acts as a threat sponging tank.  I try to get the drop on enemies by either going stealth and doing a sneak-attack backstab to any enemy mages or archers before they notice my party, or by sniping them from the shadows with my bow.  Taking out enemy spellcasters quickly is essential.  Archers are also a deadly threat, especially in groups.  One neat feature is that the game has a built in scripting system for how party members behave in combat that is easy to configure.  Each character begins with some combat tactics slots for you to customize, but as they level they can unlock more tactics slots.  You can have it so a party member will heal another party member should their health be too low, cast a defensive aura on themselves or others when being attacked, or quaf a mana potion when it dips below a specified level.  Every character will use the scripted tactics except for the character you currently have direct control over.Item collection is a staple of any rpg and DAO is no slouch, with lots of unique weapons and armor and a neat item tier system.  For instance, if you find a leather helm when your character is level 2, it'll be tier 1 with lousy stats, but discover that same leather helm when your character is level 15 and it could be tier 5, 6 or 7 and have better stats with each tier level.  This applies to magical items as well.  Also, an item can be forged of different materials and depending on the material used to make it, be better than the same item created with a different material.  For instance, a steel dagger is better than an iron dagger, but a red steel dagger is better than a steel dagger, etc.Character leveling has the typical RPG attributes that govern things like magic, attack damage, resistances, etc.  There are also skill trees for specializations and more skill trees can be unlocked through quests, party interaction, special items...  Leveling characters is both thought-provoking and fun.  Some skills require meeting a stat requirement, but there is otherwise alot of freedom in how to customize each party member. Questing works in the fashion we've come to know, but the dialogue system means that the outcome of a quest can vary greatly.  How you interact in the world with the npcs, how you complete quests, or how you interact with even your own party can all change the course of the game.  For instance, in a conversation you say something to Joe Shmoe the quest-giver that a party member voices an opinion about.  You disregard that party-member's opinion and do what you want.  You might get what you want out of it, but the party member may like you less for it.  Each party member has a scale regarding how they feel about you.  If it dips too low they may leave and never return.  If it climbs you can unlock new abilities like greater constitution for them.  Part of the system is influenced by how you interact with them and part of it is determined by how you interact with the world.  You can also find and buy gifts to give to your party members.  NPC appreciation of you can also unlock romances with certain characters, some of which affect end-game results.The game world is huge and has various environs and biomes.  You'll travel through cities, forests, swamps, snowy mountains, underground tunnels, ancient ruins, ethereal realms, etc...  The game is not open world like the elderscrolls games, but if feels big and there is alot of detail to it.  You can fast travel to places marked on your map.The graphics can be a mixed bag.  Generally, they look very good, great even.  The level of detail in the game world itself is pretty amazing.  Some of the smaller details are sometimes overlooked.  So, while player models and textures all look great, especially close up in in-game cutscenes - some of the smaller details are wanting.  A few textures here and there are noticeably low-rez and some of the world geometry is of lesser quality then others.  It's not a startling difference, and it doesn't detract because it all blends, but graphic ♥♥♥♥♥s will undoubtedly not be satisfied.  There are a few texture mods that touch on this issue, but I wouldn't bother.  The game looks great as is.  Also, there is a memory leak in the game that starts to effect loading time and transitions the longer you play.  One of the larger, more expansive texture mods out there requires a beefy rig and will still crash frequently.  I myself downloaded a minimalist/purist mod that changed 48 textures - only the worst offending low-rez textures.  You can find it here: http://www.nexusmods.com/dragonage/mods/3869/?The music and sounds are all great.  The sound effects of swords clashing, glancing off shields, enemies screaming, and the whizzing of arrows are all spot on.  The attention to sound in each environment is noticeable and it really helps immerse you when you're trumping through a forest hearing wind in the trees, water dripping in caves, or the bustle in the city.  The voice acting is amazing.  Usually, the weakest point of any game is the voice acting, but every voice here is perfect.  And you will hear ALOT of inter-party banter as you travel, plenty of which is whimsical or laugh-out-loud funny.  The story itself is engrossing, but not earth-shattering in originality.  It's the smaller stories you come across as you make your campaign through the main quest that really shine - allowing you a sense of the world and it's inhabitants.  To that end, the history of the world is rich and you can discover hours of reading material within the game that's gets added to your "codex".I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the dungeons & dragons style of rpg gaming.  It is not, however, for the casual gamer.  While it's not as pedantic as 'Temple of Elemental Evil', it's still a game for the more serious roleplayers than those used to FF7 or Zelda.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												One of my favourite games to date, if not my favourite ever.Dragon Age: Origins allows you to make decisions and interact with NPCs and party members in a way that can get you truly attached to their stories. There are so many tales woven into one wonderful, complete and complex campaign which you can, to a fair extent, influence through your decisions. The combat system is very simple to learn but still can be manipulated to fit your style, and you can make this game as challenging or leisurely as you like it.Not only can I appraise the obvious, but I can also comfortably say that the attention to detail in this game, right down to the little things like the designs on the armour sets, is set to a very high standard.It's abundantly clear how much work was poured into this game. The only flaw I could accentuate would be that the dungeon crawling does get a tad repetitive, but it's necessary, so if you can forsake a hard. gruelling dungeon crawl and you're willing to give up many, many hours of your life, this game comes with my strongest recommendation.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Dragon Age: Origins stands as one of the most memorable rpg experiences I've ever had. Memorable because it does something that too many games nowadays don't do. It invests you into the story. Your choices influence the way a lot of story elements pan out. Sure the game follows a fairly defined progression but it is your choices that influence the way certain characters react during that progression. And while it might seem trivial, in reading, it can impose a very broad spectrum of emotional connections with the characters in your party. If you haven't played Dragon Age: Origins you're seriously cutting yourself out from a fantastic experience. This is not your generic Jrpg. This is a powerful epic that spins multiple perspectives on race inequality, the meaning of life, the essence of good vs evil in the eternal struggle for moral/ethical definition of a corrupting world, and theological/mystical affluence.Don't deny yourself one of the greatest RPG experiences ever created. Get Dragon Age: Origins as soon as you can and let yourself be moved by a true masterpiece.

												Dragon Age: Origins is among one of Bioware's best. Gameplay is a nice balance between the old school D&D rule sets and the streamlining of today's RPGs.
