number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												Dragon Age: Origins remains as one of the best fantasy roleplaying games in existence. Everything vital to a successful RPG is present: a quality character progression system, a gripping and immersive storyline, fantastic music, ambience, and sound effects, supremely developed and dynamic characters, and an actively enjoyable combat system. This game provides an exceptionally entertaining experience (with an estimated forty hours of gameplay) with tremendous replay value, as there are a variety of alternative choices you may decide throughout the game's nonlinear epic. For any fan of RPGs or fantasy, Dragon Age is a necessity!For some background information, you'll be able to select from several Origins (three races: human, elf, and dwarf) and be conscripted into an order known as the Grey Wardens, hunters of creatures known as Darkspawn. As a Grey Warden, you will observe a period of Blight in which an Archdemon, the highest member of the caste of darkspawn, is present. Though a Blight occurs, you will face several political challenges as the entire country of Ferelden is in turmoil. You and your band of party members will have the combat this threat yourself. The story is ultimately highly intriguing.

												I had actually initially owned Dragon Age: Origins for the Xbox, but the system died and a year or two passed and I DL'd it for the PC through Steam. If you are a completionist like me, this game is going to take a toll on you. There are a LOT of options and I don't necessarily know that it's possible to play every possible combination. That being said, if you are looking for a dark fantasy RPG, this is probably a good on. Set in aerial 3/4 view (not unlike diablo) the game handles easily. I wished it was an FPS RPG like the Elder Scrolls games, but it's not too bad. The combat is relatively simple, and the story is extremely immersive. If you like an RPG that really allows you to carve out a character an delve into their choices as the world around you forms based on it. Play this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Recently decided to pick up the ultimate edition of this game, having owned the physical copy of the original since the year that DA:O came out. Altogether I've probably spent over 200 hours into this game and if you were to do a full playthrough inculding all the DLC and the explansion you might be looking at around 70 hours of immersive gameplay. Origins in itself is largely about what race/class combo you choose and subsequently throughtout the game you will experience different interactions that promote the game's replay value. So in my opinion it's well worth the money these days.However having never tried the Awakening expansion before, I was surprised by how easy it was even on the hardest difficulty compared to the original game. To me if felt like your hero—if you choose to import from origins—is too well geared at that point and has way too many skills attributes, to the point where often I couldn't even find a place to spend points to maintain my builds later in the game. And add the fact that companions were not so fleshed out in the expansion through things like specific character stories and conversations, you will be surprised at the transition from the base game to the expansion.Nonetheless the base DA:O game is a RPG that I would recommend to all who are interested in a unique pause-combat system in addition to a great fantasy story.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Let's start with the positives and then go to the negatives.For the positives:+Great storyline. You will find a rich story filled with a lot of lore. The codex is also a great idea, and you can get more immersed into the storyline in Dragon Age Origins.+Memorable characters. Every single companion that you find has a great backstory and each of them their own niches. They each had a great characteristic about them that give each of them their own personality. None of them (Other than Secret Companion) can be hated, and they each have their redeeming qualities that make up for some flaws in their personalities. But come on, no one is perfect, there has to be flaws.+Tactics. Yes, you need tactics to survive if you play Normal difficulty or higher. Don't go in thinking you're Rambo, because you aren't.+Replayability. This game is extremely replayable. Given that there are multiple endings, multiple starts, and multiple branches throughout the game. You will spend a lot of time replaying the game.Now, for the cons of the game:-No controller support. I know there are third party software that allows you to play the game with controllers, but come on. There are other games from 2009 and before that have controller support on the PC. Why didn't Bioware somehow figure out how to do this?-Save system sucks. Quicksaves don't work. The saves that you have can sometimes NOT work. I have checked online for something for this issue. Nothing. Needs to be fixed.-The game crashes a LOT. There are some instances where you have a lot of combat, and you can't quicksave or save. Though, because of this, you need to save a lot because of stuff like this. Overall, other than the mechanical issues, Dragon Age Origins is worth the gameplay. Play it with mods. The vanilla game is really awkward at some parts, and you'll understand which parts are.Edit: I'm going to add a few more things to the Cons list. I found this out while playing the game even more.-Once it stops responding, it stops responding. I honestly don't think that Dragon Age Origins was optimized for the PC. There are parts of the game where you want to reload, and sometimes it takes 10-15 minutes for a small area to load. When you go in, it lags a bit, and I tried to restart the game. It wouldn't let me do such a thing. After that debacle, I decided to close it through Task Manager. Another 30 minutes passed, and it wouldn't close, forcing me to restart the computer just to gain use of it again. -The game is extremely unbalanced. You know how people say that magic is always broken in fantasy games and that mages are always the ones that seem to be overpowered? Dragon Age is also a victim to that generalized assumption. My Rogue has high willpower and dexterity, which should pretty much make him untouchable at the endgame. Even with my willpower at around 30, my dexterity and cunning at 50, the game still has the audacity to make magic a 100% hit, and a HIGH damage output. Magic is inherently broken in this game.To add to that overall, a lot of the mechanics of this game do indicate how aged the game is. It's not bad, but if someone were to play this game at this year without prior knowledge to it, they would most likely place this game as something they would not recommend. Mods will relieve this problem, but this is a warning to any person who is still deciding on whether or not to buy this game: Lower your standards to around 2009, when the game was released. Don't have the high expectations of a seamless and perfect combat system, because Dragon Age Origins does not have a perfect combat system. It has a rusted one. Don't expect the game to be easy unless you play the mage character. Magic in this game is broken and you can essentially beat every single boss in the game without losing health with the three mages and a tank. I will still recommend this, but at this point, without mods, the game needs some serious work. If playing Vanilla, I would not recommend this game (And this series is one of my favorite series to date), but with mods, I would recommend this game to many others. To summarize:+ I would recommend this game if you play it with mods.- I would not recommend this game if you decide to play it Vanilla.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												At first I despised the whole "group controlling" aspect, because I was looking for another RPG like TES. But after spending 1-2 hours, I started feeling oddly attracted to the game. I literally fell in love. The story is amazing, the graphs are still pretty decent after 4 years, the gameplay is fantastic. Amazing "tactics" system that inspired me to actually strategize my attacks. All hands down, probably the best RPG I played in a long while. That being said, a few things must be said. Firstly, SAVE A LOT. Some quests can be BUG nests, so be extra cautious. Secondly, before you even CONSIDER trying to build a GENERAL character, know that you will encounter party members of different classes, so just pick one path and master it. Otherwise, you will end up creating a weakling-deadweight character whom you will always have to carry in to battle. Long story short, you won't have enough time to master every single skill, so just master one or two if you are lucky.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												I have beaten this game on origin.Fun facts for people interested in playing itit includes basically two epilogues, and several additional questsif you go onto bioware social or just check the dragon age website you can get all of the additional promotional content for free as well. When combined all of this makes for a game that is mass effect 2 levels of awesome. On Pc your lucky enough to have mods that will make the game look and feel like it meshes well with the other two titles DAII and DA Inquisition. Its either plays like a point and click, or a tactical RPG depending on how you go about pursuing each quest. Easy enough to complete, but with enough challenge to make you invest at least 45-50 hours (if you try to complete every quest). The characters leave an impression, and in all honest this game is put together well enough that you can beat it and then hop straight into inquisition without missing a beat. for I'd give it a 7.5 out of 10 the missing two and a half points is just because the graphics are a bit under par especially considering this game was released around the same time as mass effect 2. That being said modded it feels more like a 8.5 out of ten. Not quite there graphically but significantly better than where it was.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2014
												Customizable characters, difficult decisions (no red or blue or right or wrong like other games), funny dialouge between characters, epic boss fights, weapons, romance, and over 100hrs of gameplay.....What more could you ask for from an RPG game. The main story is amazing. You will laugh, cry, and ponder about you're past decisions as you progress through the many hours of the game. Always was a fan of the original dragon age orgins edition, so buying the Ultimate was a no brainer for me. The DLCs whether following the main story or occuring after the main story may not be the longest, but they are definitely interesting and will leave you wanting to knwo what happens next. The Awakening DLC is fantastic though; being able to lead the Graywardens and make decisions not just for yourself but for a city of people is stressful , but rewarding. Also being able to be reunited with former friends and make many new ones is also a nice change in pace. The darkspawn in this dlc are also more interesting since there are those who talk and do things with a purpose not just because they can. Overall, get this game!!! Whether its the regular edition or the Ultimate Edition, either one wil be worth every last buck.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												"In war, victory. In peace, vigilance. In death, sacrifice."Peace is over and war rages as another Blight spreads upon the lands of Ferelden, led by an archdemon that intends to destroy the world with its corrupting taint. You, a newly recruited gray warden, is among the few who can defeat the creature and put an end to its destruction. However, first you must raise an army to combat the darkspawn hordes, gain political favors to end civil war, and most important of all: survive all the horrors you encounter along the way."Dragon Age: Origins" is but an amazing story of social and political intrigue, filled with compelling dialogs, interesting characters and wonderfully written plots. The choices presented along the way have a true impact on how the story progresses, and many of them are such tough decisions that the need for a curious replay often presents itself. For these reasons, and more, this game stands as one of my most favorite games of all time.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Back in 2010, I had trouble when BioWare handed the support over to EA (How could you!? *curses*). I basically lost my original account and was provided with one that did not contain all the bonus items I had acquired, because EA is apparently incapable of transferring data correctly (I was in touch with the support for about three years, then I gave up). Thanks a lot, a 100 bucks wasted on the CE and the bonus packs back then. I was so angry I simply ignored DA:O.Fast forward to New's Year's 2014/15: Now here's a super nice discount at Steam! 5 bucks for the whole package, including all the bonus items (and those that are not included can easily be downloaded for free at BioWare Social). So I decided to start all over and give the game another shot, five years later. Thank you, Steam! I fell in love with this wonderful piece of work all over again. Great story, nice graphic, great gameplay and a gripping atmosphere. After all, the developers are not accountable for the EA fiasco. ;)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												Oh wow, where should I start? Well first of all this is the third time I've owned the game, first on the Xbox 360, then again on the PS3, and finally on the PC.  Now this game is dated, it came out in 2009, and you can really see it when you play it.  Even cranking the graphics up to max on your pc won't do much to improve the apperance of the game.  However there are quite a few mods out there that tweak the appearance of the game, making it signficantly more pleasant, however I have not seen any total overhaul mod out there.  Do note that there is no Steam workshop for this game, but Nexus does include the Nexus Mod Manager, and has a very large selection of mods available for this game, so definitely check them out once you buy, and install this beast.Now for the meat of things, Dragon Age Origins is the first game in the trilogy, and takes place in Ferelden, the fictional nation inspired largely by medieval England, as the on set of the Fifth Blight encroaches the land.  I do not want to spoil anything, so I'll avoid talking any more about the story, but I feel that at this point in time almost everyone has played this game or at least wikia'd the plot.  This game features the point and click style combat, as in I left click over my oponet and he begins to swing his sword, then I can press one of my hotkeyes for him to use a skill.  Do not come in expecting this to be like DA II or DAI, where you'll be spamming the attack button like a game of Dynasty Warriors.  Fortunately you have regenerating health outside of combat, and mages have a healing branch, something that Bioware took out of DAI, which drove me insane, especially on Hard and Nightmare difficulties.  In this game you'll often find yourself pausing combat so you can survey the battlefield, formulate  a plan, and then issue orders, then unpause to watch your four man/woman team move out. Now I would definitely recommend playing this game on hard at least, to get a real challenge out of things, it definitely makes the game more enjoyable, and I practically live in pause mode/tactical mode.  The mechanics here are amazing, as you travel from area to area, you have a slight ability to explore each of these areas.  Now this is not a free roaming game, well not in the traditional sense at least.  You can control to which 'area' you want to go to, and within each area there is a small degree of exploration involved, but to me that was never important, seeing as how I was so engrossed by the story.  There's plenty of NPC's to talk to, a fair amount of side quests to do, and so much♥♥♥♥♥♥to pick up it isn't even remotely funny.  The Ultimate Edition also comes with all the DLC you could ever want, and the game has for that matter.  So you definitely get your money's worth, especially with the story expansion Awakening installed that (can) continue your journey after the completition of Origins.  Not to mention you have all of the smaller story/mission DLC's to play, that will take up a few hours of your time, answer some of your questions or give you some closure in some of them, as well as net you new items for your main game.  Oh yeah I forgot about the prologue story for Leliana, entitled Leliana's Song, which takes place before Origins, lets you play as Leliana, and also gets you some cool items to use in Origins (especially for Leliana!).  This game is amazing, it has so much content, gameplay is fantastic, the story will keep you hooked and playing until the sun comes back up, and you'll know why this game is the best of the trilogy.  Plus you'll establish such unhealthy connections with some of the characters you might end up getting a body pillo...uh you'll just try to learn everything about them.  Also the game gets better with mods, they're like swear words and spices, it makes things better.  Plus it'll help clean up the appearance of the game a little bit.  Personally I love this game, it's in my top 5 games of all times, and it's better then those other two, and it has a better ending than Mass Effect 3.  This game is a 10/10, you wont find a better game with as much content for this price with access to thousands of mods that make it even better.  Plus it has a story better then the entire Elder Scrolls universe.  Even Commander Shepard would tell you that this is his favorite game on all of Steam, I mean at least believe him, he is the first human SPECTRE, savior of the galaxy, human icon, and an all around great guy.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												DA:O is an incredibly fun tactical squad-based RPG. The story is solid and character decisions make a HUGE difference, especially as you can import your save from DA:O into Dragon Age 2, and then into Dragon Age: Inquisition. The gameplay is just as strong, featuring a simple, easy-to-use dialogue system and a robust combat system, replete with AI tactics which can somewhat automate the process of managing 4 characters in a combat environment.TL;DR - If you like RPG games with meaningful player decisions (e.g., not what Skyrim does with meaningless player decisions) and don't mind an over-the-shoulder/bird's-eye-view approach to a tactically-grounded squad-based combat game, then this is the game for you!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												A very long, but excellent game overall. Aside from the Elder Scrolls series, I don't know any games that will give you more bang for your buck than Dragon Age (: Origins - Ultimate Edition). If you go through all the DLC and finish most of the sidequests in the game you'll easily spend over 100 hours on a single run, and there were hardly any points in the game where I felt like the plot was starting to drag.The gameplay is good overall. I do think the strategy elements were sometimes a bit tedious though. I didn't like pausing battles every 0.5 seconds to give all of my characters new orders and it was also difficult sometimes to get my characters to do exactly what I wanted them to, when I wanted them to. The AI is not as bad as in Mass Effect 1, but I still often had to deal with things like my ranged fighter throwing herself into melee combat rather than keeping distance and my assassin attacking enemies head on rather than trying to backstab. The game does provide you with Tactics slots to tell your characters in advance how to respond to situations in battle, but that takes a lot of time to set up and doesn't always give good results. As with most BioWare games (KOTOR, Mass Effect), they've put a lot of effort into developing the main characters and giving them intruiging backstories. However, in Dragon Age I feel like they've even taken it a few steps further. Each individual character gets lots of 'screen time' (if you bother to talk to them) and the romance sidequest has been worked out a lot more than in their previous games. One of the gameplay elements is a 'relationship' system that will make choices you make during the game affect your relationship with your party members. A good relationship will make characters befriend you or fall in love with you (revealing more of the character's backstory), a bad relationship might make the character leave the party permanently. Personally, I really loved this and wish more RPGs had this. What I particularly loved about this game is that the choices that you face during the development of the plot aren't always as straightforward as picking a good or bad option. You will face plenty of dillemmas in which it is not so obvious what the outcome of your choices will be and you'll feel compelled to apply your own moral reasoning to the situation. In the end, this makes it feel more like you're actually playing as yourself (or a realistic human being) and not someone who's putting up a goody-two-shoes / bad♥♥♥♥♥act. Anyway, I enjoyed Dragon Age a lot. I think it will please any fan of the RPG genre. It's a very well-made game overall that is more than worth the €7,50 I paid for it during the Sale.

It stands as one of my favorites and alongside The Elder Scrolls Series, and that's saying something.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												I bought this purely because of Dragon Age: Inquisition but DA: Origins is a great game that with a few mods looks great. I highly recommend the ultimate edition, forget the deluxe edition, and forget vanilla pay the extra money for the ultimate edition. It adds greatly to your Dragon Age experience and works well with Bioware's Dragon Age keep. At an easy setting you will run through the game in about 48 hours, but with 6 character origins options and 3 unique classes you'll come back for more.The game also has strict consequences to actions - like The Witcher series more than The Elder Scrolls - so choose wisely. If you are into role playing your CRPG characters then DA: Origins is a solid option with its racial, gender and class options. In terms of mods I also recommend downloading Bioware's own graphics update for  the Qunari race[social.bioware.com]. I also highly recommend using DAO-Modmanager by Altorian (this is a must have if you want to mod the game) and Dragon Age Redesigned by Dracomies and Extra Dog Slot by Dheuster. I run two or three other graphics/texture mods but to my mind these mods are necessary. All in all I highly recommend DA: Origins even if it’s 5 years old. There are a few glitchy aspects to the controls but nothing major. This is a tactical combat game not an action hack and cast adventure. Like Final Fantasy or older CRPGs you’re managing a party but with the added twist of favour points which will determine whether your companions stay with you or not (although in my experience you can easily manipulate their favour at lower difficult settings to “adore” ratings by gifting regularly.If you don’t like Dungeons and Dragons (DnD) inspired game systems or DnD/Tolkienesque fantasy races then this is not a game for you. Dragon Age is steep in the stock of fantasy tropes, the undead (Dark Spawn), dragons, mages, rogue, dwarves who live under mountains, demons and god-like dragons (don’t think just because you’re the chosen one you take a dragon on single-handed this is very definitely not Skyrim).  However if you do like DnD and do like the stock fantasy tropes Dragon Age: Origins offers an engaging storyline with good graphics and good tactical combat system.As a backstory to DA: Inquisition Origins is a good buy, but even as a stand alone game Origins fares well as a tactical combat DnD inspired game. A solid 3 out of 5

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												+/+ Complex and engaging battle mechanics.+/+ Some very memorable characters & locations.+/+ Good number of side quests and a lengthy (30+ hour) main story.+/+ Solid graphics and sound effects.+/+ Multiple options for character builds and good/evil choices.+/+ Multiple difficulty options.+/+ Various PC options (rebindable keys, multiple graphic settings, etc.).+/- Voice acting varies dramatically throughout the game.-/- Orzammar (Dwarven location) is poorly designed.-/- Not all dialog options have a real or noticeable impact.-/- Some backtracking is required.-/- Lacking steam features (achievements, cloud, workshop, etc.) – to be fair, this game was released before these features were integrated into steam.Verdict: 8.5/10.  Dragon Age is a very well-constructed RPG. I would easily recommend it to fans of the genre.

												Dragon Age: Origins is my favourite RPG, personally. content:
Posted: November 16, 2015
												i have played this game off and on for a number of years, without having completed the story before just recently. it is really a great game, with alot of top notch story and plenty of dungeon crawling to satisfy the tastes of most.  the various 'origin' story branches make replayablilty high, and the expansion + add ons extend playablilty even more.      the main complaint i have has to do with the stupid approach that the parent company has taken to pc games. they have (again, stupidly) attempted to maintain an arbitrary barrier between pc and console gamers by refusing to include controller support for most of their pc titles. this would be forgiveable had they not released the same titles on each of the consoles, with, of course, full controller support. grow up! pc is the master race, but not because everyone loves kb/m. choices, choices are of utmost importance.    second complaint is how poorly the add ons and expansion were integrated into the main game. it seems that, with some extra work, they could have made it a seemless experience, but as it is i had to use the internet to see which order to play the additional content in. seems sloppy.    if not for the second part, this game would get 9.8 out of 10 from me, but since they cut some serious corners in my opinion, 9.3 out of 10. excellent game almost all around.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												Originally bought this game for PS3 when it came out and played it ALOT so the hours i sank into it don't match up in Steam.I bought it because of the epic CGI trailers that spawned in between TV commercials (weird that they aren't on the store page) and bought it in a whimp without knowing what i was getting myself into. So, when i started playing i was like "WTF is this ****"? ugly graphics (compared to it's trailer counterpart that is) and weird gameplay (didn't check the box for info. I just dived into it). But i kept going because of the story and setting. I literally played hours smashing buttons when i was in battle and thinking what crappy unresponsive combat it was :DAfter +- 3 hours i noticed you had to trigger combat by pressing a button "ones" (auto-attack) and select the appropriate skills when needed. I was like "mehh" and yet i still kept playing and then it slowly started to grow on me. When i was like half-game i was addicted! I couldn't stop playing (micro managing tougher battles! hell yeah!) and days turned into nights in a heartbeat! What voodoo trickery is this! So yeah, it was hard getting into it mainly because of the visual aspect and there's not really an in-game explenation of the batlle system (for as far as i know i had to figure it all out by myself and not being into Tactical RPG it took a long time), but story, gameplay and setting (medieval fantasy) made me forget that. And best of all... some characters you meet in this game are so loveable and if not worst; are truely missed in the next installments (besides some small cameo's) :( This game got me truely into RPG games (if you don't count "Wonder Boy In Monsterworld" xD )Bought it again for PC so i can mod it!Dragon Age: Origins get's 10 hearts!*crappy review i know :p

content:
Posted: April 24, 2013
												If you liked Neverwinter Nights franchise, you will love Dragon Age Origins.  The game has a compelling story and has a different introduction depending on the character you chose to play.  The graphics age well, while the UI takes about an hour to become familiar with.  The game is truly personal as the characters you chose to be your companions converse with you and each other, and your actions do affect the outcome of the story.  If you like to micromanage, you will have your time to optimize your characters; If not, than you still can enjoy the game just by picking up and wielding what you find along the way or want to buy from a vendor.  Origins + Awakenings is easily a hundred-hour investment, and will leave you eager to jump into Dragon Age II. 9/10 RPG Strategy

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												Having put over 250 hours into Dragon Age: Origins, I think I am qualified to say this is a rich, immersive game you can't get enough of. This was my first fantasy RPG game I ever played (and my second video game period), but the learning curve is not awfully steep, particularly if you are persistent in the face of adversity. (I'm looking at you, Revenant, in front of the Redcliffe Castle. BRUTAL.) By the end, you'll have developed the confidence to take on the Archdemon himself. And if you get into it as much as I did, helping the Archdemon himself as well. ;) (The Darkspawn Chronicles.)There are a few bugs that interfere with gameplay, particularly in Awakening, so don't hesitate to look up any issues you might have; all that I had were solved with a few mods. Otherwise, the gameplay is a seamless experience.If you're still here reading this review, cut down on your patience and ramp up your impatience to start DRAGON AGE!

content:
Posted: March 23, 2013
												For a fantasy game, Dragon Age: Origins is truly majestic. For such a large scale game, it has unrivaled attention to detail and virtually no flaws.  Only other recent BioWare games create characters this well, and the game is most powerful when you're talking to NPCs, shaping their attitude and defining their personalities, and when you watch the outcomes of all of your decisions. DAO is a true RPG with over 300 hours of content, and is never the same when replaying it.  There are so many critical ethical choices that will linger in your mind as you play, and there are no clear-cut good or bad choices; everything has it's consequences.  It's definitely one of the very best games ever made.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2016
												This is one of the greatest RPG games of all time, don't let my small amount of play time at the moment of this writting fool you, I've spent easily over 600 hours playing this game on the Xbox 360, and to this day it remains one of my favorite RPG games, 3rd, only to Skyrim, and Fallout New Vegas. Don't bother with buying the regular version, you'll want everything that this game has to offer, including all of it's DLC, which is why I am reviewing the Ultimate Edition, you can get a great game if you just buy the standard vanilla version, but really, don't, because the game and all it's DLC is outstanding by the standards that have been set today, not to mention the shear number of mods that are out there for this game, if you care to do that sort of thing. The game is a bit strange if you've never played a game similar to this before, but you'll quickly get used to it, and, it doesn't take an insanely powerful computer to run it, all I have for my hardware, at this time is an Intel Core I3-4150, and running the onboard Intel HD 4400, I can play the game on low settings at 1600x900 screen res just fine, no issues. Definitely take advantage of the sale that is running at the time of this review if you are thinking about buying it.10/10, but as someone else said, the Fade can get a little annoying if you don't know what you're doing lol

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												A spiritual successor to Baldur's gate IIDA: O is an amazing game that Bioware spent 5 years working on it and polishing it to the absolute shine. There is a whole new world for players to get lost in; World of Thedas has a rich lore and imaginative history fraught with struggles between nations, races and ideologies. A beefy and satisfying real time tactical system with a pause makes every single battle count, every maneuver you make essential, and every mistake you make can and will cost you dearly. Even today, graphics look breathtaking with amazing artistic touch to it. Music and sounds are excellent, emphasizing the epic feeling to the campaign, as well as provoking tender and mystic feel as well.Dragon Age was designed from the start to be a dark fantasy game, different from its older brethren that became golden letters in the history of RPGs. Origin tries with all its might to prove it being separate from Baldur's Gate, KOTOR and Icewind Tale series that it makes occasional blunders as well. Some conflicts look forced, and some resolutions in the story look a bit silly. But for the most part, DA: O hits all the right notes in being unique and grand, although a bit flawed experience compared to the first Witcher from the same year.The story told in the lengthy campaign is awe-inspiring, immersive and emotional. Companions in your group and NPCs are complex where each one of them has their own reasons why they are helping you; most of them aren't doing it from the goodness of their heart. Enemies, along with the Archdemon and the Architect are imposing, menacing and believable. The best character of them all, of course is YOU, the last of the Wardens, a sacred order created with only one goal: to fight the Blight that threatens the World. Like in RPGs of yore, there are so many dialogue options that will affect the game and characters around you, thus making you the most complex and interesting individual in the game. There are neither dialogue wheels nor a need for the main character to have a voice, no unnecessary simplicity and limitations in roleplaying your character. Talking to others in this game is a thing of beauty.Not everything is rosy though: some sections of the game can be a series of long fights with minimal roleplaying in them; side quests are sadly very poor and superficial, with deliberate "fetch me this, kill me that" vibe to it. In fact, this might be the first game that started with the trend of dumbing-down side quests, which only escalated in further Mass Effect and DA games. Lastly, game is brutally difficult, not even close to the Dark Souls sadomasochism, but casual players might be turned off to such a steep spike of difficulty.7 years after its release, Dragon Age Origins still stands as a jewel in the roleplaying waters, and will continue to do so. It has fought for its own place under the spotlight, away from other Bioware games and managed to do that and much more.P.S. Dragon Age II is good, if you can manage simplifications in roleplaying and fighting segments, and the constant repetition of certain areas in the game. The story is quite unique for Bioware, much more personal without the need to save the world; companions are as funny and intriguing as ever.P.S.S. Dragon Age Inquisition is OK, barely manageable. It is buried underneath the tedious MMO-like fighting system, huge and uninteresting maps, and superficial side-quests and of course, the greatest enemy of RPGs is still here: the dreaded Dialogue Wheel. Story is really interesting and imposing, characters you meet awesome and DLCs are actually for a change quite good, lengthy and satisfying.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 8, 2016
												Dragon Age: Origins... What you are seeing here is probably the best story-driven rpg in the world. The game has a fantastic story with fantastic characters that actually are interesting. There are so much believable emotions and personalities in this game that even the best movies have a hard competition with this game.That being said there are things in this game that is not so fantastic and there are things that are just above average but the whole package is fantastic indeed. The game suffers from bugs and glitches that lowers the score for this a well 10 deserved game otherwise. Even after their latest patch it still has problems that i will mention further down.Instead of you having to read a whole bunch of text ill just form up a list of whats good and whats bad about this game.Good:+ Interesting characters with lots of dialogs and options to choose from.+ The story alone is what makes this game a diamond.+Things you do or say in the game changes your gameplay and experience.+ Every hero you choose to be has its own beginning and it sometimes matters if youre a man or a woman.+ There are plenty of weapons and armors to choose and they are not all specified to each classes. (A few are though) So your customization is vast!+ Abilities and spells are very fun and near at hand and are easy to use+ Tactics is an excellent way to customize each and every team members behavior.+ Over 40 hours of gameplay. (If you do all the secondary stuff)+ The game rewards you for exploration and to be on the look out. There are plenty of books, objects and loots that gives you extra quests and sometimes rewards you with unique equipment.+ You can build up relationships with your teammates and even find love if you want. And the game rewards you for talking to them, give them gifts and show your interest to them.+ Combat is smooth, the AI is good for about maybe 90% of the time and the animations looks very good.+ Excellent voice acting, facial expressions, hand movements and everything. It fits so perfectly.+ Detailed graphics that looks great with maximum settings. These graphics are indeed timeless.Bad:- The game suffers from a memory bug. The more you play the game the more your computers memory gets over-loaded and frame rate drops vastly when there are many enemies and the loading times takes longer and longer the more you play. Restarting the game solves this problem but it its a pain to do. - The ending is a giant bug and glitch fest. I can max everything graphic-wise but combine the insane amount of enemies in the end with the memorybug and you have a painful delay on everything that pretty much kills the experience. For som strange reason every regular enemy dies with one hit no matter how low damage you do but the elite enemies works normally. And when they spawn they just stand still and do nothing. And when you hit an enemy it can take 5 seconds for a damage reaction.- The corpses takes sometimes forever to show its droppings. (Memory bug) This happens all the time after playing for a while without restarting the game.- The game is a bit too linear sometimes with a basic "start and goal" with only one way to go. Just a small minus though.- Places are reused plenty of times and it makes you travel between the same places witch can take long time especially with the memorybug. (Secondary quests suffers from it at least) And running from place to place can be a pain in the **** sometimes especially in Orzammar.To sum it all up. The game is a 10/10 from the beginning to 90% forward but ends up with a 9/10 because of the problems at the end.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												Dragon Age: Origins is, in essence, a true treat for any RPG fan. Although the micromanaging and large array of choices you can make during the game may seem daunting at first, everything is easy to get the hang of, and the game has amazing replay value.The gameplay is fun, the story is gripping, and when you're pulled away to do something in real life, you'll always want to go back to playing DA:O when you're finished. Although I find the game tiring after more than a few hours of play, as sometimes the story itself can get emotionally exhausting (but I won't spoil you on that)!The extra money for the DLC is definitely a good deal if you know you'll enjoy DA:O or plan to spend a lot of time playing it.Story: 8/10Graphics: 7/10 (It's easy to mod the game to have better graphics, and with the mods I would easily give it a 9/10)Gameplay: 8/10Audio: 9/10 (The voice acting is absolutely amazing)Replayability: 10/10 Overall: 8/10+ Great story+ Great audio and voice acting+ Engaging combat and gameplay mechanics+ You can play this game a dozen times- Somewhat bad graphics if you play on low settings or don't mod it- Combat may be confusing at first- Planning and micromanaging is requiredSummary:If you like RPGs, games that help you develop your character as a person rather than just a silent entity, and an interesting build and combat system, consider picking up DA:O. For any RPG fan, you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												"In war, victory. In peace, vigilance. In death, sacrifice."Peace is over and war rages as another Blight spreads upon the lands of Ferelden, led by an archdemon that intends to destroy the world with its corrupting taint. You, a newly recruited gray warden, is among the few who can defeat the creature and put an end to its destruction. However, first you must raise an army to combat the darkspawn hordes, gain political favors to end civil war, and most important of all: survive all the horrors you encounter along the way."Dragon Age: Origins" is but an amazing story of social and political intrigue, filled with compelling dialogs, interesting characters and wonderfully written plots. The choices presented along the way have a true impact on how the story progresses, and many of them are such tough decisions that the need for a curious replay often presents itself. For these reasons, and more, this game stands as one of my most favorite games of all time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												I count Dragon Age: Origins amongst my favourite roleplaying games ever made. I've played through it at least four times on console, and then some. A perfect combination of old and new, Origins appeals to fans of RPGs old and new.The game itself plays out like your typical Dungeons & Dragons inspired affair, with a wide variety of skills, attributives and abilities that govern the outcome of multiple scenarios. Though the combat animations can be a bit sluggish and dull, winning fights takes some degree of cunning and strategy, especially on the higher difficulties. More than any other game I've seen, this one takes managing your party to a whole new level. For fans of strategy games, this game will more than satisfy your inner tactician with its myriad of planning options for each and every consistency.You pick from the standard three classes: rouge, warrior and mage. However, the more open-ended structure of the leveling system allows for a lot more nuance and depth than your average dice roller. For example, on my second playthrough, I decided to be a mage. And whilst being a mage in this game is the most fun I've ever had as a mage in any game, I still prefer the path of the warrior. With a couple specialisations that I unlocked in the game, I was able to craft a battlemage that fit my tastes perfectly, capable of rushing foes down with a battleaxe and heavy armours and able to switch to a fireball or living bomb spell for crowd control seamlessly.Though the setting is extremely derivative, the world's politics and inner working still manage to be intriguing with plenty of rich lore to back it up. However, it's not the world that makes exploring Thedas on your quest to save the world from an army of orcs and an evil dragon interesting. It's the characters.For those familiar with [/i]Mass Effect[/i] will find themselves very comfortable with how [/i]Dragon Age: Origins[/i] treats party members, perhaps even more so. For almost your entire crew, you almost always have the option to kick them out, kill them or otherwise refuse your help (though you'd have to be some kind of hardcore maniac to do this). Most of them are romancable, and all of them are colourful, multi-dimensional people with their own interests, backstory, agendas and quirks. This is where making "moral" choices becomes difficult. Instead of any kind of morality meter, each of your followers have an approval rating with you. When considering your actions, you'll have to keep satisfying your party in mind as well. And the choices. Oh man, the choices you have to make. Some of them thought-provoking, others gut-wrenching, all of the choices you have to make are interesting, leaving plenty of room to characterise your silent protagonist. Are you a ruthless leader who refuses to compromise for your goal? Or are you a noble, naive hero who always seeks to help others? What about a greedy, power hungry sociopath? Maybe you're just a complete psycho. Whether you want to be any of these things or anything in-between, this game gives you the freedom to decide.The plot itself is as straight forward as it gets. It's an epic albeit cliche-riddled journey as you unite the land and raise an army strong enough to face a horde of monsters and the demonic dragon that leads them. Sound familiar? Does it sounds like every fantasy game you'd ever played? Dragon Age: Origins is anything but original, however it proves the rule that it's better to do something well than to do something new and fail, as we've seen with its successor. The plot is entirely character-driven, and though there are some eye-opening twists and turns here and there, it's a fairly simple, though well-written ride. That isn't why you play through, however. This game is made by the characters. Even if you don't enjoy the pseudo MMO-style combat, the action is highlighted by your interaction with a large cast of colourful, well-rounded characters. From the flawed human antagonist and his pure evil sidekick to the socially-inept and seemingly heartless witch to the conflicted albeit well-meaning bard, everyone has a story to tell, and you'll love hearing it.If any of the above interests you, please don't hesitate to buy the Ultimate Edition for ten dollars more than the base game. If $29.99 seems a bit steep, wait for a sale and keep in mind that you're getting a mind-boggling amount of content here. Aside from the high replayability the open-ended character levelling system and multiple origin stories provide, you already have a base campaign that can take you tens of hours (we're talking 30+ if you take the time to talk to people and engage in side quests) with plenty to see and do. The additional DLC is very much worth playing. The Stone Prisoner adds a unique party member with his/her own questline for you to uncover, which doesn't just add more content, it can breathe new life into the vanilla content as well. [/b]Warden's Keep[/b] is a short, but enjoyable mini quest that tasks you with clearing a new dungeon and finally siding with one of two new characters. This includes some new skills and items as well as a party chest to store your loot, though that can be done with a mod just as easily. Return to Ostagar takes you through familiar territory, but it remains a poignant reminder of one of the most intense parts of the story, despite being little more than a remixed level with extra loot and tough enemies. If you're particularly passionate about the story and its characters, you'll get a kick out of it. Feastday Gifts and Feastday Pranks are silly nothing add-ons that can be easily overlooked on their own, but as a part of the complete package, can add some cute little extras, like cleaning the party's blood off with soap, playing fetch with your dog and having Alistair play with dolls. Good fun, but not essential or even worth buying on its own.The Darkspawn Chronicles is a standalone campaign in which you play as the Darkspawn in a darker, alternate universe where the hero dies early on and the bad guys win. It's worth playing at least once for the amusing "what if" scenario, though I personally found it to be a bit boring without any actual dialogue or plot aside from the interesting bits of lore that detail the choices your party made and the adventures they had without you. Leliana's Song on the other hand, is a canonical standalone campaign in which you play as a younger Leliana alongside a cast of fresh faces. Their misadventures make for a fun romp, especially if you really like Leliana.The Golems of Amgarrak is another standalone campaign, this time featuring your main character from the base game, if you so choose. This one is peppered throughout with spooky lore and a bit of dialogue, but what this DLC really nails is atmosphere. It's an oppressive adventure through the darkest parts of the fallen Dwarven kingdom that leads up to a terrifying and challenging final boss, one that is easily amongst my favourite boss battles in RPG history just for the sheer satisfaction of finally taking him/her/it down. Not to be missed for any one who enjoys the combat and a challenge, or just wants to see more of their characters adventures in Thedas.The final add-on and the last to take place canonically, Witch Hunt features the return of your hero - again, unless you want to make a new guy with a different agenda - in search of a character from the original campaign. This standalone campaign has almost no new content in terms of the enemies you'll be fighting and the places you'll be going, but what it does have is a challenging campaign perfect for those who want answers (not that you'll necessarily get them) about the original game. Your three new party members are fun, and I only wish it was longer, just so you can spend more time with them.So yeah, I recommend this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												Overall, I would reccommend Dragon Age: Origins to anyone looking for a lengthy and fun to play RPG campaign.First off, I'll start with some of the negatives. Graphically, the game isn't really much to look at compared to what one might be used to in this day and age of graphics and content; it's an older game, so I should hope prospective buyers can easily overlook this. Secondly, the game does have a tendency to crash (at least on my computer) if too much is going on at one time, but with the ever frequent autosaves and a hopefully attentive-in-saving player, this shouldn't prove too much of an issue. Finally, there is quite a difficulty curve, even on normal difficulty settings. Do not expect a quick walk through the part to overpowered status like in a round of Skyrim; if you don't learn to utilize strategy and your companions, you aren't going to get very far. Luckily, if you are feeling a bit overwhelmed, difficulty can be changed at any time from the in-game options menu, though I would suggest struggling through the campaign on at least normal difficulty for satisfying payoff.For the most part, that's really all the issues I can find at this particular moment. There may be more, I just can't think of them! So, let's get to the good stuff. One might expect Dragon Age: Origins to be "like Mass Effect but in the Middle Ages" because of the pedigree associated with it. There are certainly some aspects of Dragon Age: Origins that one may find similar to its developer's previous titles, but all and all, it's unique from both its predecessors and other big-name RPGs.In terms of gameplay, Origins blends real-time action and careful strategy with the simple press of the space bar, which pauses the game and allows the player to issue commands to every individual in the four-man party. I may also mention here the you, as the player, will find yourself filled to the brim with companions in your camp, but you can only take a total of three others (in addition to your own character) into battle with you. Honestly, it is a bit disappointing that you've got ten companions (plus the additional companions one will find in the episodic DLCs) ready to fight for you, but only three will actually go with you to fight. Anyways, I digress and continue with the gameplay. For the most part, it does have some open-world elements to make it feel closer to a sandbox than it actually is, connecting cities and environments you can explore together on a World Map or City Map, depending on the particular location. Despite the environments being fairly linear in comparison to other games and there being no optional areas in the vanilla game, there are still plenty of nooks and crannies to explore in every city, map or extremely lengthy dungeon. And I say this because some of the dungeons, both due to difficulty and overall length, feel like they take a long time to complete. I do not say this as a negative, personally, because I like the length added to the game, but for some, it may be a bit grueling.From the beginning, character creation isn't as in-depth as other RPG titles. Honestly, that doesn't matter that greatly to me, but hey, it might to you. You can choose from three starting races--human, elf or dwarf--which each have their own racial bonuses (except dwarves can't become mages), and from there, you may choose one of three classes --warrior, rogue or mage--with each class having four specializations like "assassin" for rogues or "shapeshifter" for mages. And yes, you could be a warrior or rogue, but overall, it's just as wise to be a mage and spam AOE damage spells while ordering your allies clear of the AOE (or not, if you are devious), because it will essentially decimate any non-boss group of enemies you encounter. And even some bosses. Finally, each character gets to undergo one of six origin stories, which all feature characters later introduced in the plot and can affect the plot iself later. They all eventually lead to the same place, but regardless, it's a nice touch to the game's opening.Story's not much to write home about on its own. There is a demon. It is leading an army of other demons. Maybe you should kill it. That's your traditional RPG fare. However, where Origins really shines is in its characters and lore. Firstly, there is an entire codex devoted to lore, information and bestiaries that gets progressively filled as you go through the game, providing an incredibly lengthy amount of reading content for any lore-lover. Origins is a very rich world in that respect. However, my favorite part of Origins is the interactions between characters and the personalities of the involved parties. The aforementioned ten companions you acquire throughout the game are all unique even in their skillsets, despite there being only three starting classes, and none of them feels like a carbon copy of the other. In fact, most don't even feel like they belong to a stereotypical character archetype, as one would normally find in an RPG. They feel fully fleshed out and their interactions between one another and your character feel like real people talking in the real world. Plus, the voice acting is quite high quality for most of them, so they are very expressive to compensate for the weaker facial animations of this era of gaming. Additionally, the villains one encounters in the game are motivated not by a desire to do evil, but by a want to protect others from the coming Blight and to prepare themselves for such a difficult time. I appreciate seeing characters who do evil because they see it as good and rational.So all in all? Origins is a quality game. Ultimate Edition comes packed with a huge amount of DLC for an incredible price (though with the time that has passed, I would hope that price would be incredible), complete with Awakening, which is a sizeable campaign (though certainly not Shivering Isles sizeable) with an interesting plot for the lore Origins established. It also comes with several short, episodic campaigns that explore the Origins world from different perspectives, characters and even timelimes. Would I recommend it? Yes, as I have hopefully established earlier. We can only hope the the upcoming Inquisition will live up to Origins' high-standard, as Dragon Age II failed quite miserably before it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												I may be one of the biggest RPG nuts around. I've played so many its hard to keep track of them all. That being said Dragon Age: Origins is probably in the top 10 Rpgs I've ever played. EVER. The story is fun and the characters are memorable. The lore that is established is incredible, especially for a game that's the first in what's hopefully a long series. The origins, the main story, and the seemingly meaning ful choices are what set this game apart.If you are familiar with Bioware games such as KOTOR, Baldurs Gate, and NWN then you know how the combat in this game works. If you don't, you need to know that combat is very strategic, and not exactly fast paced. If action packed, fast paced combat is your thing, you may want to skip this one. But if you enjoy strategizing and co-ordinating the skills of varied party members, this will go down as one of your favorites.The only cons I can think of are that there are no maps that you can just free roam on, and the cities that should seem like bustiling hubs actually feel pretty dead...This is an RPG in every since of the word, so understand that heavy story sequences, reading, and fairly large areas are all par for the course. There are plenty of things to do in the game and lots of secrets to go off and find. If you buy this game, have fun, and I hope you enjoy it as much as I have

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												DA:O is my absolute favourite not only RPG game but overall RPG series. Some people may find the graphics of this first game a little outdated (though I believe there are online patches available if you're really that bothered), but other than that I would argue it's an essentially flawless experience. As long as you don't overly dislike fairly closed-world games or the occasional use of strategy in battle, there's not much else to complain about. Even if you do dislike those things, though, I'd still encourage you to give the game a chance and maybe watch some playthroughs on YouTube, just because the DA franchise gaming experience is largely unique compared to all the other games I've personally played. I think the greatest appeal of this game is the construction of the narrative. The story is deeply engrossing and involved, with each one of your actions and decisions both in gameplay and dialogue actually changing something about the world and plot. The origins (hA) you pick for your character also change not only other character's treatment of you and the skills you have available, but even the sympathies you yourself begin to hold in relation to the complex world and politics of Thedas. And, of course your role is to save that entire world, so the decisions you make send shockwaves of consequence throughout the entire game but, hey, no big deal. The UE version of this game is an excellent price for not only the long core game itself but also all the available DLCs that are included in this pack. That said, I'd still wait for a sale on the game, just because it's on sale fairly often. If you enjoy RPGs, you should be pretty damn delighted with the rich and complex experience DA:O game offers, and are bound to return to its world for later installments as well.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												At first I despised the whole "group controlling" aspect, because I was looking for another RPG like TES. But after spending 1-2 hours, I started feeling oddly attracted to the game. I literally fell in love. The story is amazing, the graphs are still pretty decent after 4 years, the gameplay is fantastic. Amazing "tactics" system that inspired me to actually strategize my attacks. All hands down, probably the best RPG I played in a long while. That being said, a few things must be said. Firstly, SAVE A LOT. Some quests can be BUG nests, so be extra cautious. Secondly, before you even CONSIDER trying to build a GENERAL character, know that you will encounter party members of different classes, so just pick one path and master it. Otherwise, you will end up creating a weakling-deadweight character whom you will always have to carry in to battle. Long story short, you won't have enough time to master every single skill, so just master one or two if you are lucky.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												I bought this game back in 2009 on xbox when it first came out. I didn't know all that much about it, I just thought it looked interesting. I'm glad I decided to buy because it's one of the best RPGs I've ever played. I put over 100 hours into the gme when I had it for xbox. Now a days I'm a PC gamer and when I saw Origins on sale for only $7 with ALL the DLC, I just had to get it. I have to say the PC version is a step up from the console version. Not only does it look and control better, but there are a ton of awesome mods you can install to improve the game or just add more content. The conversation system is great and really engaging. The story is pretty interesting and theres a ton of lore around it. And the battle system is a good mix between real time action and micromanagement. You can choose to play tactically by pausing the action and planning your attack or you can just run in hacking and slashing. I could go on for days about how great this game is but honestly If you like RPG games with a lot of loot, a challenge and a great story then you'll love Origins.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												This game is one of the best RPG's in existence. It has a diverse cast of characters, each with their own unique look and personality. As the main character, you get to pick your race (human, dwarf, or elf), completely customize your appearence and skill set, and choose between several origin stories (hence the name of the game) for your character. Based on what you choose, NPC's have different reactions towards you. You can also recruit many companions throughout your travels, each packaged with their own backstory and personal quests. The voice acting in the game is pretty amazing. Each companion and major plot line character has a voice that is unique to them and easily recognizable.Gameplay is great as well. While on easier difficulties, you can take whoever you want with you, click on an enemy, and easily win, it is far more complex on higher difficulties. The game uses a tactics system that makes your companions use their abilities to react to certain conditions. On a high difficulty, it is necessary to balance out your companions abilities and tactics to ensure that you will be ready for even the strongest of enemies. If you don't have good balance or don't plan your battles, you will likely be easily destroyed.As far as graphics go, I will admit that this game isn't the best looking (but hey, it's five years old now, so it's pretty easy to overlook, and the other aspects of the game more than make up for it). However, Bioware has made this game easily moddable so there are many mods out there that can completely transform this game. I don't even know how many I have installed, but it's a lot! Overall, this game is just a fantastic RPG with decent graphics, great story, unique characters, amazing voice acting, complex gameplay, and an amazing modding community. If you like RPGs and haven't played this yet,  THEN GET OFF YOUR BUTT AND GET THIS GAME.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												A+With dialogue options that determine storyline and character outcomes and a combat system which allows you to manage and direct each party member individually (which is essential for group cohesion and maximum effectiveness) this is by far one of the best RPG's that I've played. The voice acting is one of the best I've seen in a game, not to mention party members converse with each other independent of the player controlling them resulting in entertaining and humorous banter while you explore. An amazing addition that I enjoyed the whole way through as it changes with each combination of characters you elect to your party. The cutscenes do not take away from gameplay, rather they aid in making the story more cinematic. Pros -  - Good story - Well-rounded combat system with party tactics, allowing player to manage all members as they see fit. - Dialogue choices affect outcome of relationships between player and companions as well as quests and storyline. - Incredible voice acting for all characters (except the player, whose character does not speak). - Professions and skills can affect combat and dialogue options. - Character background choices determine one of many intros to the main game making replay value more worthwhile than just builing a new spec.Cons -  - Maps seem a bit limited in exporability. - Character background, while providing variety, has only minor impact on game outcome, but interaction throughout is noticeably different.Overall: One of my top ten games. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys both RPG and fantasy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												Dragon Age: Origins wove a beautiful tapestry of a country torn apart by encroaching darkness, and interaction with your cadre of companions gives you a wide and deep appreciation of the effects of the Darkspawn rising as well as setting the scene for the Templar/Mage conflict of the second game. Your companions' offhand conversation over the course of the storyline adds amazing color, humor, and occasionally tenderness to both your relationship with them and their own feelings about each other. The combat system, although a little stilted, gives you an excellent range of specializations for your companions, allowing you to build a winning team that suits your personal style. Overall, the inception of this series drew me in as a fan for life. 9.5/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												An absolute must-have for a fanatic Baldur's Gate lover such as me.Compelling storyline and great character development with tons of possibilities for dialogues, interactions and romances. A vast world full of lore and juicy politics, plots and intrigues. Elves and dwarves have an interesting social and political background which is a breath of fresh air from their usual depiction in classic fantasy. The player's choices, race, gender and abilities affect the plot so greatly that I felt the need of starting a new run with a different character even before completing the first one!But what amazed me the most was the feeling of pure EPICNESS I experienced in a lot of scenes and fights. I think it hadn't happened to me in a videogame ever before. I loved it.I recommend buying the full package with all DLCs because... Shale! The grumpy golem is hands-down one of the best characters in the game (and powerful too, with a unique fighting style and set of abilities).I think the word "masterpiece" can apply here :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												I may be one of the biggest RPG nuts around. I've played so many its hard to keep track of them all. That being said Dragon Age: Origins is probably in the top 10 Rpgs I've ever played. EVER. The story is fun and the characters are memorable. The lore that is established is incredible, especially for a game that's the first in what's hopefully a long series. The origins, the main story, and the seemingly meaning ful choices are what set this game apart.If you are familiar with Bioware games such as KOTOR, Baldurs Gate, and NWN then you know how the combat in this game works. If you don't, you need to know that combat is very strategic, and not exactly fast paced. If action packed, fast paced combat is your thing, you may want to skip this one. But if you enjoy strategizing and co-ordinating the skills of varied party members, this will go down as one of your favorites.The only cons I can think of are that there are no maps that you can just free roam on, and the cities that should seem like bustiling hubs actually feel pretty dead...This is an RPG in every since of the word, so understand that heavy story sequences, reading, and fairly large areas are all par for the course. There are plenty of things to do in the game and lots of secrets to go off and find. If you buy this game, have fun, and I hope you enjoy it as much as I have

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												Dragon Age Origins would be considered a spiritual successor to the late and great Bioware RPG known as Baldurs Gate. Both share a similar style of game play and similar style of story and design, though Dragon Age is far superior in terms of production value from its much older cousin-game Baldurs Gate. From amazing graphics (that still stand against most of todays games), to a compelling story line (that can be nearly fully customized despite the obvious fact it has to end), the music and even the sound effects - everything is crisp, clean, easy to run and not too hardware intensive. Set aside a few hours a week if you want to play this fast paced tactical RPG, you won't regret it.

												As a warning, I'm not done with this game yet.This is a story-rich Roleplaying Game where you play as one of the last of an order of protectors fighting to save the world. The setting is a fantasy one with not too many departures from tropes. Characters are generally written well enough. You have a party with which you can develop a variety of relationships including romances. Combat plays like an MMO, but has some extra things that allow you to play more strategically.There's plenty of content and quests to do as well as things to explore in your character's journey.If you like Western RPGs this is well-made one with a story that has depth and a world filled with enemies to rid it of in your travels.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												[CONTAIN SPOILERS!] I got to make friends with a women encounted in a wild swamp and I got a pet war dog. Slaying monsters with a sword in each hand like boss and selecting the characters for my party based on who had best argumentative synergy just for laughs on the road. Spend time building an army to save the lands by making different groups & races love me, because I'm epic at slaying monster and a master of conversation! Shaping the world how I saw fit, making my friend marry his recently killed step-bother's widow in order to become king and when he thought I was going to stay at his side to help out I ran off into the sunset with my women and war dog - just after saving the world of the end times. 11/10 would recommend to a friend.[FREE OF SPOILERS]Now for a serious review: This is a game that I have played many times, each time as a different race, background and class and still today it stands as a excellent game for it's story, combat and is still decent graphically.Creator creation: There are 3 races (both genders), 3 classes (fighter, rouge and mage) and a number of different backgrounds (like Noble). The start of the game is different depending on your background and race which makes the game greatly more replayable. There is the normal customizability at the start for your character that you would expect, eye/hair colour, sound of voice, size of jaw line, character profile picture etc.Combat: Can pause the game during combat, issue commands to your party members or take direct control over them. Set up tatics for each party member, which is used by the AI when your not directly controlling them. Tatical camera gives you an overview of battles or if you would rather be close to the action you can zoom right in and watch all of the blood and gore of combat take place.Story: One of the most oringial, deep and epic that I've seen in a game which is set in a massive world (both in locations and lore). Different startings and many endings based on your actions means you end up with an experience very much unique to you. Like with many BioWare games, you can later import your saved data in the later games DA2 & DA:I (via Dragon Age Keep), which is great to see when playing the later games. The story also gives you the opportunity to often affect the ending (without you realising in most/some cases - if not your 1st time playing it), and even the smallest of quests at the start can lead to events later on in the game. You can easily spend 40-50 hours on a single playthrough if not more (first time on a non-steam version I played it, I spend over 100 hours)!Companions: There are some great companions that you encounter along the way which you would expect from BioWare. Although trying to please everyone to like you the most that they can is difficult as often your actions will gain favour with some and lose favour with others. Also you can get a pet war dog :) If you have never played a Dragon Age game, this is a great introduction to the series. If you have played the later games but not this one, I would recommend you play DA:O as it feels different from the others and one of the best games out there.11/10 would recommend to a friend.Just to state, I've played this game before on PC before buying on Steam with a game time ~400 hours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11
												The characters of Dragon Age are memorable and the story is brutal and interesting. Gameplay of turn based combat is a lot of fun and strategic once you start understanding it. All of the main characters have fair amount of depth to them and they truly feel part of your team.The loot system and gears are varied and pretty cool. You can customize all of your characters in any way you can but a lot of the armors look way too similar and it gets boring to see legendary level armors and weapons that look the same as much cheaper ones.The setting of Dragon Age is both a strength and weakness. The places you go to are memorable and are visually amazing, but there just aren't that many places and they aren't big enough. You basically fast travel from one place to another, and the world doesn't feel big at all.Overall the fantastic story, well done characters and fun combat system definitely makes for a really fun game. The climax of the game also feels epic and hectic. Rating 85

content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												So DAO is much better than DA2 or DAInq. What I just wrote is a fact. There is no way around it. If you liked either of the games I listed as worse than DAO, play DAO, now. My three favorite fantasy game series are Dragon Age, The Witcher, and The Elder Scrolls. I love fantastic worlds with lots of lore and factions that hate each other while crazy original (and unoriginal but look good) monsters run around providing you with quests to simply, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥up and get sexy gear and weapons to ♥♥♥♥ up uglier♥♥♥♥♥♥harder.The story is 10/10. (Bonus though the Warden's Keep, The Stone Prisoner, and Return to Ostagar are all add-ons that come with the Ultimate Edition that once downloaded are applied during the main campaign, they are all ♥♥♥♥ing sweet as hell.) DLC wise, which the Ultimate Edition comes with all of it, the (best waifu Morigan) Witch Hunt dlc was awesome to play through because she was my love interest during the game and I loved being able to choose if you follow that love or not after the events of the main game. The Golems of Amgarrak dlc is hard but a crap ton of fun. Now the Tales of Orzammar was meh, only mattered if your MC was dwarf so if you intend to play the full main story as dwarf then go ahead and do it, it’s basically a prologue of 40 minutes of play. The Darkspawn Cronicles and Leliana's Song are both meh as well, I didn't use Leliana during the campaign so it’s probably more interesting to those that want to learn more about how a priest became a thieving rogue while the Darkspawn Chronicles adds a chance to PLAY THE ♥♥♥♥ING DARKSPAWN! I KNOW RIGHT?!!?! Wrong. The dlc is an alternate storyline which is and never will be cannon but its cool to ♥♥♥♥ up humans with creepy♥♥♥♥♥creatures. (Protip for DC, get an ogre and run it into the explosive barrel holding darkspawn and it explodes without hurting your ogre but decimates everything.)DLC route (Cannon Route and best way to play them route):Main Game (which includes Warden's Keep, The Stone Prisoner, and Return to Ostagar add-ons in the story) -> Dragon Age: Awakening (bomb♥♥♥♥♥extra story and you get to build up a giant fortress and kill a very unique Darkspawn.) -> Golems of Amgarrak -> Witch Hunt (Don't be a♥♥♥♥♥♥to her she comes back in DA:I.)Basically, follow the above route and you will never hit any lore holes or bugs and you will have all the followers without any lore discrepancies (example doing Witch hunt allows you to make the main character disappear in a place for years which means Dragon Age Awakening (the only expansion) makes no sense because it is a couple months after the main story ends. Follow this ♥♥♥♥ing route. Trust me.(Protip: Do The Stone Prisoner dlc ASAP during the main game. Shale is a ♥♥♥♥ing beast and playing with a hilarious♥♥♥♥♥golem that smacks the everyliving♥♥♥♥ outta people is so enjoyable. To those minmaxers, great support that takes damage, the best at it other than if you load up the MC with sword and board.)You can load your progress into DA2 and then DA2 into DA:I or you can import what you did after finishing the campaign onto the website for story and load it into DA:I when starting in. Basically if you play origins and not 2, don't worry, just put what you did in the game into Dragon Age Keep (name of website) then load it in and all your choices and character deaths follow through.This game is easily 9/10 and for some reason the graphics got a lot better as the game progresses, weird but true. They aren't even bad and there are mods to make it look unreal but ♥♥♥♥ that.Also, if you are worried about paying and not getting value for it, my hours account for 1 main campaign, (100% I am proud to say.) and 1 play through of each DLC, the add-ons were installed as well to take into account hours for the main campaign. So yes, this game has a mc♥♥♥♥ton o' depth if you choose to dive in.TL;DR Quit being a♥♥♥♥♥♥and buy this damn game, it is worth every penny if not more. Get Shale. ♥♥♥♥ Morigan's brains out. The Templars always will be,♥♥♥♥♥♥♥Also, add me if you buy it and read my review, I'll talk to you about the damn game as much as you want.
