Posted: November 2, 2015
												Wow.  Just wow.  I had never played a game so immersive and interesting before now.  Dragon Age: Origins has created a monster.  I've always been a pretty casual gamer, but this game and its sequels have found me staying up literally all night to play them.  The story is well-written, the romances are heart-wrenching, and the characters feel so real.  Plus, the combat mechanics really agree with me.  11/10.  This game will always have a place in my heart.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
AUDIO: Nothing Special                                    AESTHETIC: ClassicMEMORABILITY: Expansive                              WORTH: DiscountPROS: Many hours of awesome, fantasy-driven story that will leave you invested. (Played console versions in entirety) Classes all have very different paths, giving DA high replay value. PC version runs well and looks great. Most of the lore is optional in info packs picked up from dialogue and items, meaning you won't be bored to tears or left out of the loop. You can go check out the plethora of information available to you when and if that suits you. Gameplay is very easy to pick up.CONS: Awakening is weak. No steam achievements despite achievements being available on console version. EA game means you're going to get some heckling from third parties, and you'll have keys to redeem. Couldn't seem to get controller working. Those who are expecting highly-technical gameplay to match the plethora of immersive writing will be disappointed.OVERALL: It doesn't break new ground, but it is a definitive title for what it is and is one of the most memorable "stereotypical fantasy" games to have come out in recent years. It is also very friendly to newcomers, making it a good toe in the water for people you want to introduce to the genre.                                                    SCORE: 8/10

content:
Posted: July 9, 2015
												It's 2015 now, 5 years after the release of this game... (Well the steam release at least, i'm not going to bother looking up the official release date) And I still play this game... a lot. Despite Dragon Age: Origins spawning 2 sequels, I always find myself coming back to this one. The textures are bad, run speed is slow, combat takes a while to get engaging but this game is irrefutably the best game in the franchise. Gameplay wise it's extremely polish, allowing for multiple builds and adding new depths of difficulty. Every build has advantages and disadvantages, forcing players to think about where their next skill point should be placed. Dialogue is skippable and the choices are clear and concise, making it easy to judge what an NPC's reaction will be to your choice! However this RPG doesn't use a patronizing dialogue wheel that shows you pictures and says, "This is the NICE option, This is the FUNNY option, This is the MEAN option, This is the option to kill yourself", No, this game knows you're too smart for that and says, "Here's the choices as to what your character will say, NOW ROLEPLAY", Which is an EXTREMELY welcome change from the all too common "Choose your prick" gameplay style. - *cough* Dragon age 2 *cough* -  Story wise it's engaging , constantly forcing the warden to make critical choices that will ultimately affect the ending. Graphics wise it's not the BEST, it could be way better, but graphics never really mattered to me in the long run, and the UI looks really good. The characters and their animation can get comically bad sometimes, but it never gets ugly- *cough cough* Dragon Age 2 *Unconvincing cough* - and the charcter creator is a lot of fun. (I like making characters, don't judge my life choices, you're not my REAL mom!xD) All in all, Dragon age: Origins is a great game, well worth your time and money.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												People usually say Skyrim: Elders Scrolls V was a revolutionary game! I say those people have never played Dragon Age: Origins,!!! This game has it all, graphics, storyline, action, drama, romance, there's a bit in the game for every kind of player. From those who wish to face on hordes of enemies, to those who like things more stealthily. However, none of these features were what attracted me the most to DA:O, I've always been an MMORPG kind of player, and DA despite not being an MMORPG can make you feel like you are in one, its party system lets you experience any class through your companions, despite having chosen a specific one for your character when you first created. It also brings that group work kind of feeling to the whole game, but you're the only one doing all the work, which in my opinion makes it all the most amusing. The combat pause system is something out of this world, something I had never experienced before DA:O and I must say, no other game that offers anything slightly similar to DA has ever pleased me as much, due to the lack of this "game mode"...All in all, to me, this is probably the game of the last decade if not the game of this century, really a must for anyone wanting to try something classic yet revolutionary at the same time.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												The most exciting RPG, that follows the footsteps of the Baldur’s Gate-series. Bioware goes back to its roots, combining classical party-roleplay and tactical battles with a cinematic presentation that reminds to the Lord of the Rings-trilogy by Peter Jackson. The storytelling and the dialogues are fantastic, the sound effects are great and you’ll be deeply involved in the game within minutes. Though, the technical background isn’t state of the art. Lack of high textures and missing details in the surrounding level-area aren’t satisfying. But the grapichs still are not something to hate the gameplay, as it will take you in without a doubt. My all time favorite RPG!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2012
												A simply amazing game.Like many of BioWare's titles, Dragon Age offers a deep and enriching story filled with interesting characters, intriguing lore and unforgettable moments.The main story is quite long, taking me 50+ hours to complete. There is a huge amount of content and large amounts of replayability due to the branching and dynamic storyline. The 'Origins' part of the game - where you choose and play out your background, as well as your own actions and choices - really helps define your character, making them feel unique and personal.While the 'pause and play' style of combat can be slow and repetitive, it's tactical and (most of the time) places you on your toes.With an interesting world, lore, story and characters, Dragon Age Origins is an enthralling experience that will grip you untill it's very last moments----- Potentially Slight Spoilers -----I personally found the last 'boss fight' to be really underwhelming, especially with all the hype and tension placed on you throughout the story. Maybe it was due to the setup or skills that my party had but I personaly found that final battle quite easy.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												This game is amazing just what you expect from bioware. The graphics hold up really well in 2017 and the voice acting is top quality for the most part until you hear some normal soldiers talk and that can sometimes lead to some cring worthy moments.gameplay is in real time but not like the newer dragon age games more like balder's gate and pillars of eternity style combat system but what those games don't have is the 3D enviroments with the beautifull and gory animations. It's tactical and deep and you can make some pretty crazy builds and can be very helpfull in batlle and keep it fresh for multiple playthroughs, you have some great flexibility in the classes in this game.The armor and weapons are just amazing, you really start out with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ MMO style gear but when you start hitting lev 10 and beyond the variation is just breathtaking just look up some armor pieces and weapons and you will know what i'm talking about. the story is for me personally the best of all the dragon age games because it reminds me a lot of Game Of Thrones. It has many moments that will hit you with twists and turns and most of all shocking deaths that you can control at some points but mostly is out of your hands.What sell this game and makes it so original above all the other dragon age games or Other RPG's in general is the "origins" in the titel. Yes, you have the choice to choose between 6 different (origin) stories depending if you are a human. elf or dwarf. This means above the main story that revolves around the darkspawn invasion, you get your own personal backstory that you actually take part in at the beginning and throughout the story will be faced with actions that will determin not only your Origin story but the faith of the main story as well. This is trully an amazing game and i still hope that in the future Bioware wil make another dragon age game with the origins style storytelling but with the newer combat and class systems.9/10.Sidenote: played over 100 hours on ps3 so yeah my review is legit and yes the PC version is FAR superior than the console version.

												This is a great game considering it's age (unintentional pun). It's main positives would be it's massive amount of possible quests and unique npc interaction, it does a very good job in creating a real story that gets you hooked (which is something i have to come to constantly expect from bioware). But every games has it's faults, the battle and fighting system is very slow paced and boring to take part in (this is something that the second installment fixed) and some classes mainly the mage, dual weapon rouge and/or warrior are quite unbalnced, this is as with a dual weapon user can breeze through a massive amount of eneimies with ease, but the mage will struggle with it's lack of health and resistances (unless you are some sort of god). This is especially clear in the early parts of the game such as the tower of magi where going solo through it can really f**k you up, I myself have become infuriated at the amount of damage (or lack of) a single mage will put out when going through the game, whereas the npc's such as a well equiped zevran and alistair can melt eneimes, and in this alistair will also take zero damage being a tank. This is most apparent with the dlc of DAO as the OP equipment you recieve from it give characters like alistair and zevran a huge powerstrike. (first detailed review plz no hate). Overall a good introduction to the game, where combat lacks story flourishes, the oppisite for DA2, but then brought to a balance of both aspects in the third game DA Inqusition.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2016
												Dragon Age Origins is an archetype descended from Tolkien that's been done so many times before, and better, but is still competent enough to have fun playing, despite its many flaws. As always, Bioware has created an expansive, engaging world, and as always, exploring that world and creating an identity within it take a backseat to being the Savior of Humanity. As well crafted and compelling as the personal origin stories are, each is quickly redirected for the player to become The Chosen One, and then lays out a mostly predetermined path through Ferelden. While it is possible to choose which towns to be the Savior of Humanity at in which order, every decision and battle is done first and foremost as a Grey Warden. The graphics are a trough slop of jaggedness, stiffness, and clipping, and the music is a mostly forgettable blend of generic Fantasy songs. Gameplay is a party-based, real-time, Fantasy RPG which can be paused mid combat to issue commands. Party AI can be organized through the tactics screen, but characters will still need to be micromanaged lest they slip into their favorite pastime, posing dramatically on the battlefield while everyone around them is slaughtered. Nightmare difficulty mode was challenging enough to remain interesting, even into the later stages of the game, though I imagine lower difficulties would be less engaging. And sadly, it doesn't take much looking to find EA's tacky profiteering, but that is no fault of Bioware's.It is the storytelling that shines as DAO's real strength, and while not a word of it escapes from standard Fantasy tropes or clichés, it still remains very competently constructed. There are pages and pages of historical text, so as not to disappoint the furious people who thought they were installing a book rather than a game, but there is also strong characterization and voice acting in the companions, despite the awkward way they stare and move in conversations, like wooden puppets occasionally struggling against their strings for freedom. As per Bioware standard, the player may interact with the characters of Ferelden through helpful, self-interested, or for some reason, bewilderingly pissy conversation options.There are some non spoiler elements I really wish I’d known going into the game that I shall list here to spare others from my mistakes. Firstly, there are locked chests EVERYWHERE. Cunning is required to unlock these chests, aided by the Rogue talent, Deft Hands. Without a rogue with high cunning in the party, easily half of the loot in the game is forfeited. Secondly, cunning is required to access many dialogue and story options, aided by the Coercion skill. Many choices are simply unavailable without cunning, but since only the cunning of the player’s character counts for these checks, and cunning is only useful as a combat stat for Rogues, the player must either choose a melee Rogue, take a large hit to combat effectiveness, or forgo several story options throughout the game.Coddle the warden’s teammates! Mirror their opinions in conversations and make all decisions in the world based on which characters are currently in the party. This desperate bid for a follower’s approval directly affects their stats, and if the player’s popularity drops too low, their followers will simply walk away, impending apocalypse be damned. Remember that DAO isn’t about exploration or curiosity, and tiptoe carefully around the judgmental fragility of teammates whenever the temptation to pursue something interesting arises, or risk losing a group member, their role in the party, and all their god damned gear.DON’T RECRUIT THE DOG!!! I cannot stress this enough. Once the dog has been recruited, nearly every conversation initiated at camp will be competing with its loud barking, and there’s no option to remove it from the party or throw it into a volcano. For those players who want to catch every detail of interaction between characters, this dog is the quickest route to panic attacks.Lastly, while it is possible to romance certain companions with the typical, cutesy exchange of quips and cleverness, even mundane interactions with them can make the game assume something is going on. After telling Zevran it didn’t bother me that he stared at me, people starting referring to us as an item. In the epilogue, it said that he mourned my loss, and while he took many other partners to bed, he never loved again. I had maybe three conversations with that elf…

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												A party based RPG with an optional RTS/Tactical element of zooming far out and getting a better view of the field. You can pause the game and issue orders to your party at will, giving you time to think and plan ahead, especially in the tougher battles. The game has a tactics system you can set up for each party member that works similarly to gambits in Final Fantasy XII. For example: Ally Health <50% - Use Ability: Heal, and so on. You can unlock more tactics slots by leveling up, and also by spending a skill point for even more slots.It's a quality RPG with a rich story, oceans of codex, and MMO driven combat by Bioware. Dragon Age: Origins has loads to do in the main campaign alone, let alone the expansion it comes with.Unfortunately the game was coded like a potato, causing the game to chug like a drunk fratboy due to memory leaks unless you reboot the game every hour or so.Technical issues aside and only one crash so far, it runs stable enough.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												Dragon Age, the classic game brought to you by the makers of Mass Effect, KOTOR and Jade Empire. Certainly better than its half arsed sequal after EA ♥♥♥♥ed Bioware into a shell of its former self. You are the grey warden and you'll be going on a quest to save the entire realm from darkness... yeah it's pretty much the typical good must triumph over good story, nothing really original but still interesting nonetheless. You'll battle creatures like the undead, dark monsters, and surprisingly a few dragons. This is Biowares classical style of game, where the main character is a mute and there's a lot of detail to the world you inhabbit. I do prefer Dragon Age 2's voice acting and some of the characters, however in this game when you make a character from the start you have the freedom to make a human, elf or a dwarf and a choice of different backgrounds to start the story from. Whether you want to be a human noble or an Elf ranger, as well as the choice of class for your character, of which it is limited to 3: Warrior, Rogue and Mage. It would have been better if there were more of a variety of classes like the Elder Scrolls, or even their own game Mass Effect which has sci-fi rpg classes of about 6.Dragon Age: Origins is a must have if you are an RPG nut and you like fantasy worlds inhabbited by Elves and Dwarves.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												For the past decade, Bioware has been heralded as the undisputed king of roleplaying games, largely because of a single game: Baldur's Gate II: Shadows of Amn. Those who have experienced the tale need no explanation, but for those whose gaming histories are lacking, I shall say simply that Shadows of Amn is quite definitively the quintessential title of the entire roleplaying genre. The success of Shadows of Amn fueled Bioware to develop the massively successful Star Wars: Knights Old Republic, Neverwinter Nights and its many expansions, Jade Empire, and more recently Mass Effect. Sadly, none of Bioware's subsequent titles managed to fully recapture the raw quality of gaming present in Shadows of Amn. So it was that when Bioware began to bill their latest RPG, Dragon Age: Origins as the spiritual successor to Baldur's Gate, we stood up, and we took notice.Dragon Age: Origins appears to offer us exactly what we wanted—a return to the depth of gameplay we found in Shadows of Amn. Bioware promised us deep gameplay, a strong and compelling narrative, unique characters, absurd quantities of side-quests and banter and content of all kinds. The question we are now faced with is this: did Bioware deliver on its promises?As is often the case with such things, our answer is both yes and no. Dragon Age: Origins offers a stronger gameplay mechanic, more content, and better writing than nearly any other "Western" roleplaying game in the past decade. To be perfectly honest, the only other game that even begins to approach the depth and character of Bioware's latest title is CD Projekt Red's phenomenal RPG, The Witcher. In some places, Dragon Age: Origins manages to succeed the standard set by Baldur's Gate, yet in others it falls short. Nevertheless, gamers looking for a strong, immersive RPG experience need look no further than Dragon Age: Origins, which is rapidly taking its place as one of the best fantasy titles produced after Bioware killed off the Infinity Engine nearly one decade ago.Dragon Age: Origins is by no means a perfect game, or another "quintessential" example of the genre. It has its faults and its faults are many, but it also has its own, unique charm. And make no mistake: Dragon Age is most-certainly one of the very best games we have seen in a very, very long time.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												You start the original campaign by creating your character. You can choose from three different races (dwarf, elf, or human) and three different roles (mage, rogue, or warrior). This gives you eight (no dwarven mages) combinations to choose from. You can also choose from different social backgrounds depending on which race you picked. I played a dwarf casteless warrior. Regardless of how you make your character, events will eventually lead to you being the one who has to unite all of the races to fight the darkspawn invasion. The storyline is fairly common, but well-written. It requires you to deal with the tensions and politics between and within the races for much of the campaign.  Another interesting aspect of the game is some of the difficult choices you will encounter. The consequences of your choices will influence future events in game and the final outcome. For example, you will have the option of recruiting a warrior who murdered a family to help you deal with the darkspawn or leaving him in a cage to die. The combat is real time. You can pause it and select different characters, make them use different abilities, or use different items. The game features a tactics system that will make each character use certain abilities in certain situations. You can modify the tactics use or disable them completely. I opted to disable tactics since the default settings for some characters were pretty annoying. Some characters will use abilities at times that are inconvenient.Each class features an interesting variety of talents for each class. There are passive talents and talents that give your characters additional abilities.  If you play a warrior, you can use talents that support a sword and shield build, a dual-wielding build, or a build that requires a two-handed weapon.The difficulty is appropriately tuned overall. I played on normal difficulty setting. The difficulty scaled well with the endgame encounters being more difficult overall than the rest of the game. This game has some technical issues. There are invisible walls. In some places, your characters can’t walk up stairs. They have to run up them. There were a few exploits to be used. For some encounters, I could stand at max range with a mage, hit enemies with normal attack, and they would not react.The Awakening Expansion features a new storyline, a new territory, adds new abilities to the existing ones, and mostly new characters. You can either import your character from Origins or create a new one.The story of Awakening features a little more mystery than its predecessor. It’s quite good and, in my opinion, better than the story line in Origins. It features some fascinating choices that I won’t reveal because of spoilers.The rest of the expansion doesn’t feature as many side quests and storylines as the original. It took me 42 hours to complete Awakening compared to 94 for Origins. The difficulty seems to be easier in Awakening. Enemies don’t always scale to the level of your party. My warrior tank felt unkillable since he took very little damage.Overall, Origins features a good storyline and strong role-playing elements which make it a game worth playing. This combined with the story in Awakening is why you should get Ultimate Edition.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												I really hesitated to write this review, because so many people have told me (and will probably tell you) that Dragon Age: Origins is one of the greatest games ever made. I don't think it is. But it's still a great game and worth picking up at the full retail price (a rare thing in itself!).So what's good? Story, characters. BioWare is famous for both; Dragon Age Origins is one of the games that sustained that reputation. Choices have REAL consequence; alternatives have different outcomes, not the same outcome with different dialog. Music is superb, and though dated, the game still looks awesome (mods can help). Upgrade trees are deep and varied. There is a ton of loot and side-quests. The world of the game is huge (even though it's actually dozens of smaller hub-worlds). And the different races each come with their own scripted origin stories that you actually play through (instead of just having a wall of text to read).So... (start scary music) what's – dare I say it – bad? Subjectively (not objectively), my primary issue is the combat. I know what you're thinking. “Another FPS dummy who can't understand tactics! Dood hates to think when he games. Go have fun with mindless drivel, Dragon Age Origins is for REAL gamers.” Trust me, I've heard plenty of the hate. Hear me out, though. I've played this game using multiple methods and techniques – my playtime numbers indicate the amount of time I've devoted to figuring this game out. I leveled my characters with deep (highly developed) specializations, not trying to put points into everything, and didn't neglect my passives. I brewed potions and oils, created traps and explosives. Had plenty of Health poultices and Lyrium potions on hand. I balanced my party with: one “tank” (i.e. a damage sponge), one healer, and one that fights from a distance (I preferred another mage). And I took pains over my party tactics. Tactics are the default actions your AI squad-mates take. The learning curve is steep here, but after some trial and error, this is one of the keys to successful combat. Once combat is initiated, your squad-mates will attack whatever the tactics dictate they should attack. Failing that, they will attack whatever enemy you are fighting. Sounds good. Frequently, though, a character will have more skills than tactics slots. So the only way to use that skill in battle is to pause the action, select the squad-mate, and manually execute the command. If you don't want to die – A LOT – pausing isn't a feature to be occasionally utilized; it becomes a requirement in order to survive. Pausing the game occasionally is fine, but once it becomes an integral part of the combat, a few things happen:1. Gameplay starts to feel choppy, with a constant go-stop-go-stop-go feeling.2. Because of the above, there isn't any real flow to the combat. 3. Battles stretch out way too long. Given the length of some missions – like the Deep Roads – that's potentially hours spent going through one region. The alternative I found is to play the game (mostly) in real time, with a few pauses here and there to issue specific orders for specific bosses. This prohibits me from ramping up the difficulty level. Normal is more like Hard when played in this manner. Orange-lettered bosses take forever to fall. But the gameplay flows better and the story progresses much more quickly. The combat isn't "bad" per se; just awkward and choppy for those (like me) who don't want to manage every detail of a combat situation.Dragon Age Origins is a great adventure, no question, with some of the best writing, choices and characters that have ever graced a video game. If that's what appeals to you, go ahead and purchase it, you'll love it. If you love “classic” turn-based RPG combat, you'll probably love the game even more. Some micro-managing required. On DLC:Get the Ultimate Edition, or don't buy the game. There is a lot of DLC, and the Ultimate Edition bundles it all up in one tidy package. An account on social.bioware.com is required to access and download your DLC, though.

												12/15 Stars. RPG.If you want a good Role-Play-Game to sink your teeth into, start with Dragon Age Origins. The immersive world will suck you in and leave you wondering just which of your companions you want to bonk.Pros: - Interesting Story - Fleshed Out Characters - Well paced combat - Plenty of contentCons: - The first hour or so of the game is a bit of a slog, but once you press on it's more enjoyable. - Exploration was done oddly. Has a map and you auto-travel around it by clicking, and then you come across random encounters which feel like forced time-extension to the game. - Reused areas

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												8.5/10 One of the best strategy games I have ever played, if we are not counting Total War games then this would be the best strategy game I have ever played. (if i remember them all)Dragon Age: Origins - Ultimate Edition has many storylines and the combat system is perhaps slower than some would prefer because of the need to pause to give comands throughout a fight. I personally like the feature. The graphics are able to be crap or awesome depending on your PC needs so dont worry about having a weak computer, you can play Dragon Age regardless of your PC.There are some parts of the lore that drive me nutts that I would like to change; but I cant go changing portions of a game now can I? I would say that despite the occasional glitch and the fact that the game is rather difficult at times it is good for all ages. Screw whatever the "official" rating is I can see anyone 12+ playing this game and enjoying it, provided they are not too stupid to play the game.This game also has many mods on the Nexus as well as the Nexus Mod manager compatability.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
Personal Rating: Buy on summer sale if you like lengthy RPGs with a whole bunch of lore to appreciateTraditional Rating: 6.5/10 maybe higher, but not lowerCan't promise this will be spoiler free (it's not), but I'll do my best (spoilers are hidden behind spoiler bars).If You're Going to Buy DLC...Return to Ostagar provided some closure that the original game didn't.Soldiers's Keep or whatever it's called added some lovely lore to the whole Grey Warden business.Shale's expansion is okay if you like the dwarves and want to know more about the golems. Plus the new areas are very pretty. Those who hate birds will share a very special bond with our miniature golem.Awaken wasn't really worth it, in my opinion. If it goes on sale, maybe. Was basically DA:O but with different characters and a thousand-breasted slug monster instead of a dragon.Feastday Gifts is not worth your time or money; cheap way of gaining character affection that loses its novelty very quickly.Whatever the version where you can play as darkspawn is was fun, never finished it because holy crap is it difficult and yet gets boring at the same time.Where did that 3.5 go?The Mage's Circle Quest (2.0):There's actually a mod which removes it from the game[www.nexusmods.com] because it's so lengthy and repetitive and annoying and I just want to get on with the story please let me out of The Fade! Seriously, Bioware,  if people are modding a whole 2 hours of gameplay out of a game, you messed up.Main Character (0.0):S/he serves as a foil for the other (much more interesting) characters. I understand wanting to let the player throw their own personality on to a character, but if you're okay with giving the character a backstory, give them a personality. Only one I can see being appropriate in not having a personality is if you went with the mage route. Since this is a minor, quib, I didn't make it count towards the overall rating I gave.Choices (1.0):In terms of actual choices (aside from some dialouge choices and one choice), they all boiled down to being excessively nice to please Alistair or unnecessarily mean to humour Morrigan. Something that Might Bother Other People (0.0):The combat has tactical view with the ability to pause mid-fight. I found it wasn't necessary until closer to the end (then again, I was playing on easy because I'm horrible at these kinds of games), but it does a fantastic job of interrupting the flow in combat.Minor Grumbles (0.5):The "love-making" scenes were rather immersion-breaking. Seriously, I have never seen something as gratuitous as sex for sex's sake used well in a game - it's like you're listening to someone read The Return of the King to you and suddenly they switch to... say 50 Shades of Grey. Thankfully, these can be avoided as long as you don't mind hurting any characters' feelings. THIS IS A SPOILER, if you still read it, that's your own fault. When you go to kill the Archdemon at the end of the game, Alistair will insist on sacrificing himself if your character is a lady and friends/more with him and you didn't complete the ritual with Morrigan. While I understand that sacrificing himself for a friend is totally in his character, he doesn't do this for the male mains, (regardless of how close he is to them) and I wanted my moment of sacrifical glory; gosh dangit, stop stealing the spotlight from me you royal bugger!. On the topic of characters and their feels, the dialogue becomes some sort of delicate political dance where you say one thing but it ends up meaning something that you definitely did not mean to say. Also, the game way overstayed its welcome. 72 hours for one playthrough - and it was my second time through (on easy)! A fair amount of that was unecessary padding; could probably have made it 40 hours and still gotten as much out of it.Dragons:What the heck is up with the rock music in the trailers and the emphasis on dragons? There were four dragons and two of them weren't in the main story and one of the ones in the main story was Morrigan's mother! It did add to the whole large-scale awe of fighting one though. It didn't end up turning dragons in to barbeque lighters with wings.The Part Where I'm NiceCharacter Dialogue:I would have bought this game just for the background dialogue between main characters. I picked my parties in-game for the background dialogue (Zevran, Morrigan, Alistair/Sten, and Wynne; I was a rogue), I spent hours trying to figure out how to trigger party banter and eventually downloaded a mod that increased the amount of times banter started. Bioware definitely knows how to flesh out characters when they want to.Lore:You know that feeling when you want to find and read all the possible history of the universe you're playing in? Yeah I got that feeling while I was playing this game. While there are a few subtle rewards for understanding the basic lore, I can only think of a couple examples where digging deeper had any payoff. I can understand they didn't want to alienate players who don't read a lot, though, so that's okay.Conversation:I know the choices don't all matter in the end, but they certainly feel like they do at the time and those little nods to events later in-game really do make them feel more important. Not to mention I got way more enjoyment out of pestering Sten with endless questions than I should have.All in all a fun game that I managed to sink 72 hours in to - and that's only counting my second full playthrough. First one was not with a steam copy, so I would estimate around 160+ hours have been spent on this game. Flaws didn't hugely detract from the fun to play factor.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												I have tried to get into this game pretty much since it came out, but to no avail. I adore Bioware's Mass Effect, but it seemed like no matter how many playthroughs I gave Origins, I still wasn't going to be charmed in the same way I was with ME. But finally, on probably my sixth or seventh attempt at completing the game, I fell in love with it!I'd definitely say this is a title you have to mod- the vanilla graphics are, well, 2009, and the gameplay has some rather frustrating design flaws that might leave new players feeling aggravated. But Nexus has everything you need to make the game shine as much as it possibly can, so I would recommend a stop there before firing up a new game. The gameplay is extremely well thought out and flexible to different play types. Lower difficulties combined with god mods will turn it into almost a hack and slash- a good choice if you're here for the story but aren't a fan of the sometimes difficult gameplay. Higher difficulties offer an almost turn based sort of battle chess, which is loads of fun because there's an endless number of combinations of spells and attacks that can be combined for added damage and unique effects. Each character can receive a maximum of twenty five combat tactics slots, which can be set with extremely detailed parameters, making automating party member behaviour a breeze. If you're a fan of older JRPGs or tabletops, you'll have a ton of fun with the gameplay in this. Character creation is extraordinary, and definitely will not leave you feeling class locked. It's a very nuanced system that allows for growth right up until the end of the game. I played as a Mage, a class I normally would not pick because I prefer melee classes. However, the game offers the option to further specialize in two subclasses at level 7 and 14, which allowed me to create highly offensive mage that could use both magic and melee weapons with equal strength. You can make some truly unique players, and the armor/weapons add even more depth to the system, as they grant perks and can be modified as well. The story, I'm sure it goes without saying, is pretty damn good. You'll feel a bit like the errand boy of Ferelden instead of a warrior dedicated to slaying demons at times, but the pay off for most of the quests is good enough to make the slower parts worth it. The characters are lovable and the dialogue well written and voice acted. It's darker and grittier than Mass Effect, which I really liked, and has some truly memorable moments. As usual with Bioware games, player choice affects the game world, and I feel like this game has perhaps the best range of good/neutral/evil options of any of their games. Outcomes are pretty unpredictable and some of the decisions and negotiations actually made me stop and think for a moment. tl;dr Mass Effect but dark fantasy, mod it, play it, probably love it.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												I mean, what is there to say that hasn't already been said?  The characters are amazing, the gameplay is...alright.  The story's not ORIGINAL, but it is still VERY good.  All-in-all, this game gets a 9/10.  Here's the breakdown:Writing: 10/10.  I thought this game was fantastically well-written with each character having distinct characteristics, likes, dislikes, and just general likability.Music: 8/10.  It's got good music, but none of it is memorable to me.  It sorta sits in the background, which I guess is its purpose, but you also don't find yourself humming any of the songs when you're trying to sleep at night.Gameplay: 9/10.  Solid, but trite.  It's been done.  Raise your numbers so you do more numbers and those numbers help you find arbitrary gear that raises your numbers more.  If you're into this sorta thing (I am, so very much), then it's gold.Story: 9/10.  Like I said, the story's been done before.  Lone hero has to save the world from an unspeakable evil by slowly gathering an army about him, one group at a time.  That being said, the story's kept fresh with some fantastic writing and excellent worldbuilding.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												This is the first game I've played in this series (haven't played any of the Baldur's Gate games). I have however, played similar games in the past. This game begins pretty slow but grew into something much more than I thought it would become. The party members are all dynamic and interesting and will leave you cursing the 4 members limitation. The quests are usually not that deep but the combat system and the character interactions are amazing. Graphics aren't anything extraordinary but there are some mindblowing views at certain sections of the game. Randome encounters when travelling from one city to another can get annoying at times. The different in-game guilds do not really make you feel like you're a part of the guild (unlike the assassins brotherhood and the thieves guild in Skyrim which made you feel like a true member). While the dungeons are pretty varied and interesting, the main cities themselves are usually extremely small and not very interesting to explore. Combat can at times get overwhelming with the large number of skills and many of which are usually repetitive. The DLC is pretty decent and grants some useful skills and items to your party members. Overall, it is a pretty good game, definitely overrated but still worth playing.8/10

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												First off this game is amazing, even though its starting to show its age. I have played all three versions of this game, Xbox360, PS3, and now on PC. Its a no brainer, PC is the best version of this game hands down! Graphically It looks alot better on PC, of course, most of the game looks way better and the menu selection/navigation is a joy compared to the barf console version. The gameplay and the controls on the PC are what make you wonder why they even bothered with the clunky garbage console setup, but money talks. The UI is setup more like a MMORPG with hotbars for ease of play. WASD is friendly territory for movement ect. ect. but It actually feels like a refined version of the old Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic engine. Spacebar is defaulted as the "pause" button for more accurate tactical choices, easy awesomeness. Play this game on PC if you can! Even if you have played the console versions! Its like a whole new experience! Yes, the Ultimate Edition works with all the content straight from the download! Cheers STEAM!

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Its the best game for your dollar, I recomend it for people who like a great storyline with witty characters. The battle style takes a few to get used to, but other than that, its a must have game. Im quite addicted to it!:Edit:I have played close to 100 hours on it, and i still feel as if i have yet to hit all of the storys. The ending can change depending on what choices you have made so far up untill the ending. I liked how the groups you can fight with at the end, you can change. Elves VS Werewolves. Dwarfs VS Golems. Templars VS Mages. If you have beat the game, you know what i am talking about. If you have yet to beat the game, i recommend that you do!The awakening part of the game, well it could have been better. It was still fun, but maybe its because i dont have the nitch for politics, that everyone hated me in the end, when i tried doing the best i could. The ending of Awakening, was a bit stale, but im still glad i played it for the insite of the chars ill be with in Dragon Age 2.Most people say they dont like it because of "the art style" or "bad graphics" or maybe you "got bored".. Well to all of those people out there i say, how are you a gamer. The art style im sure was great back >>>When The Game Was Made<<< but to live up to the newer games? Thats a good chunk of time difference there my friend. If your getting bored playing it, then your not a RPG player. I like the RPG games, where it takes you hours to complete, if you ever to complete it. Maybe your just another FPS, stick to those if you like mind numbing shootouts. (No offence) But frankly, you must not like playing something that requires you to think, Or that if you have beer with it you cant just butten spam and be done with it. THIS IS NOT THAT TYPE OF GAME. There said it. Now before all you people out there want to go and throw a hissy fit because i just "insulted you". Im not saying you are all drunks, or that you all are stupid. I stated that before so those who that applies to can shoo. If you are the type who likes RPG games, but didnt like this game, for what ever reason, then the more to you. Im not trying to insult you guys, just the ones who have no sence in reviews. Some games just arnt for some. For those of you thinking of buying this game, i say, go for it, if you are unsure because of a Neg review that had thought put behind it, then wait for a sale, and try it then.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2015
												This is the first game I've played in this series (haven't played any of the Baldur's Gate games). I have however, played similar games in the past. This game begins pretty slow but grew into something much more than I thought it would become. The party members are all dynamic and interesting and will leave you cursing the 4 members limitation. The quests are usually not that deep but the combat system and the character interactions are amazing. Graphics aren't anything extraordinary but there are some mindblowing views at certain sections of the game. Randome encounters when travelling from one city to another can get annoying at times. The different in-game guilds do not really make you feel like you're a part of the guild (unlike the assassins brotherhood and the thieves guild in Skyrim which made you feel like a true member). While the dungeons are pretty varied and interesting, the main cities themselves are usually extremely small and not very interesting to explore. Combat can at times get overwhelming with the large number of skills and many of which are usually repetitive. The DLC is pretty decent and grants some useful skills and items to your party members. Overall, it is a pretty good game, definitely overrated but still worth playing.8/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												Mixed feelings on this game. I'll recommend it, sure, but know what you're getting into. This game will take time, annoyance and then some more time. It's an old school RPG, save constantly or die, and a lot of the finer points of the game, you'll have to figure out entirely on your own. Or google, which may hurt your immersion every so slightly.My first try to get started, I played less than an half an hour. Dwarf noble was just not a very exciting backstory, and trying to be an archer from level 1 did not quite work given the melee-arena grind that is the dwarf quest.Second time I figured I'd go in the opposite direction. Dalish TwoHand Warrior it was. The game felt sluggish as hell, and by the time I'd gotten to the point where the world opens up and you can go where you want, I didn't really want to go anywhere. I wanted my character to die.Third time though, as a dual wielding dwarf commoner rogue, my character felt right. The entire pacing of the fights was vastly improved, and I've been able to play since then.Good stuff:- A well fleshed out RPG universe- Hard is actually so hard, every save you forgot to do will haunt you- Fun playing around with different character from the party in combat to get some variety- Immersive soundtrack, and often quite beautiful enviroments.- A certain sequence in the mage tower was nothing short of epic.- Lots of content- Sten, Ohlgren, Leliana, Wynne, Shale and my dog were enjoyable companions.Bad:-  Loading screens. Ever more of them.-  You will probably need to pick certain party members every time due to their usefulness in combat, instead of taking party selection more In Character. *glares at mage characters in the party*-  Any KOTOR players will miss the option to queue actions so badly. You need to pause and jump through your party EXTREMELY vigilantly if you don't want the AI to waste spells for you etc.  For a game that is otherwise so similiar, its a shame they didn't include that as well.- Difficult fights are a bit random. Every now and then you'll cruise through enemies that storywise are "tough", then meet some random encounter that is death incarnate unless you've played the exact encounter before already. Meaning, you actually depend on having fought and lost to sort out a lot of the fights. This is ok, ofc, but with the many loading screens it gets annoying, and often makes me decide to quit the game and do something else instead.- Lots of content: There are a lot of good games out there, and limited amounts of time. This game takes a lot of time to get the most out of.- Allistair and Morrigan. Neither is particularly well written, and while both can be amusing, they're sub-par for Bioware. Sadly, they're pretty essential characters to bring if you're not a tank or a mage yourself. Additional comments:- Leliana's song DLC was pretty fun.- Darkspawn Chronicles seems to be really bugged.- By the time I'd finished the game, I hadn't talked to my companions for 13-20 hours. I'd used all their dialogue. That it's as limited as that sucks.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												First off this game is amazing, even though its starting to show its age. I have played all three versions of this game, Xbox360, PS3, and now on PC. Its a no brainer, PC is the best version of this game hands down! Graphically It looks alot better on PC, of course, most of the game looks way better and the menu selection/navigation is a joy compared to the barf console version. The gameplay and the controls on the PC are what make you wonder why they even bothered with the clunky garbage console setup, but money talks. The UI is setup more like a MMORPG with hotbars for ease of play. WASD is friendly territory for movement ect. ect. but It actually feels like a refined version of the old Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic engine. Spacebar is defaulted as the "pause" button for more accurate tactical choices, easy awesomeness. Play this game on PC if you can! Even if you have played the console versions! Its like a whole new experience! Yes, the Ultimate Edition works with all the content straight from the download! Cheers STEAM!

												I haven't played this in a couple of weeks but if you combine my xbox versions total play time with this you would get close to 2000 hours played since the games release. And I genuinely never get bored. Such a great story and amazing characters. And personally I love the gameplay. This is genuinely one of my favourite games and I'm surprised at how few people have this game on my friends list, and of those who do, how little time has been played. So I urge you to give it another go or even pick it up.Also be sure to go to the nexus site for mods there are some pretty good mods there. And if  any of you don't know about the nexus check it out it's really helpful for finding and installing mods and you get an unlimited free trial.Seriously, if this is in the Christmas sales do yourself a favour and just buy this game.This, to me, was Bioware at the top of their game. Right before EA could get their money grubbing paws all over them.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												Well Hello fellow Gamer's, Testers and Game designers.  Where to start On such a Magnitutde of a game.I'll start by saying I have played through most of this game, including most of the DLC as I own Ultimate edition for both Origin and Steam.  I think from memory I have beaten the game just the once near releae time.  That was Many years ago now however.  Ultimate edition comes with all the released DLC Made available for the game.  Grahpics 7/10 Could look a lot better but understandable as I imagine Bioware wanted the game to run on lower end PC's as well. Gameplay 8/10 Pretty good gameplay quests aquisition, dialogue, exploration, codex entries and loot are all their.  Story 9/10 As some would excepect from Bioware a top developer not the most Original but certanly keeps you interested.  Combat 8/10 Combat works well smooth responsive attacking varied abilities and talents.  Sound 9/10 Very good music throught fitting and eerie to suit the tone and theme of the game.  Overall 9/10 Stellar RPG Game Definatley one of the best in recent years.  Their you have it my first game reveiw hope you al enjoyed it and please feel free to comment on it with thumbs up or down.

												Better than DA2 and DAI. While less customizable, and with slower combat, and worse graphics, it remains the only truly enjoyable installment in the series of Dragon Age.
